Thus he released from all previous impressions of\nconsciousness.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The words used by\nPatanjali for the state of tranquillity constitute atia prasadanam, adhyatma\nprasadanam, svarasa vahini and ananla samapattih. When agitated, consciousness\nis brought to an undisturbed state; it is citta prasadanam (favourable\ndisposition of citta). When sorrows are subdued, it is svarasa vahini (flow of\nthe soul's fragrance). When exertion in search of the soul ceases, it is ananla\nsamapattih (assuming the original and eternal form). Expertise in meditation is\nadhyatma prasadanam (manifestation of the light of the soul). All convey a\nsimilar meaning - that the seeker and the sought are one; that the seeker is\nthe seer.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">That high level of\nmastery called nirodhah-parinamah occurs in the moment of transition when there\nis a convergence of the rising tendency of deep impressions, the subsiding\ntendency, and the attention of the mind field itself.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The steady flow of this\nstate (nirodhah-parinamah) continues by the creation of deep impressions\n(samskaras) from doing the practice.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nirodha parinama is an\nadvanced stage in a yogi's spiritual journey. In this stage, the mind is\nliberated and no longer influenced by thought-waves, or citta vritti.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nstate of nirodha parinama is considered to be a transformational state because\nas the citta vritti cease, the mind is freed to connect with the moment as it\nappears.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Reaching a state of nirodha parinama &nbsp;takeS a lot of practice and concerted,\ncontinual effort. It requires the yogi to have the power to command and\nrestrain their own mind. When they are in this state, the yogi can immediately\nrecognize any samskaras that accumulate and be in control.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The flow of nirodha\nparinama becomes steady through habit.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The restraint of rising\nimpressions brings about an undisturbed flow of tranquility.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When this suppression\nof thought-waves becomes continuous, the mind's flow is calm.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">By constant and\nuninterrupted practice the mind can remain in a state of attention for a long\ntime.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The steady flow of this\nstate (nirodhah-parinamah) continues by the creation of deep impressions\n(samskaras) from doing the practice.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nirodha parinama bringS\nabout a free flow of peace, tranquility and spontaneous freeing of the mind,\nunencumbered by thought waves. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nirodha parinama is the\nfirst state of the three parinamas, or great transformations, which together\nbring the complete liberation of the mind</span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">3.11 --- sarvarthataikagratayoh\nkshayodayau chittasya samadhiparinamah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The weakening of\ndissipated attention and the rise of one-pointed attention in the citta is the transformation\ntowards samadhi. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Consciousness wavers\nbetween multi-faceted and one-pointed attention. When one-pointed attention is\nestablished, multi-faceted attention disappears; when one-pointed attention\nfades, consciousness is scattered. Observing these alternations and learning to\nhold unwaveringly to single-pointed attention is the second phase of the\ntransformation - samadhi parinama.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Citta has two properties\n- dispersiveness (sarvarthata citta) and one-pointedness (ekagrata citta), with\nwhich it can direct its attention externally or internally. It can unite these\ntwo powers into one, to move towards spiritual absorption.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Citta assumes the form\nof any object seen, observed or thought of. It can spread itself as much as it\nwishes to. When it spreads, it is multi-faceted; when it remains steadily\nfocused, it is one-pointed. When it is scattered, distraction and restlessness\nsets in. This restlessness can be curbed, but nothing which exists can be\ndestroyed; it can only be transformed, made to disappear or fade by thoughtful\nattention, enabling the stream of conscious restfulness to flow unwaveringly.\nIn this manner, consciousness is influenced by its own action. It forms the\nhabit of absorbing in a single thought, which prepares one for spiritual\nabsorption. This type of attention, samadhi parinama, stabilises the state of\nrestfulness.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In nirodha parinama,\nthe issuing of thought-waves is restrained and quietened. In samadhi parinama,\nthe intervals between the emergence and the restraint of thoughts and vice\nversa are studied. From this study issues a stillness which leads to silence.\nOne should know that stillness is rigidity and silence is passive and meditative.\nIn the state of silence, the fragrance of the soul emerges as the centre of\nattention. This is ekagrata paririama.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The mind alternates\nbetween the possibility of intense concentration and a state where alternative\nobjects can attract attention.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The mastery called\nsamadhi-parinamah is the transition whereby the tendency to all-pointedness\nsubsides, while the tendency to one-pointedness arises.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The state of\nall-pointedness refers to the tendency of the mind to be drawn in countless\ndifferent directions. In the state of samadhi-parinamah being described, this\ntendency towards all-pointedness subsides. It does not mean that those\ncountless objects themselves go away, as they are not destroyed. What it does\nmean is that the inclination of the mind towards this stance of all-pointedness\nsubsides. In other words, it is only one thing that is subsiding, and that is\nthe tendency towards the endless diversity presented to the mind.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The state of one-pointedness refers to the\ntendency of the mind to concentrate or focus on a single point. If you observe\nyour own mental functioning, you can easily see both tendencies. The mind tends\nboth to the diversity of all-pointedness, as well as to one -pointedness. We\nall experience both of these tendencies in daily life. Here in this sutra, it\nis this one-pointedness that is arising.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Here, in the high state of samadhi-parinamah,\nthere is witnessing of this transition into samadhi, whereby the\nall-pointedness subsides, and the one-pointedness arises.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is innate nature of\nthe mind to be attentive to all the things at the same time. One-pointedness is\nalso the nature of the same mind. This is the anatomy of the mind. The mind has\nto be trained and tamed. This weakening of distractive nature of the mind is the\nsadhana. Strengthening of the force of one pointedness is a prerogative of\nsadhana. This taming is a skilful art and should never be forceful and sudden.\nIt has to be gradual. This journey from many-pointedness to one-pointedness is\nthe crux of mental transformation. The process has to be handled very\ndelicately and effortlessly. That is the real mastery over the mind.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">We are aware of many\nthings, since awareness from one thought/object shifts to another\nthought/object. But at a single given moment and time the awareness is of only\none thought/object. But the shifting is so fast that it appears that the mind\nis unbridled and disperse. This fastness has to be replaced with slowness and\ngradually let not the awareness shift from the single object. Finally, the\ninnate unmanifested quality to shift will be eliminated. This subtle\ntransformation is termed as Samadhi Parinama. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nirodha Parinama is the awareness of the\ninterval between two thoughts and Samadhi Parinama is the awareness of the\nquietitude. Cultivating one-pointedness infers holding the mind on a single\nobject and vise versa.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are various types\nof transformations, such as nirodha parinama, samadhi parinama, ekagrata\nparinama, dharma parinama, lakshana parinama and avastha parinama. These are\nthe terms used by Patanjali to indicate the types or kinds of transformation\nwhich the mind passes through in its processes of concentration, meditation and\nsamadhi \u2013 which is samyama.</span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">3.12 --- tatah punah\nshantoditau tulyapratyayau chittasyaikagrataparinamah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">When rising and falling\nthought processes are in balance, one-pointed consciousness comes forth.&nbsp;</span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Maintenance of awarenesss with keen intensity from one-pointed attention to\nno-pointed attentiveness is ekagrata parinama.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even in this focus on\nthe property of citta alone, the sensitivity of attention may be intense or\nlight. To preserve a steady, uninterrupted flow and intensity of attention in\ncitta is the third phase of transformation.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Occasionally,\nconsciousness is thoughtfully silent, but then it suddenly spirts out into\nvivacious activity. In a split second, this activity may be controlled and\nbalance regained. This control needs effort, and effort calls for time. By\nskillful practice, the depth of silence, which at first appears only in fleets,\nis made to interpenetrate and fill the entire citta. Then the feeling of time\ndisappears. Past and future are reabsorbed into the timeless. M</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">ind and time are\ninterdependent. As the moments of the mind come to an end, so does time. Citta\nand the seer (atman) are the two sharp edges of a blade. In one-pointed\nattention (ekagrata samskara) the energies of the seeker and the seer become\none.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the state of\nrestraint is reached (nirodha samskara), glimpses of silence are nurtured and\nfill the consciousness (samadhi samskara). Then the third phase of ekagrata\nsamskara should be practised. Here, the consciousness which was dependent on\nexternal objects moves inwards to infuse the seedless seat of the soul.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In. 3/9-12 Patanjali\nexplains the three levels of transformation of consciousness in sequential\norder - nirodha, samadhi and finally ekagrata. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ekagrata, as explained earlier, has two\nmeanings. One is concentration on a given object - at this external level it\nbears the same meaning as dharana. The other is 'one without a second' - i.e.,\nthe soul. This level of transformation of consciousness is the highest.\nPatanjali thus states his meaning as - ekagrata parinama is the final phase of\nthe transformation in which consciousness is uplifted to the level of the soul,\nand is one with it.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The mastery called\nekagrata-parinamah is the transition whereby the same one-pointedness arises\nand subsides sequentially.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rising and subsiding of\nthe same one-pointedness: In the last sutra, it was described that\nall-pointedness subsided and one-pointedness arose. Now, in this sutra, the\nsubject is where that one-pointedness subsides, only to arise again. The\nmany-pointedness is not there, only the cycling and recycling of the\none-pointedness. It is this transition that is being witnessed.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Three transitions:\nThus, we are referring to three forms of transition in sutras 3.9-3.12. The\nfirst one related to the transition of the mastery of thought patterns itself.\nThe second related to the transitioning rise of one-pointedness of mind, along\nwith the subsiding of the many-pointedness. The third (in the current sutra)\nrelates to the transition of the repeated rising and subsiding of the same\none-pointedness.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mastery over\ntransitions: Once again, this witnessing and mastery over transitions themselves\ngives mastery over the underlying thought patterns and processes themselves. In\nother words, master the transitions, and you master the thought process; master\nthe thought process, and you can go beyond, ultimately to experience the center\nof consciousness .</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the subsiding past\nand rising present images are identical, there is ekagrata parinama\n(one-pointedness).&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The mind becomes\none-pointed when similar thought-waves arise in succession without any gaps\nbetween them.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The mind reaches a\nstage where the link with the object is consistent and continuous. The\ndistractions cease to appear.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The mastery called ekagrata-parinamah\nis the transition whereby the same one-pointedness arises and subsides\nsequentially.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The various likes and\ndislikes in the mind are vrittis.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is the urge that is\nfelt inside the mind itself which propels it towards something outside, whether\nit is a physical object or a conceptual notion. This urge within is an\nimpediment.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">An ekagrata vritti is not normally present in the\nmind. It has to be brought about; it has to be introduced by effort. This is\nsamyama; this is, precisely, yoga. The ekagrata vritti is the healthful\ntendency of the mind, the power with which it keeps the organism of the mind\nintact and prevents any kind of depletion of energy. The integrating force,\nwhich is the ekagrata vritti, will not allow the leaking out of mental energy\nin respect of objects outside. It blocks all the passages of sense and the\ntendency of the mind. But these tendencies are also powerful enough, so they\ntry to break through the fortress which has been built by the ekagrata vritti,\nand then, somehow or other, try to get out, just as prisoners can run out of\nthe jail in spite of the great guard that is kept around them.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ekagrata&nbsp; &nbsp;is\nintent pursuit of one object, close and undisturbed attention.Yoga emphasises\nregular practice (Abhyasa) meditation and self-imposed discipline to acquire\nekagrata.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dharana converges on a particular concept or object.\nIn the state of ekagrata there is clarity and right direction: yoga begins with\nekagrata and culminates in nirodha, a consciousness free of movement. Dharana\ngives the ability to see one\u2019s own mind, one starts looking inwards deeply. If\nekagrata is lost the full power of intention to achieve goals to be achieved is\nlost. Intentions afflicted by doubts, fears and reactive thoughts break and\ndiffuse the energy of intentions.The mind which is the cause of Sankalpa\n('notion')-Vikalpa ('alternative') must be controlled, it must be bound.\nEkagrata assists in keeping one\u2019s own mind bound and still.</span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">3.13 --- etena\nbhootendriyeshu dharmalakshanavastha parinama vyakhyatah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Through these three\nphases, cultured consciousness is transformed from its potential state (dharma)\ntowards further refinement (laksana) and the pinnacle of refinement (avastha).\nIn this way, the transformation of elements, senses and mind takes place. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The three stages of\ntransformation elucidated in III.9-12 affect the entire being - organs, senses,\nbody and mind, and bring about a stable, sound state of consciousness.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Both purusa and prakrti\nare eternal. Purusa remains perpetually changeless. Prakrti goes on ceaselessly\nchanging, due to the interaction between its own gunas of sattva, rajas and\ntamas.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Earth, water, fire, air\nand ether; their counterparts smell, taste, sight, touch and sound; the senses\nof perception and organs of action; mind, intelligence, consciousness and ego\nare all parts of nature. Ego, consciousness and intelligence are sensitive and\nelusive. They pile up experiences of objects perceived through the senses of\nperception, organs of action and mind. These experiences differ according to\ntheir relation to circumstances. In this way, consciousness is throttled by the\nqualities of nature. It is also linked with time, because it fluctuates with thoughts\nof past, present and future.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">By disciplined study\nand effort, experiences are observed to move qualitatively towards the best.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Through study one\nrealises that consciousness has four dispositions or attributes. The first,\nwhen avidya is predominant, is its wandering nature - vyutthana samskara. The\ndawning power of discrimination leads to the second tendency - restraint,\nnirodha samskara, dharma pannama. The effect of restraint is the flow of\ntranquillity (prasanta vahita samskara), experienced between vyutthana and\nnirodha samskaras. This gives rise to the third tendency - laksana parinama.\nThe effort to lengthen this silent intermission brings the sadhaka to the\npinnacle of emancipation (avastha pannama) - the fourth or final attribute of\nconsciousness.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When consciousness\nloses all these tendencies and becomes contemplative, it rests in the seer.\nThis affects the behavioural patterns in the body, senses and mind, which also\nremain peaceful. Consciousness becomes pensive. This wholly peaceful state is\nekagrata parinama. &nbsp;By thoughtful action, consciousness traces the source of its\nattributes, moves towards it, and is dissolves in that. At that moment, body,\nsenses and mind are devoid of evolution and dissolution, of birth and death.\nThis is viveka khyati. The sadhaka transforms himself to an exhilarated state\n(dharma parinama), develops awareness of perfection (laksana parinama) and\nmaintains himself, without losing the acquired perfection (avastha parinama).&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dharma parinama is the\nknowledge of prakrti and purusa; laksana parinama is the way one makes use of\nthem; and avastha parinama is steadily maintaining them, once they have been\npurified of trial and error, in the established state. In this process the\nelements, organs of action, senses of perception and mind are transformed;\npurusa is recognised and understood. All these transformations are stabilised,\nand the changing states in body, mind and ego come to a conclusion, enabling\nthe sadhaka to rest in the eternal undying purusa. The search terminates and\ndichotomy between the seeker and the sought ends as the seer realises that he\nalone was the seeker, seeking his own form - svarupa. From now on, he drinks\nthe nectar of his own self-generating pure fragrance.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">These three phases of\nconscious transformation culminate in tranquillity. Awareness flows peacefully,\nand virtue arises as dharma parinama. This is the true character of\nintelligence and consciousness. Now, the sadhaka is highly sophisticated and\ncivilized. This is laksana parinama. Maintaining this qualitative state of\nconscious progression towards the pinnacle is avastha parinama.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Through these three\nphases, cultured consciousness is transformed from its potential state (dharma)\ntowards further refinement (laksana) and the zenith of refinement (avastha). In\nthis way, the transformation of elements, senses an mind takes place.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In this state, it\npasses beyond the three kinds of changes which take place in subtle or gross\nmatter, and in the organs: change of form, change of time and change of\ncondition.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">As it has been\nestablished that the mind has different states [corresponding to which there\narose different attitudes, possibilities, and behavior patterns in the\nindividual] it can also be said that such changes can occur in all the objects\nof perception and in the senses. These changes can be at different levels and\ninfluenced by external forces such as time or our intelligence.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Parinama is a Sanskrit\nterm describing transformation or change, on both a philosophical and practical\nlevel. Patanjali outlined six kinds of parinama: nirodha parinama (the\nsuppression of the vrittis), samadhi parinama (development of samadhi),\nekagrata parinama (one-pointed transformation), dharma parinama (transformation\nof appearance), lakshana (transformation of character) and avastha parinama\n(transformation of condition).&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Both Samkhya and yoga\nschools of Hinduism believe that everything is a projection of something that\nhas already been present or hidden. That is also why these schools of thought\nbelieve that the world has materialized out of the world that existed in a\nhidden way before. This is called the \"Parinama Vada,\" the\ntransformation theory.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">With reference to the\nAntahkarana, the Dharma that operates at the present moment is Dharma Parinama.\nWith reference to what has passed and to that which is yet to come, it is\nLakshana Parinama. If the present Dharma increases or decreases, it is Avastha\nParinama. Thus the three kinds of Parinama occur in the Bhutas and Indriyas\nalso. The mind assumes various forms. This is one kind of Parinama with\nreference to form. When the change becomes manifest in relation to some time,\npast, present or future, it is called Lakshana Parinama. When after this the\nparticular property ripens into maturity or decay, it is called Avastha\nParinama. The mind passes into various states. It is also Avastha Parinama.</span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">3.14 ---</span> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">shantoditavyapadeshyadharmanupati\ndharmi</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The substratum is that\nwhich continues to exist and maintain its characteristic quality in all states,\nwhether manifest, latent, or subdued. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The integral\ncharacteristic quality of nature (mula-prakrti) has three properties - pacified\nor calmed (santa), manifested (udita) or latent (avyapadesa). They appear\nindistinctly or clearly, according to one's intellectual development.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The substratum of\nnature remains the same for all time, though transformations take place. The\nmoulding of consciousness takes place owing to the changes in the gunas of\nnature.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Patanjali explains the\nthree phases of consciousness as rising, being restrained and the pauses\nbetween the two. In III.10, he describes these pauses as tranquil\nconsciousness. If these pauses are prolonged, all pointedness and\none-pointedness meet, and there is no room for rising or subsiding of thoughts\nSutra 12 explains that maintaining these quiet moments gives rise to a balanced\nstate of consciousness, which is described in III. 13 as a cultured and\nharmonious state. Rising and restraining thoughts are the inclinations (dharma)\nof the citta, and the tranquil state is its characteristic quality (dharmi).&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The rising citta is\nfelt in the sensory body. Citta then appears at the external level as bahirahga\ncitta. Watching the movement of rising thoughts is an external or bahirahga\nsadhana. The delicate restraint of rising thoughts moves citta inwards from the\nperipheral body - this is inner or antarahga sadhana. Stabilising the tranquillity\nthat takes place in the intervals is innermost or antaratma sadhana - that\nstate is considered to be an auspicious moment of consciousness. It is like\nre-discovering the dust, which existed before the pot.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Consciousness has three\nphases - external, internal and innermost. As one traces and retraces these,\ntheir relevance can be noticed to an individual's practices of asana, pranayama\nand meditation, in which consciousness moves from the skin inwards, and each\ncell and fibre is infused with the tranquillity of the seer.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Today, everyone is\naware of constant 'stress and strain' in life. These aspects of consciousness\nwhich confuses life are by no means new to mankind. Patanjali's word vyutthana,\nused to designate the 'emergence of rising thought', is equivalent to the appearance\nof 'stress'. Nirodha, 'restraint of rising thought' is equivalent to the\n'strain' of trying to control that stress. Striking the balance between the two\nis called 'relaxation' (santi citta). Restraining of rising thought is against\nthe current (pratipaksa). Hence restraint is strain.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">A person who has\nundergone childhood is santa, because that childhood stage has passed and is\nover. As one stands at the threshold of youth, he is in the present or udita\nstate. In course of time, one moves towards old age, which is yet to come -\nthis is avyapadesya, old age which is still in an unmanifested form and\nindistinct. But the person remains the same through all these changes. That\nunchanging person is dharmi. Likewise, milk is the property which separates into\ncurds and whey, or changes into butter. It is the same with dust, which is\nformed into clay to make a jar. The dust stands for the past, the clay for the\npresent, the jar for the future. Thus every change from the source move in time\nas past, present and future.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In II.18, the\nproperties of nature are explained as luminosity (prakasa), vibrancy (kriya)\nand inertia (sthithi). By the use of these qualities, one may be entangled in a\nmixture of pleasure and pain, or go beyond them to unalloyed bliss.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The properties of\nnature exist for the purpose of one's evolution and involution. Consciousness,\nbeing a part of nature, is bound by the spokes of the wheel of time.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">If an aspirer sows the\nright seed through knowledge and discrimination (viveka) and develops consciousness,\nhe reaps the fruit of self-realisation through ekagrata. He becomes the force\nwhich severalises between the hidden properties and the transformations of\nnature. He recognises his true, pure state of existence which is changeless and\nvirtuous. This is the fruit earned through the astute effort of sadhana.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The import of this\nsutra can be used to practical advantage while practising asana, pranayama or\nmeditation. If one observes the various scattered cells dust lying latent in\nthe body, and charge them so that they adhere (lump of clay), one can feel the\ninner unity and transform body, breath and consciousness into designs in the\nform of different asanas and pranayamas, as the potter moulds his clay into a\nvariety of shapes.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In asana, if the energy\nof the body is reconciled to a 'point zero', while in a state of tension, one\naccomplishes exactness. The same can be applied to the intake of breath, its\ndistribution or discharge in pranayama, and in meditation. The combining of\nsingle-pointed attention with all-pointed attention at the core of one's being\nis the essence of this sutra.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">'Point zero' designates\nthe point of balance and harmony at which one can unlock and liberate the\nproblematic confusion of matter and emotion. It also expresses the importance\nof finding the exact centre of the meeting points of vertical extension and\nhorizontal expansion in body, breath and consciousness.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is the substratum\n(Prakriti) that by nature goes through latent, uprising and unmanifested\nphases.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The substrata is that\nwhich continues to exist and maintain its characteristic quality in all states,\nwhether manifest, latent, or subdued.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">A compound object has\nattributes and is subject to change, either past, present or yet to be\nmanifested.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A substance contains\nall its characteristics and, depending on the particular form it takes, those\ncharacteristics conforming to that form will be apparent. But whatever the\nform, whatever the characteristics exhibited, there exists a base that\ncomprises all characteristics. Some have appeared in the past, some are\ncurrently apparent, and others may reveal themselves in the future.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is an unmanifest,\nindescribable substratum or existence that is common or contained within all of\nthe other forms or qualities.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is an unmanifest,\nindescribable substratum or existence that is common or contained within all of\nthe other forms or qualities.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Find the substratum:\nThe point of witnessing all of those subtle processes is to find that\nsubstratum, the object underneath, that is common to all, is continuously\nexistent within them all, and unchanging in any of them. This is a further\nrefinement of the process described throughout Yoga of witnessing and setting\naside that which is not the eternal, indivisible reality of our true nature\nthat we are seeking. After everything else is eliminated, we experience the\ntrue Self .</span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">3.15 --- kramanyatvan\nparinamanyatve hetuh</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Successive sequential\nchanges bring about the distinctive changes in the consciousness. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Differences in changes\nin consciousness are caused by the changing order of sequences in the method of\npractice. According to the sequence of practice, distinct transformations take\nplace. The earthenware pot instance and look at the clay dust as the first\nprinciple of evolution, will help one understand the property (dharma)\ncontained in it, the lump of pliable clay which embodies the qualitative mark\n(laksana), and the jar which culminates the process and which represents the\nevolved state (avastha). Only by following a certain sequence of actions can\none turn earth into pottery. This is harmonious and organic growth. In yogic\npractice a regular sequence must also be followed. The sadkaka first acquires\nrestraint in consciousness (nirodha parinama) in order to experience\ntranquillity (samadhi parinama). Then he proceeds towards the 'one without a\nsecond', the seer (ekagrata parinama). Only then does he become a fulfilled\nyogi (krtarthan). Though consciousness may be considered partially to exist\noutside time, the work needed to transform that consciousness definitely exists\ninside the framework of time. It may well be that there is an evolutionary\n'tilt' to the cosmos by which all things incline to evolve for the better in\nthe long run. But one cannot count on that, and so some amount of individual\neffort is necessary, especially as the world itself, the only known theatre of\naction for this evolutionary drama, is now in danger from man's excesses of\npollution, greed and war. Such was not the case in Patanjali's times, yet he\nsaw fit to furnish the future with an exact evolutionary map, so that one's\nadvance might be orderly and expeditious. There is a logic to the involutionary\nspiritual journey, just as there is in the growth of a plant from seed, to\nstem, to bud, to flower, to fruit. The original, pure consciousness which one\ntraces through Patanjali's method is the seed of transformation in oneself. &nbsp;One's own self is the maker of one's own\nspiritual destiny. The importance of structure and sequence can be shown in the\ninstance of language-learning.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">If one starts out to\nlearn a language without structured tuition, one may or may not learn it. It is\na 'hit or miss' process. But if one seeks to learn in a structured way, there\nis a definite order of procedure. One starts with the present tense of the verbs\n'to be' and 'to have' and certain basic nouns and prepositions. To start with\ncomplex grammatical forms would be idiotic and self-defeating. The structure of\nevolution and progress in all things has its own inner logic and harmony. This\nis sequence, or krama. Change in the sequence of the characteristics is the\ncause for the different appearances of results, consequences, or effects. There\nis a natural flow or transformation in all levels of nature, whether in gross\nor subtle planes of reality. These transitions are the foundations of the\nprinciple of cause yielding effect. Some of these are known at the surface\nlevel by all of us. The subtler transitions are known to the Yogis. One of the\nfoundation principles of Yoga is non-attachment . </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is a process that evolves in stages, and\nthat here, in this section we are talking about extremely subtle processes.\nThough the processes are subtle, the principles are the same. You witness,\nnotice an underlying reality, and let go of the more surface attachment. A\nparticular form comes from the sequence of states: Imagine that you are able to\nmeditate so quietly that you recognize that all of the objects of your\nattachment were simply a result of a change of sequence in states. For example,\nclay turns into pot (while remaining clay), and then, eventually turns back\ninto clay. So it is with all of the objects, whether objects in the external\nworld, or object in the mind. It is all a matter of changing form, or the\nsequence in which those forms are seen. Gradually, the unchanging truth is\nrevealed, underneath all of the apparent change in successions of\ntransformations of that uniform oneness. By changing the order or sequence of\nchange, characteristics that are of one pattern can be modified to a different\npattern.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Change in the sequence of the\ncharacteristics is the cause for the different appearances of results,\nconsequences, or effects.</span><br />\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c4536017635967534947\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_141M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2017/12/the-rotating-statue-on-nemi-ship-on.html?showComment=1514505087379#c4536017635967534947\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">December 29, 2017 at 5:21 AM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_141MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\n<br />\nRoshan Raghunathan<br />\nDecember 29, 2017 at 12:18 AM<br />\n<br />\nHello Captain, your post on amavasya ekaadasi and fasting vi a vis the lunar cycles is very informative indeed. is there any reason that north indian labourers - marwadis specially ive noticed - dont do any work on amavasya or is that just a superstition? id be glad if you clarified this. The moon appears full when the Earth is between the moon and the sun. In both cases, the gravitational pull of the sun is \"added\" to the gravitational pull of the moon on Earth, causing the oceans to bulge a bit more than usual. This means that high tides are a little higher and low tides are a little lower than average.<br />\n<br />\nSpring tides, has nothing to do with the season of spring. Rather, the term is derived from the concept of the tide \"springing forth.\" ..<br />\n<br />\nSpring tides occur twice each lunar month all year long, without regard to the season\u2026.<br />\n<br />\nhttp://tides.mobilegeographics.com/calendar/month/547.html<br />\n<br />\nIN THE LINK ABOVE YOU CAN SEE THAT FULL MOON IS ON 3RD DEC 2017..<br />\n<br />\nTHREE DAYS LATER THE DATE IS 6TH DEC..<br />\n<br />\nTHE HIGH TIDE ( SPRING ) IS 12.5 METRES --THE HIGHEST..<br />\n<br />\nJEW ROTHSCHILD TOOK AWAY INDIANS TO WORK AS INDENTURED LABOUR.. text-decoration-line: none;\">December 29, 2017 at 5:32 AM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_139MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nIt is better NOT to use energy for digestion during this particular 24 hours\u2026The high energy of the full moon gives the body a chance to do deep cleansing\u2026<br />\n<br />\nDuring the Amavasya / Poornima there are many more negative ions in the atmosphere, which is good for neutralizing free radicals \u2026 Body cells get a deep cleanse..<br />\n<br />\nAt my home i have a water fall for NEGATIVE IONS..<br />\n<br />\nThe Nemi lake is a VOLCANIC CRATER and it produces humongous negative ions..<br />\n<br />\nThe 4 electrolytes \u2013 sodium, potassium, calcium and magnesium \u2013 form a kind of dance over 24 hrs called the day-night shift. ..Magnesium and potassium live normally within the cell, and sodium and calcium are found outside. ..<br />\n<br />\nDuring the day sodium invades the cell, taking a hydrogen ion with it, which is acidifying\u2026 In order to buffer this acidity, which is toxic to the cell, calcium also moves in. ..This has the effect of displacing potassium and magnesium which is shoved out of the cell\u2026<br />\n<br />\nAt night due to the effect of the moon, the opposite takes place and potassium and magnesium move back into the cell, pushing out the calcium and sodium, which takes the hydrogen ion with it\u2026<br />\n<br />\nWHEN I TRIED TO WRITE A KARVA CHAUTH POST ON THIS CHUTNEY MARYs ATTACKED ME\u2026<br />\n<br />\nhttp://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2013/10/karva-chauth-synchronising-fertility.html<br />\n<br />\nTHE POST ABOVE IS THE SECOND HIGHEST READ ARTICLE ON THIS PLANET TODAY--THE FIRST BEING SURYA NAMASSKAR --96% BY FOREIGNERS..<br />\n<br />\nThis has the effect of cleansing the cell, so you should wake up bright and refreshed. When the body is not cleansing properly, this process is impaired and instead you wake up tired and lethargic . There is a higher sodium content in the cell, therefore a higher hydrogen (acidifying) content, and as water follows sodium in the body, the water content of the cell starts to swell. ..<br />\n<br />\nSo the cell is under pressure from high acidity \u2013 so it pulls in more calcium, which displaces more magnesium causing an imbalance\u2026<br />\n<br />\nThe moon-pull is much gentler than the sun-push. Only if conditions are right within the body can the moon pull the sodium back across the cell membrane, thus making way for the Magnesium to exert a gentle push with the potassium, so that they go back to their rightful position, which is inside the cell\u2026<br />\n<br />\nWhat is lymph? Ayurveda knew it 6000 years ago, while modern science knew about it just 60 years back\u2026<br />\n<br />\nhttp://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2012/08/yoga-and-ayurvedic-massage-for-draining.html<br />\n<br />\nhttp://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/01/lymph-nodes-vs-endocrine-exocrine.html<br />\n<br />\n6200 YEAR OLD Ayurveda was the first to write about AUTOPHAGY.. literally SELF EATING -- it\u2019s the body\u2019s system of cleaning house: Your cells create membranes that hunt out scraps of dead, diseased, or worn-out cells; gobble them up; strip them for parts; and use the resulting molecules for energy or to make new cell parts.<br />\n<br />\nAutophagy makes us more efficient machines to get rid of faulty parts, stop cancerous growths, and stop metabolic dysfunction like obesity and diabetes.. the process plays a hand in controlling inflammation and immunity.<br />\n<br />\nTHE MOST IMPORTANT EFFECT IS THAT THE BRAIN GETS SHARPENED AND THE AGEING PROCESS SLOWS DOWN<br />\n<br />\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=10jNZleNH9w<br />\n<br />\nFROM NOW ON HINDUS WILL CREATE THEIR OWN DESTINY--WE DONT CARE FOR THE WHITE MEN WHO FOOLED US USING AGENTS LIKE GANDHI AND BR AMBEDKAR\u2026<br />\n<br />\nCapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n<span class=\"comment-actions secondary-text\" id=\"bc_0_139MN\" kind=\"m\"></span></div>\n</li>\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_139B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 16px; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; In April 2012, the United States\nannounced a bounty of $10 million on Hafiz Saeed, for his alleged role in the\n2008 Mumbai terror attacks in which 6 American citizens were killed among\nhundreds of other victims, but there have been protests in Pakistan against the\nUS bounty.[5] [6] [7].&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">India considers him one\nof its most wanted terrorists because of his alleged ties with Lashkar-e-Taiba\nand his involvement in attacks against India such as the 2008 Mumbai terror\nattacks, therefore Saeed is listed on the NIA Most Wanted list and India has\nbanned his organisation as a terrorist organisation.[8] The United States,[9]\nthe United Kingdom,[10] the European Union,[11] Russia[12] and Australia have\nalso banned LET.[13] [14]&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Criticizing his\nanti-India comments, Indian Muslim leader Asaduddin Owaisi said, \"People\nlike Hafiz Saeed are unaware about teachings of Islam, jihad in Islam. They are\nkilling innocent lives in Pakistan, children are being killed. They are using\nPakistan for maligning another country. She works as a\nconsulting editor with NDTV.[2] Dutt gained prominence for her reportage of the\nKargil War.[3] Dutt has won many national and international awards, including\nthe Padma Shri, India's fourth highest civilian honour.[4] Dutt was one of the\njournalists taped in the Radia tapes controversy.[5]</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dutt\nwas criticised for her coverage of 2008 Mumbai attacks, during which she\nreported from Taj Mahal Hotel and Oberoi Trident.[15] She was blamed for\nsensationalising the events, putting lives at risk and causing deaths by identifying\non live television where the hotel guests might be located.[15] Writing for the\nNew York Times, Lydia Polgreen wrote that critics viewed Dutt and some other\nreporters as extremely \"theatrical and melodramatic\" in their\ncoverage of the 2008 attacks.[16] A blogger, Chaitanya Kunte, who had\ncriticized Barkha Dutt's reporting was served legal notice by her,[17][18] and\ncoerced to take down his blog.[17]In a 2012 interview with Madhu Trehan, Dutt\ndefended herself against Kunte's criticism and of others who questioned her\ncoverage of the 2008 Mumbai siege, and accepted that she did send a legal\nnotice to Kunte.[19]</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In November 2010, the magazines OPEN and\nOutlook published transcripts of some telephone conversations between Nira\nRadia with some senior journalists, politicians, and corporates.[12][20] The\nCentral Bureau of Investigation announced that they had 5,851 recordings of\nphone conversations by Radia, some of which outline Radia's attempts to broker\ndeals in relation to the 2G spectrum sale.[21] Barkha Dutt's conversations with\nRadia were reported and Dutt became the face of the tapes scandal.[16 Magazine\neditor Hartosh Singh Bal said that Barkha Dutt's role in the Radia Tapes\nexposed the \"institutional malaise\" of the organization of which she\nwas a part\u2013 \"proximity of NDTV and Tehelka are concerned, their closeness\nto the Congress is no secret. font-size: 14px; line-height: 1.38; overflow: hidden;\">\n<div style=\"display: inline;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white;\">Times Now calls for gagging of media &amp; for journalists to be tried &amp;punished. This man is journalist?I am ashamed to be from same industry as him. What's striking is his brazen and cowardly hypocrisy. So he drones on and on about Pro Pakistan Doves without one word on the JK alliance agreement that commits the BJP and PDP to talks with Pakistan and Hurriyat and is silent on Modi's own Pakistan outreach- neither of which I object to- but since Arnab Goswami measures patriotism by such views why is he so silent on the government? Chamchagiri? Imagine, a journalist actually exhorts the government to shut down sections of the media, misrepresents them as isi agents and terror sympathisers, calls for them to be tried and acted against. And our fraternity remains locked into politically correct and timid silence. Well Im not a</span><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"> shrinking violet </span><span style=\"background-color: white;\">Mr. Goswami and no matter how many times you take my name directly or indirectly on your show, I really dont give a toss for your opinion. I hope I will always be someone whose journalism you loathe, because trust me, the feeling is so utterly mutual that it would kill me to be on the same side of any issue as you.</span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\">FADING VIOLET ? text-align: center;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During the &nbsp;2014, Lok Sabha elections , Narendra Modi came\nout of the polling booth after voting , and then he walked away to a distance\nand took a selfie showing his inked finger with a tiny lotus symbol in view.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Immediately the Italian\nwaitress made a hue and cry , stating that the poll code was violated.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The election commission\nordered an FIR with the Ahmedabad crime branch.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The EC said that \u201cfrom\nthe substance, tone and tenor of the address\u201d and the \u201cmanner in which the\nsymbol, lotus, of the BJP was being displayed by him\u2026 thereby displaying to the\npublic election matter by means of television in areas going to polls today\u201d,\nit is \u201cevident\u201d that it \u201cwas in the nature of political speech intended and\ncalculated to influence and affect the result of elections in the\nconstituencies going to polls today, not only in Ahmedabad but also in all\nother constituencies in Gujarat and elsewhere in the country. Modi has violated\nthe provisions of Sections 126 (1) (a) and 126 (l) (b) of the Representation of\nthe People Act, 1951. If any restrictions have been imposed by the competent\nauthority in Ahmedabad under Section 144 of CrPC, then complaints/ FlR should\nalso be made under Section 188 of IPC\u201d. BLAH BLAH.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The EC also directed\nthat separate complaints/ FIRs should be filed against all the TV channels and\nother electronic media which carried the proceedings/ images of the meeting and\ndisplay of election matter.&nbsp;<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"> EC warned\nthat Supreme Court had ruled that an MP would be immediately disqualified if\nconvicted by a court for a criminal offence with a jail sentence of two years\nor more. If convicted, Modi\u2019s status as a Gujarat MLA or a Lok Sabha MP (if\nelected) could be in jeopardy.</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-ZcRWW8vKrmg/V6KkdbucFnI/AAAAAAABLRo/qWYHkGHVFE42vFVnIYOna1ezOJrepFE9wCLcB/s1600/iydjedmages.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"226\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-ZcRWW8vKrmg/V6KkdbucFnI/AAAAAAABLRo/qWYHkGHVFE42vFVnIYOna1ezOJrepFE9wCLcB/s400/iydjedmages.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">At that time I told my\nwife who was watching TV with me\u2014\u201c Prannoy Roy will give an award to the\nelection commission soon !. I have not reached this far in life by being a\nchoot !!\u201c<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Then an hour later when\nI was sitting in the lawn , I heard my wife exclaim OH SHIT !<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">She came running\noutside and &nbsp;cried \u2013what you said have\nbecome true. NDTV will be giving the entire election commission INDIAN OF THE\nYEAR AWARD.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both;
