, &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">CHAPTER IV--&nbsp; KAIVALYA PADA --&nbsp; LIBERATION<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">janmaushadhimantratapahsamadhijah\nsiddhayah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">jatyantaraparinamah\nprakrityapoorat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">nimittam aprayojakan\nprakritinan varannabhedastutatah kshetrikavat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">nirmannachittanyasmitamatrat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">pravrittibhede\nprayojakam chittam ekam anekesham<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tatra dhyanajam\nanashayam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">karmashuklakrishnnam\nyoginah trividham itaresham<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tatastadvipakanugunanam\nevabhivyaktirvasananam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">jatideshakalavyavahitanam\napyanantaryamsmritisanskarayoh ekaroopatvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tasam anaditvam\nchashisho nityatvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">hetufalashrayalambanaih\nsangrihitatvad eshamabhave tadabhavah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">atitanagatan\nsvaroopatostyadhvabhedad<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">te vyaktasookshma\ngunatmanah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">parinamaikatvad vastutattvam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">vastusamye chittabhedat\ntayorvibhaktah panthah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">taduparagapekshatvat\nchittasya vastu jnatajnatam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">sada\njnatashchittavrittayastatprabhohpurushasyaparinamitvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">na tat\nsvabhasandrishyatvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">ekasamaye\nchobhayanavadharannam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">chittantaradrishye\nbuddhibuddheratiprasanggah smritisankarashcha<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">chiterapratisankramayastadakarapattausvabuddhisanvedanam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">drashtridrishyoparaktan\nchittan sarvartham<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tadasankhyeyavasanachitram\napi pararthan sanhatyakaritvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">visheshadarshin\naatmabhavabhavanavinivrittih<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tada vivekanimnan kaivalyapragbharan\nchittam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tachchhidreshu\npratyayantarani sanskarebhyah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">hanam esham\nkleshavaduktam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">prasankhyanepyakusidasy\nsarvathavivekakhyaterdharmameghah samadhih<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tatah\nkleshakarmanivrittih<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tada\nsarvavarannamalapetasyjnanasyaanantyajgyeyam alpam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tatah kritarthanan\nparinamakramapari samaptirgunanam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">kshannapratiyogi\nparinamaparantanigrarhyah kramah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">purusharthashoonyanan\ngunanan pratiprasavahkaivalyan, svaroopapratishtha va chitishaktireti<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">3.02 - - - tatra\npratyayaikatanata dhyanam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">A balanced, continuous\nflow of attention directed towards the same point or region is meditation\n(dhyana).&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></i></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The distinguishable\nfeature of meditation (dhyana) is the sustenance of a continual flow of\nattention on a fixed point or region, without interference or interruption. In\ndhyana, psychological and chronological time come to a standstill as the mind\nobserves its own behaviour. The strength of attention in the field of\nconsciousness neither alters nor vacillates, remaining as stable, smooth and\nconstant as oil being poured from a jug. Upholding the same strength of\nawareness, the attentive awareness moves from one-pointed concentration to\nno-pointed attentiveness. The dissimilarity between dharana and dhyana is that\ndharana is more concerned with the elimination of fluctuating thought-waves in\norder to achieve single-pointed concentration; in dhyana, the emphasis is on\nthe maintenance of steady and profound contemplative observation. Ekatanata\nconnotes an unbroken flow of contact between the sadhaka's consciousness and\nhis sadhana. It can thus be seen that dhyana may be achieved in both asana and\npranayama. In asana, there is a centrifugal movement of consciousness to the\nfrontiers of the body, whether stretched vertically, horizontally or\ncircumferentially, and a centripetal movement as the whole body is brought into\nsingle focus. If attention is steadily maintained in this manner, meditation\ntakes place. Likewise, in pranayama, the flow of in- or out- breath is\nconsiderately measured and sustained, resulting in complete involvement with\nthe self. During retention, when the breath, cells of the torso, consciousness\nand soul are brought into unison, meditation happens. In short, when attention,\nreflection and contemplation in action and observation are steadily sustained,\ndharana evolves into dhyana.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The key term in this\nverse is pratayaya. Pratayaya,&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">is an\nauxiliary cause, as distinguished from a direct cause (hetu). A seed, for\nexample, is a direct cause of a plant, while sunshine, water, and earth are\nauxiliary causes of a plant. Mind is an inseparable part of the human being. It\nis distinct from brain, nervous system; it is distinct from all other physical\norgans, it is distinct from Pranic Force behind body activities. The mind is\ndistinct from all these systems but at the same time, it is closely associated\nwith all these systems of the body. Mind is very difficult to access directly\nbut all these systems are relatively easier to access. So mind can be accessed\nthrough these systems.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">People have not been\nclear about dharana and dhyana. Both are not the same. Dharana is the contact,\nand dhyana is the connection. Dharana, which means \"holding on\", is\nthe focusing and holding one's awareness to one object for a long period of\ntime. Dhyana is contemplating, reflecting on whatever Dharana has focused on. Dharana\nmust precede dhyana, because the mind needs focusing on a particular object\nbefore a connection can be made.. People frequently confuse concentration with\nmeditation. In concentration, there is a subject and an object. You, the\nsubject, are concentrating on a the bindu of Sri yantra</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">candle, or an image of ishtadevata </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">or the tip of your nose. These are objects of\nconcentration. In meditation, the object disappears. The subject disappears.\nAll becomes one. Rather than focusing on a mantra, you and the mantra become\none. In meditation, all borders, boundaries, and separation between ourselves\nand the universe begin to disappear. We begin to realize the inherent oneness\nof all beings and all of creation. Dhyana is contemplation. If the\nconcentration was on one object, Dhyana is non-judgmental, non-presumptuous\nobservation of that object. Dhyana is uninterrupted train of thought, current\nof cognition, flow of awareness. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In Patanjali's\nRaja Yoga, dhyana is \"a refined meditative practice\" a \"deeper\nconcentration of the mind\", which is taken up after preceding exercises\nsuch as mastering pranayama (breath control) and dharana (mental focus). Dhyana\nis integrally related to Dharana, one leads to other. Dharana is a state of\nmind, Dhyana the process of mind. Dhyana is distinct from Dharana in that the\nmeditator becomes actively engaged with its focus. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">4000 years ago, Adi Shankaracharya, in his\ncommentary on Yoga Sutras, distinguishes Dhyana from Dharana, by explaining\nDhyana as the yoga state when there is only the \"stream of continuous\nthought about the object, uninterrupted by other thoughts of different kind for\nthe same object\"; Dharana, states Shankara, is focussed on one object, but\naware of its many aspects and ideas about the same object. Shankara gives the\nexample of a yogin in a state of dharana on morning sun may be aware of its\nbrilliance, color and orbit; the yogin in dhyana state contemplates on sun's\norbit alone for example, without being interrupted by its color, brilliance or\nother related ideas. Dhyana is the continuous flow of the same thought or image\nof the object of meditation, without being distracted by any other\nthought.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the mind has been trained\nto remain fixed on a certain internal or external location, there comes to it\nthe power of flowing in an unbroken current, as it were, towards that point,\nthis state is called Dhyana. While Dharana was the stage in yoga where the yogi\nheld one's awareness to one object for a long period of time, Dhyana is\nconcentrated meditation where he contemplates without interruption the object\nof meditation, beyond any memory of ego or anything else. Dhyana is distinct\nfrom Dharana, in that the yogi contemplates on the object of meditation and the\nobject's aspects only, free from distractions, with his mind during Dhyana.\nWith practice, the process of Dhyana awakens self-awareness.. Let me jump the\ngun a bit-- when one has so intensified the power of dhyana as to be able to\nreject the external part of perception and remain meditating only on the\ninternal part, the meaning, that state is called Samadhi. Patanjali\ndistinguishes between Dharana which is effortful focusing of attention, Dhyana\nwhich is easy continuous one-pointedness, and Samadhi which is absorption,\necstasy, contemplation. A person who begins meditation practice, usually\npractices Dharana. With practice he is able to gain ease in which he learns how\nto contemplate in a sharply focussed fashion, and then \"he is able more\nand more easily to give uninterrupted attention to the meditation object; that\nis to say, he attains Dhyana\". With further practice, the yogi\n\"ceases being detachedly vigilant\" and enters \"a state of fusion\nwith the meditation object\" which is Samadhi.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dhyana is\ncontemplating, reflecting on whatever Dharana has focused on. Dhyana Yoga is\nthe union of the individual self with the universal self. Yogic science does\nnot demarcate where the body starts and the mind begins, but approaches both as\na single, integrated entity. . If the concentration was on one object, Dhyana\nis non-judgmental, non-presumptuous observation of that object. If the focus\nwas on a concept/idea, Dhyana is contemplating that concept/idea in all its\naspects, forms and consequences. Dhyana is uninterrupted train of thought,\ncurrent of cognition, flow of awareness. Contemplation is of three kinds:\nmaterial (sthula dhyana), luminous (jyotir-dhyana) and subtle (sukshma-dhyana).\n(a) In \"material contemplation\", the image of a deity is thought of. (b)\nIn \"luminous contemplation\", the radiance of Divinity or of Nature\n(Prakriti) is pondered. (c) In \"subtle contemplation\", the mind is\nconcentrated on the point-limit (bindu) where the unmanifest becomes manifest,\nor on the basic coiled energy, kundalini. Contemplation is of two kinds, either\non a perceptible form (sa-rupa) or without a perceptible form (a-rupa).\nContemplation without a perceptible form is beyond the grasp of words and mind,\nit belongs to the unmanifest, is all-pervading and cannot be pointed to as\n'this' or 'that'. It is only through a long process of identification that\nyogis can cognize it. 'Dhyana is the study of deep concentration, calmness and\ntranquility of the mind. It is the study of attaining complete control over\nones mind. Meditation takes the consciousness beyond conscious, sub conscious\nand unconscious states to super consciousness. We all know that our mind is\nfickle, like a butterfly, which always flies from here and there and does not\nwait at one place for long. But the speed of our mind is far more than the\nbutterfly or it is greater than the speed of light. Mind can recollect past\nexperiences, keeps thinking about the future and experiences the present with\nall its might and we do not have any control over our minds journey. Mind has\nno physical existence. Existence of the mind can't be denied. The nature of the\nmind is to move from one point to another continuously. The mind has tremendous\nspeed.. Mind doesn't remain stable at any particular point or any object. It\nkeeps moving all the time. Mind runs after the objects it likes but runs away\nfrom the objects that it dislikes.You have already studied that the mind is\nessential in the process of acquiring knowledge. For example when you are\nlistening to a speaker in lecture, you learn through your ears. But if your\nmind is not concentrating on the lecture then you won't understand anything\nthere. As the mind is unstable, you cannot concentrate on lecture. So to learn\nwhat the speaker is telling, you must establish control over your mind and\nforce it to listen to the lecture. Then only you'll be able to acquire\nknowledge. Hence you have to control movements of mind and make it stable\nwhenever you want, as per your requirements. But this is the most difficult\npart because of unstable nature of mind. This process of making mind stable is\ncalled concentration.. If you want to remember a particular event, you will\nhave to concentrate your mind till you remember that event. Only then, one can\nget what he wants. But controlling mind is the most difficult task. Efforts are\nbeing continuously made to find out the ways and means to establish control\nover mind. Meditation is one of the very effective ways to control the mind.\nThis control can't be achieved in short period. &nbsp;Meditation is a systematically\ndesigned technique to achieve this step by step.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In Dhyana Yoga, it is\nimportant to remember three things: </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">one-pointedness\nof mind \u2013 controlling its movements; setting bounds to one\u2019s life to help\nachieve this \u2013 doing actions after weighing and measuring them; and state of\nlevel-headedness or evenness of vision \u2013 having the nobility to think in terms\nof the whole world.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">A true yoga teacher\nis not one who merely instructs verbal cues or gives theoretical knowledge, but\nalso one who guides and teaches mentally, spiritually and physically.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The very basic of a yoga class is adjustments\nand lifestyle intervention, if a teacher does not engages in such, he is just a\nmundane physical instructor. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dhyana\nensures that one does not grow with ego, the sense of self and feeling of being\nsuperior, no matter how much achievement you unlock. Practicing Dhyana Yoga\nallows the practitioner to calm his mind and allow him to look in the outside\nworld without distractions. In doing so, he is able to reach a heightened level\nof awareness. Dhyana will help us to gain awareness of the happenings and ensure\nthat we ultimately reach true bliss, but not indulge in momentary pleasures. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dhyana involves concentration upon a point of\nfocus with the intention of knowing the truth about it. During dharana the mind\nis moving in one direction like a quiet river-nothing else is happening. In\ndhyana, one becomes involved with a particular thing - a link is established\nbetween self and object. In other words, you perceive a particular object and\nat the same time continuously communicate with it. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Each time the mind evades you, runs here and\nthere and you bring it back, that is called concentration. Concentration is\ntrying to fix the mind on one thing. Meditation is when you have tried and are\nsuccessful. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">To focus the attention to\none point will not result in insight or realization. One must identify and\nbecome \"one with\" the object of contemplation, in order to know for\ncertain the truth about it. In dhyana, the consciousness of the practitioner is\nin one flow; it is no longer fixed on one subject as in dharana. Vedanta holds\nthat, since the universal divine Self dwells within the heart, the way to\nexperience and recognize divinity is to turn one's attention inward in a\nprocess of contemplative meditation. Adi Shankaracharya </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">dedicates an extensive chapter on meditation,\nin his commentary on the Brahma-sutras. The mind is like a lake, and stones\nthat are dropped into it (or winds) raise waves. Those waves do not let us see\nwho we are. (...) The waters must be calmed. If one remains quite, eventually\nthe winds that ruffle the water will give up, and then one knows who one is.\nGod is constantly within us, but the mind obscures that fact with agitated\nwaves of worldly desires. Meditation quiets those waves (Bhagavad Gita V.28).</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are different\nforms of Dhyana Yoga. The aim is to withdraw all senses from various objects of\ninterest and focus on one object. Dhyana Yoga produces a state of tranquility.\nIts objective is to cleanse the subconscious, develop concentration, clear the\nmind, and bring about various stages of unified communion with God. The most\nimportant aspect for a successful meditation practice is regularity. The best\ntime for practice is early morning. The great yogis recommend we practice\nduring Brahmamuhurta, or the hours between 4 and 6 am. Find a quiet undisturbed\nplace in your house to meditate and set up an inspiring and vibrationally\nuplifting meditation space or altar. If possible you should try to find a place\nthat no one else will disturb -It is common practice to set on the altar some\nphotos of your main deity, or the Om symbol.&nbsp;\nMany people cover the altar with a pleasing colour cloth and keep there\nfresh flowers, incense, oil lamp, and one or several deity figures. To be able\nto meditate well you have to be able to sit comfortably. Try to find a good,\ncomfortable cross-legged posture. Your posture should be very steady and easy\nto maintain. The back should be straight to balance&nbsp; the spirit level inyour inner ear cochlea.\nand the whole body should be as relaxed as possible. Generally you should keep\nyour hands on the knees or folded together in front of the body to help\npreserve energy. Try not to move. Keep your eyes closed unless you are\npracticing tratak (steady gazing). At this point it can be helpful to repeat\nthe mantra OM several times, at first out loud and then gradually mentally. It\nwill help to calm the mind in preparation for the remaining steps. Now that you\nare comfortably in your steady posture in your meditation space, you should\nmake a sankalpa, or resolve, commanding the mind to be quiet for a specific\nlength of time \u2013 this will give a powerful instruction to the subconscious\nmind. The resolve could be, \u2018I will keep my mind quiet for 20 minutes\u2019, or \u2018I\nwill meditate 15 minutes\u2019. Whatever you choose for your sankalpa be sure to\nfinish the resolve to give strength to the mind and set up a good pattern for\nyour practice. It is important at this stage not to force the mind to be still.\nIf you try to force it too much it will rebel, making your practice even more\ndifficult. Be patient and persevere.. Work with your mind, not against it. Try\nto be a witness of the extraneous thoughts, not being affected by them, but\nletting them go by as though you are just watching and not engaging with them.\nThis stage can be very difficult, but with proper patience and diligence can be\novercome. Calm the bubbling emotions, sentiments, instincts and impulses\nthrough silent meditation. Once your mind starts to calm down you should select\na focal point, or lakshya, to concentrate on. This is usually either the place\nbetween the eyebrows (ajna chakra), or in the heart center in the middle of the\nchest (anahata chakra). Center your mind in that point, concentrating all of\nyour prana (energy) and attention at that place. As an aid to concentration, it\ncan be helpful to envision in your lakshya a bright white light or your main\ndeity, or OM symbol or the Bindu of Sri Yantra. Usually people will choose the\nspace between the eyebrows and more emotional people will choose the heart\ncenter. Once you determine your focal point you should never change it.&nbsp; The last step is to concentrate on a mantra.\nThis becomes your main object of concentration. Everything else should just be\nin the background of your mind. Keep repeating the mantra until you become\ntotally immersed in it. You should coordinate the correct repetition of the\nmantra on the inhale, and the correct repetition of the mantra on the exhale.\nSome people don't have a mantra, and it is acceptable for them to use the\nuniversal mantra OM. In dharana, the mind is put through various rigors of\ntrainings to restrain its waywardness and to refine its awareness to the\nultimate degree of \u2018one-pointedness\u2019. Achieving this state is an \u2018active\nprocess\u2019 that requires much effort. But it is precisely when this\n\u2018one-pointedness\u2019 of mind ceases to be an \u2018active effort\u2019 and then just\n\u2018happens naturally\u2019, without any effort, that we have achieved the state of\nmeditation.\u2026 notice that I refer to meditation as a \u2018state\u2019 (of being, or of\nmind), and not a techinique that we \u2018practice\u2019. So dhyana, as far as it can be\ndescribed with words, is an unbroken stream of concentration, whereby very\nlittle \u2018sense of self\u2019 remains. At this level, it becomes increasingly more\ndifficult to use words and the reasoning, conscious mind to describe the\nexperiences of yoga. After all, the state of meditation, by its very nature\ntranscends our material human experience and everything that is related to it.\nWe could say that meditation (dhyana), is concentration (dharana) taken to\n\u2018perfection\u2019 \u2014 In other words, a meditative state is the natural result of\n\u2018perfect concentration\u2019. So it is prolonged concentration, then, that leads the\nsadhaka into this \u2018spontaneous\u2019 and \u2018free-flowing\u2019 meditative state, whereby\nnothing but the object of concentration fills the mental space; and whereby the\nobserver and the observed merge into one. We could also say that it is the\noccasional appearance of \u2018distractions in the mind\u2019 that constitutes the\nessential difference between dharana and dhyana.&nbsp; Meditation is an exalted state of being which\nis produced by a moral and ethical, pure lifestyle; control of the body and\nbreath through Asana and Pranayama; transcendence of and freedom from the\nimprisonment of the senses in Pratyahara. Practices of Dharana, exercises in\nconcentrating and focusing the mind must be perfected. Only then is one able to\neven speak of meditation, let alone experience it. Prayer is NOT meditation.\nThe former is a petition to&nbsp; God, and the\nother is a detached observation of one's own mind, and its processes. In the\nmodern world, meditation is used as a non-religious technique for relaxation\nand stress reduction for long-term psychological improvements. Meditation is\ndone to purify the mind and gain insight.&nbsp;\nIt abstracts the self from conscious thought, and frees the mind from\nfeelings that cause stress and suffering.&nbsp;&nbsp;\nIt fosters creative intelligence, raise consciousness, and enables\nfuller use to be made of mental potential. The spiritual aims are peace of\nmind, wisdom, and, ultimately, a state of enlightenment or\nself-realization.&nbsp; It is a&nbsp; form of natural healing, and helps people\ncope with&nbsp; anxiety, depression, and drug\ndependence. The attention is focused on monitoring the breath, and noting\nthoughts crossing the mind, without any judgement or attempt at control, but as\na silent and detached witness.&nbsp; If the\nmind throws up distractions, the meditator returns to simply observing the\nbreath each time the distraction happens.&nbsp;\nA relaxed and unhurried attitude is important, since slowing down and\nobserving the mind to see how it works is central to the philosophy behind\nmeditation. Using the mantra technique, the meditator concentrates on a\nmantra&nbsp; to banish intrusive thoughts and\nthus achieve progressively quieter levels of thinking until thought itself is\ntranscended. The subtle vitalizing frequencies of mantras activate psychic\nenergies and awaken our intuitive faculties.&nbsp;\nSonic frequencies interact with our cellular vibration levels and assist\nin maintaining a healthy resonant frequency in our bodies. Mantras still the\nactivity of thought and helps you find a deeper level of consciousness.\nMeditation brings peace and allows us to raise our vibrational level.&nbsp; Digestion grounds us. Hence eat only\nafter&nbsp; the meditation session.&nbsp; Eating engages the body\u2019s digestive system ,\nthus returning the body\u2019s vibrational level back to normal. During meditation\nthinking is separated from perceiving, so that the individual can stand apart\nfrom the emotional self.&nbsp; The reason why\npeople remain mired in negativity is because of the beliefs they have inherited\nover time. Beliefs are subconscious. We act in the way we do because we are not\naware of our beliefs and the feelings that these beliefs generate. That is why\nit is important to obeserve yourself and look within. We can do it. That is why\nwe are different from animals. We can use our&nbsp;\nconscious mind to observe ,to introspect and dip into the&nbsp; subconscious where our beliefs are embedded ,\nin order to eliminate it.&nbsp; You can\nmeditate to rewrite these negative programmes&nbsp;\nthat cause you misery. To be a mystic or a seer is not the same thing as\nbeing a spectator on the fence.&nbsp;\nMysticism provides an escape from a life of uninspired existence. It\nmagnifies man and gives him a hope and destiny to fulfill. In the modern era\nthe road to holiness necessarily passes through the world of action. A Mystic\nwho is not of supreme service to the Society -- AINT NO MYSTIC AT ALL.&nbsp; -- Meditation is an exercise of the mind.\nWhat physical exercise is to the body, meditation is to the mind. Silencing the\nbody is easy, but silencing the mind is difficult in this modern age. Silencing\nis about grace, harmony and tranquility. Exhaustion is NOT tranquility. In the\nmodern age people get stressed, and they need to still the mind--the chattering\nmonkey, which remains entangled in the past and the imagined future, but never\nin the present.&nbsp; Meditation is about\nholding your mind to the present. It is the search for inner strength. It is\nNOT a drill. It has to be done with grace. Your mind cant keep going round and\nround in circles, etching a deep groove and make the subject deep rooted.\nBeware of the spiritually arrogant, such persons cant be proper Gurus. A person\nstops thinking either when he is dead or when he has realised. When your ego\npowered mind is chattering like a monkey or the angry sea, you miss the truth.\nTruth can be communicated only in silence. For this deep silence you need to\nhave harmony between the mind, body and soul. The aim of every form of\nmeditation is to still the mind, or you cant purify it and get rid of deep\nrooted negativities , which affect your health and even give you severe\nmigraines.&nbsp; Meditation is a surgical\noperation of your subconscious mind to remove and discard negativity / ego and\nimprove tolerance, grace and kindness.&nbsp;\nYoga uses the awareness of breath method. The meditator sees the cosmos\nas nothing but the tiniest packet of quantum energy. It makes you a watcher and\na witness. Such a person cannot be an egoist. The art of observing is to help\nyou feel separate from all that you are clinging to. For a layman-- you are\nstressed when your hands feel cold, your heart rate, breathing, and muscle\ntension increases. The result is that your immune system goes for a toss and\nyou get depressed or burnt out.. Depression is a weird feeling of loss .\nMeditation teaches you to look inwards, with awareness , withing yourself and\nknow the true nature of all sensations, and loosen the stranglehold of habits\nand vices.. he scans his own body and sees where the stress and tension is. He\njust witnesses , he does not react. His mind does not control him, rather he\ncontrols his mind. It is a universal remedy for all universal ills. Find a\nquiet place to sit for 15 minutes. place where you can sit comfortably,\nundisturbed, for at least 20 minutes. Background noises like the sound of a car\nhorn or a ticking clock should not be considered hindrances, and in fact can be\nlegitimate objects of mindfulness. Don't wear earplugs .&nbsp; Wear loose clothing&nbsp; and be bare feet. Sit with your back and head\nheld straight. You may sit on the floor or in a chair. Keep your eyes closed.\nIf you must move, notice how and why you are moving.&nbsp; Simply be mindful of in-and-out breathing.\nYou may feel that your breathing is too short, too long, too gentle or too\nheavy. Do not try to control it. Stop judging. Just let it be, let it settle by\nitself as you watch.&nbsp; It is the process\nof watching which is the meditation, not what you are watching.&nbsp; When you become distracted, gently refocus\nyour attention on your breathing. Keep watching. Just breathe... As the abdomen\nrises, observe the motion from beginning to end with your mind. When the\nabdomen falls, do the same. That's it. Just keep watching the rising-falling\nmovements. You don't have to do anything to them. Just know the movements\nwithout judging or describing them.&nbsp;\nRestrict your attention to what is occurring in the immediate present\nmoment. Don't think about the past or future\u2014 don't think about anything at\nall. Let go of worries, concerns, and memories. Empty your mind of everything\nexcept the movements occurring right now. But don't think about the motions;\njust know them.In insight meditation the aim is not to think, but only to know.\nAs the abdomen expands, say the word \"rising\" in your mind. When it\ncontracts, say \"falling.\" Continue to note rising, falling, rising,\nfalling, from one moment to the next. Ninety-percent of your attention should\nbe on the actual movement instead of on the label. The aim in meditation is to\nknow the object itself, not the word.&nbsp;\nThe abdomen should not be visualized. You only have to know the\nmovements. Be sure to breathe naturally; don't try to control the breath in any\nway. A mental note identifies the object in general but not in detail. For\nexample, when a sound pulls your attention away, label it \"hearing\"\ninstead of car horn,\" \"voices\" or \"barking dog.\" If an\nunpleasant sensation arises, note \"pain \" or \"feeling\"\ninstead of \"knee pain\" or \"my back pain.\" Then return your\nattention to the primary object. When aware of a fragrance, say the mental note\n\"smelling\" for a moment or two. You don't have to identify the scent.\nThe motto is: \"Focus and forget it,\" or \"know and let\ngo.\"Healing is NOT a physical process, rather it is mental. Mind can wipe\nmistakes off the DNA blueprint and destroy any disease that has disturbed the\ndesign. DNA's ability to repair itself is affected adversely when a person is\nin depression. Meditation experiences silence, and is devoid of drives, wishes,\nfears , thoughts and emotions. Afterwards when the mind returns to its usual\nlevel of consciousness, it has acquired some freedom to move.. Grace and peace\nare the hallmarks of a healthy non-delusional mind in a healthy body.. The\nhappiness is stable.There is NO medicine for jealousy, fear, greed and other\ntoxic negativity.&nbsp; Only Yoga can save.\nAlthough there is a notable separation between dharana (concentration) and\ndhyana (meditation) in yogic philosophy, there is also an intimate connection\nbetween the two. The ancient Vedic&nbsp;\nIndian psychology has a&nbsp; fourfold\nscale, which represents the degrees of the ladder of being by which man climbs\nback to the source, the absolute divine. The change, from \u201chere\u201d to\n\u201cthere,\u201d&nbsp; is not an uneventful process at\nall.&nbsp; There come dry periods, deviations,\nviolent alterations, and temptations. If there are raptures and azure heavens,\nthere are anaconda agonies and absolute abandonments, howling hot deserts and\n\u201cdark cold nights of the soul\u201d to go through. Streaming tears of joy,\nhorripilation (bristling of the hair), stigmata (bodily marks or pains), and\nparapsychological phenomena have been known to develop. The first stage of\nmeditation&nbsp; achieves detachment from\nsensual desires and impure states of mind through analysis and reflection and\nthereby attains an emotional state of satisfaction and joy. In the second\nstage, intellectual activities are abated to a complete inner serenity; the\nmind is in a state of \u201cone-pointedness\u201d or concentration, joy, and\npleasantness. In the third stage, every emotion, including joy, has\ndisappeared, leaving the meditator indifferent to everything while remaining\ncompletely conscious. The fourth stage is the abandoning of any sense of\nsatisfaction, pain, or serenity because any inclination to a good or bad state\nof mind has disappeared. The meditator thus enters a state of supreme purity,\nindifference to everything, and pure consciousness. There were no bounds to the\nmagical powers that can be attained by great Hindu ascetics and yogis&nbsp; teaching the suppression of all activity of\nmind, body, and will in order that the self may realize its distinction from\nthem and attain liberation. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cWhatever great thing\nis known to men is known through meditation \u2026 the whole earth, middle space,\nthe heaven, waters and even mountains are engaged in Dhyana\u201d. ~ Chandogya\nUpanishad 5000 BC<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">3.03--&nbsp;&nbsp; tad evarthamatranirbhasan svaroopashoonyam\niva samadhih</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">When the object of\nmeditation engrosses the meditator, appearing as the subject, self-awareness is\nlost. This is samadhi.</span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the attentive flow\nof consciousness fuses with the object of meditation, the consciousness of the\nmeditator, the subject, appears to be dissolved in the object. This union of\nsubject and object becomes samadhi.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the object of\ncontemplation shines forth without the interference of one's own consciousness,\ndhyana flows into samadhi. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When a musician loses\nhimself and is completely enwrapped in his music, or an inventor makes his\ndiscoveries when devoid of ego, or a painter surpasses himself with colour,\nshade and brush, they glimpse samadhi. So it is with the yogi - when his object\nof contemplation becomes himself, devoid of himself, he experiences samadhi.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The dissimilarity is\nthat the artist or musician arrives at this state by effort, and cannot sustain\nit; while the yogi, remaining devoid of ego, experiences it as natural, continuous\nand effortless. Therefore it is difficult for an artist to instill his vision\nof the sublime, which is associated with the performance and realisation of a\nparticular art form, into his common daily existence. For the yogi, however,\nwhose 'art' is formless and whose goal has no physical expression like a\npainting, a book or a symphony, the fragrance of samadhi imbues every aspect of\nhis 'normal' behaviour, activities and state of being.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Uninterrupted flow of\nattention dissolves the rip between the object seen and the seer who sees it.\nConsciousness appears to have ceased, and to have reached a state of silence.\nIt is devoid of 'I', and unites into the core of the being in an unfathomed\nstate of serenity. In samadhi, awareness of place vanishes and one ceases to\nexperience space and time.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the object of\nmeditation engulfs the meditator, appearing as the subject, self-awareness is\nlost. This is samadhi.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">These verses in the video below &nbsp;were\npenned by Adi Shankaracharya 4000 years ago at the age of&nbsp; eight.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">He was the last of the 12 strand\nDNA NIL junk \u2013 king sized pineal gland maharishis. &nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Adi Shankaracharya is beyond prizes from mere 2 strand DNA , 97% junk, shriveled / calcified pineal gland &nbsp;mortals like me -&nbsp;</span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">--still I shall give him the VADAKAYIL PRIZE. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The world is a rich place because of the great soul.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/7FZFvFWztOA/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/7FZFvFWztOA?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_10M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 22.4px; margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/08/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_2.html?showComment=1470149484748#c3929991152181224766\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">August 2, 2016 at 8:21 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_10MC\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 22.4px; margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\">ADI SHANKARACHARYA ( 2000 BC ) GETS THE VADAKAYIL PRIZE. &nbsp; THIS PRIZE IS NOT WORTH A GREAT SOUL LIKE HIM-- &nbsp; &nbsp;STILL LET IT BE !</span></b><br />\n<br />\nHERE IS THE THE LIST OF MAHA MERUS WHO FOOLED THE WORLD , WHOM I HAVE TRASHED INTO THE GARBAGE BIN OF THE PLANET.<br />\n<br />\nGARBAGE BUCKET LIST:<br />\n<br />\n1) BERTRAND RUSSEL<br />\n2) ROMILA THAPAR<br />\n3) IRFAN HABIB<br />\n4) NOAM CHOMSKY<br />\n5) RAMCHANDRA GUHA<br />\n6) SHELDON POLLOCK<br />\n7) SIGMUND FREUD<br />\n8) GEORG WILHELM HEGEL<br />\n9) AMARTYA SEN<br />\n10) WENDY DONIGER<br />\n11) FREIDRICH WILHELM NIETZSCHE<br />\n12) IMMANUEL KANT<br />\n13 ) BARUCH SPINOZA<br />\n14) ALBERT EINSTEIN<br />\n15) ISAAC NEWTON<br />\n16) GUGLEILMO MARCONI<br />\n17) CHARLES DARWIN<br />\n18) KARL MARX<br />\n19) MAX WEBER<br />\n20) THOMAS ALVA EDISON<br />\n20) FIBONACCI<br />\n<br />\nNOTE: MENTAL MIDGETS LIKE ROMILA THAPAR , IRFAN HABIB , RAMACHANDRA GUHA, SHELDON POLLOCK, WENDY DONIGER MUST BE THANKFUL THAT THEY ARE INCLUDED AMONG A LIST OF CEREBRAL GIANTS<br />\n<br />\n#########################<br />\n<br />\nHERE ARE PEOPLE WHO MADE A DENT IN THE UNIVERSE\u2014 THEY GET THE \"VADAKAYIL PRIZE\". THIS IS NOT A VESTED \u201cNOBEL PRIZE \u201c<br />\n<br />\n1) NIKOLA TESLA<br />\n2) DIMITRI MENDELEYEEV<br />\n3) IE IRODOV<br />\n4) ARYABHATTA<br />\n5) SRINIVASAN RAMANUJAN<br />\n6) CHANAKYA<br />\n7) ADI SHANKARACHARYA<br />\n<br />\ncapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 250%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\">The little\ngap between two thoughts is nothing but Pure Awareness.</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 115%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2013/01/sabarimala-makaravilakku-three-light.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2013/01/sabarimala-makaravilakku-three-light.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-gtUeBjRa9Ds/V6DRl4-FK3I/AAAAAAABLOg/4SyNWCAlfuwHpLkRTCgcaSbNSITo9RjZQCLcB/s1600/o-SABARIMALA-TEMPLE-facwebook.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-gtUeBjRa9Ds/V6DRl4-FK3I/AAAAAAABLOg/4SyNWCAlfuwHpLkRTCgcaSbNSITo9RjZQCLcB/s1600/o-SABARIMALA-TEMPLE-facwebook.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-wrzPkkB5bbI/V6DSGfzD78I/AAAAAAABLOk/13-oUh5HwLQn1r1Pvn8YlZKffaiEs9opQCLcB/s1600/sabarimala-makaravidlakku.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"480\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-wrzPkkB5bbI/V6DSGfzD78I/AAAAAAABLOk/13-oUh5HwLQn1r1Pvn8YlZKffaiEs9opQCLcB/s640/sabarimala-makaravidlakku.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 250%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">IMPORTANT: &nbsp; SAMADHI &nbsp;BY KUNDALINI RAISE , AND SUBSEQUENT MOKSHA , &nbsp; IS OBTAINED ONLY BY PEOPLE WHOSE KARMIC BAGGAGE IS VERY\nLITTLE AND APPROACHING ZERO.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 250%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 250%;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">BEWARE\nOF ROGUE GURUS WHO &nbsp;SNATCH SPIRITUAL POWER , &nbsp;THE IGNORANT FAKES WHO COME ON &nbsp;BENAMI TV &nbsp;GHADI GHADI , &nbsp;WHO CRAVE THE LIMELIGHT, &nbsp; WHO SET FAALTHU GUINNESS BOOK OF WORLD RECORDS , &nbsp;WHO PROPAGATE ROTHSCHILDs FAKE CHITPAVAN JEW GODS OF PANDHARPUR, &nbsp;WHO SPEAK AT UN / FREEMASON SEMINARS , OPPORTUNISTIC BASTARDS WEARING JESUS CHRIST TYPE ROBES &nbsp;WHO SAY ANAL SEX BETWEEN MEN VERY GOOD ( SO\nTHAT ZIONIST JEWS WILL OPEN MORE BRANCHES FOR THEM AROUND THE WORLD AND GIVE\nTHEM PUBLICITY IN ROTHSCHILDs MEDIA ) &nbsp;, &nbsp;WHO\nSTAY IN 5 STAR HOTELS --</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 250%;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 250%;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">NOWADAYS MENTALLY SICK PEOPLE ARE CLAIMING TO HAVE RAISED THEIR KUNDALINI AND OBTAINED SAMADHI. &nbsp; &nbsp; WHEN SUCH &nbsp;MAD PEOPLE <span style=\"color: red;\">WITHOUT EGO ( BECAUSE THEY ARE MAD )</span> DIE , THEIR GREEDY AND EVIL FOLLOWERS CONVERT THEM INTO GODS &nbsp;AND START CULTS , WITH POLITICAL AND COLLEGIUM &nbsp;JUDICIARY &nbsp;SUPPORT. &nbsp; BIG FOREIGN &nbsp;MONEY IS INVOLVED .&nbsp;</b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In Samadhi, there is\nneither Dhyana nor Dhyata (neither meditation nor meditator). The meditator and\nmeditated, the thinker and the thought, the worshipper and the worshipped\nbecome one or identical.. Sam\u0101dhi is the highest state of consciousness that a\nhuman can reach in life. It is the goal of our spiritual journey on earth. Samadhi\nis the blissful return to our Divine origin. When the thousand-petalled Lotus\nof the Sahasrara Chakra opens and the Jivatma dissolves within it, the goal of\nits long, experience-rich journey is reached, and its lifelong thirst for the\n\u201cnectar of immortality\u201d (Amrita) is quenched.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is no longer any\nindividuality. Consciousness and self-awareness continue to exist, but not in\nthe previous duality of \u201cthat is mine\u201d and \u201cthat is yours\u201d. The person lives\non, but from now on the inner Self remains with the Supreme Self. This means the\nend of all problems and pain, the end of suffering, of rebirth and death. The\nliberated one lives on the earth in eternal happiness and joy, and when the\nbody is renounced the consciousness dissolves completely in the Divine Self. As\nin sleep, physical sensations such as heat, cold, hunger, thirst, etc., are\nstrongly diminished in Samadhi. The state of Samadhi, however, is in no way\ndetrimental to the body. The atma is at all times connected to the body, and is\na witness to everything that occurs. Therefore, at any time one can return to\n\u201cnormal consciousness\u201d just as one instantly awakens from a dream if touched or\nspoken to. Samadhi is the Supreme Consciousness in which knower, knowledge and\nobject of knowledge unite. A peaceful nature, all-understanding goodness,\npurity, splendour and a quiet dignity radiate from a God-Realised soul. When\nall the \u201cseeds\u201d of the Vasanas (desires, wishes) have been roasted and burnt in\nthe \u201cfire of Yoga\u201d can they no longer sprout. Only then does the door to\nliberation open to the aspirant. Because from then on one\u2019s actions produce no\nnew Samskaras in one\u2019s consciousness, and therefore no more effects for\nsubsequent lives. With the dissolution of the ego \u2013 when the distinction of \u201cmy\nI\u201d and \u201cyour I\u201d no longer exist \u2013 the Sanchitkarma ((Karma from earlier lives)\nalso dissolves. He is so much established in that state of spiritual\nconsciousness or awareness that even while he is moving and acting, he still\nremains in that state of inner awareness. He has no use for Guinness book of\nworld records , dye for hair /beard , or faalthu limelight on TV. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">They no longer identify\nwith body, mind, senses, emotions, qualities, worldly position or profession.\nTheir inner bliss is unshakable. The last chains of Karma dissolve, and all\nassociated attachments vanish. They discover the entire Universe within and\nalso identify the Self with the Cosmos. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nirvikalpa Samadhi\nmeans \"free from all sorts of modifications and imaginations.\" The\nmind completely melts in BrahmAn. A sudden stroke of mystic illumination puts\nan end to all the empirical existence altogether and the very idea or\nremembrance of such a thing as this world or the narrow individuality of the\nspirit in this world absolutely leaves the Self. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When you enter into\nnirvikalpa samadhi, however, you not only feel bliss, but actually grow into\nthat bliss. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">You see the universe as a\ntiny dot inside your vast heart. When the yogi can: (1) sustain focus on the\npratyaya for an extended period of time, and (2) minimize his or her\nself-consciousness during the practice, then dhyana transforms into samadhi. In\nthis fashion then, the yogi becomes fused with the pratyaya. Patanjali compares\nthis to placing a transparent jewel on a colored surface: the jewel takes on\nthe color of the surface. Similarly, in samadhi, the consciousness of the yogi\nfuses with the object of thought, the pratyaya. The pratyaya is like the\ncolored surface, and the yogi's consciousness is like the transparent jewel.\nSamadhi is a spiritual state of consciousness.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the object of\nmeditation engulfs the meditator, appearing as the subject, self-awareness is\nlost. When, in meditation, the true nature of the object shines forth, not\ndistorted by the mind of the perceiver, that is absorption (samadhi).&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In samadhi the mind becomes still. It is a\nstate of being totally aware of the present moment</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: large;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\">THIS POST IS NOW&nbsp;</span><span style=\"line-height: 24px;\">CONTINUED</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;TO PART 62, BELOW--</span></b></span><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/08/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_5.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/08/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_5.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2015/01/yoga-only-complete-exercise.html\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2015/01/yoga-only-complete-exercise.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">CHAPTER I-&nbsp; SAMADHI PADA-&nbsp;&nbsp; CONTEMPLATION<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">atha yoganushasanam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">yogashchittavrittinirodhah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tada drashtuh svaroope\navasthanam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">vrittisaroopyam\nitaratra<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">vrittayah pangchatayyah\nklishta aklishtah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">pramannaviparyayavikalpanidrasmritayah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">pratyakshanumanagamah\npramanani<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">viparyayo mithyajnanam\natadroopapratishtham<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">abhavapratyayalambana\nvrittirnidra<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">abhyasavairagyabhyan\ntannirodhah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tatra sthitau yatno\nabhyasah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">sa tu\ndirghakalanairantaryasatkarasevito dridha-bhoomih<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">hetufalashrayalambanaih\nsangrihitatvad eshamabhave tadabhavah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">atitanagatan\nsvaroopatostyadhvabhedad<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">te vyaktasookshma\ngunatmanah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">parinamaikatvad\nvastutattvam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">vastusamye chittabhedat\ntayorvibhaktah panthah <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">taduparagapekshatvat\nchittasya vastu jnatajnatam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">sada jnatashchittavrittayastatprabhohpurushasyaparinamitvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">na tat\nsvabhasandrishyatvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">ekasamaye\nchobhayanavadharannam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">chittantaradrishye\nbuddhibuddheratiprasanggah smritisankarashcha<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">chiterapratisankramayastadakarapattausvabuddhisanvedanam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">drashtridrishyoparaktan\nchittan sarvartham<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tadasankhyeyavasanachitram\napi pararthan sanhatyakaritvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">visheshadarshin\naatmabhavabhavanavinivrittih<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tada vivekanimnan\nkaivalyapragbharan chittam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tachchhidreshu\npratyayantarani sanskarebhyah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">hanam esham\nkleshavaduktam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">prasankhyanepyakusidasy\nsarvathavivekakhyaterdharmameghah samadhih<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tatah\nkleshakarmanivrittih<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tada\nsarvavarannamalapetasyjnanasyaanantyajgyeyam alpam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tatah kritarthanan\nparinamakramapari samaptirgunanam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">kshannapratiyogi\nparinamaparantanigrarhyah kramah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">purusharthashoonyanan\ngunanan pratiprasavahkaivalyan, svaroopapratishtha va chitishaktireti<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.52 - - Tatah ksiyate\nprakasa avaranam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Pranayama removes the\nveil covering the light of knowledge and heralds the dawn of wisdom. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Its practice eliminates\nillusion, comprising ignorance, desire and delusion, which overcloud the\nintelligence; and permits the inner light of wisdom to shine. As the breeze\ndiffuses the clouds that blanket the sun, pranayama blows away the clouds that\nscreen the light of the intelligence. In the Yoga Chudamani Upanisad, it stated\nthat there is no discipline higher than pranayama. It is named as an enlivened\nknowledge (mahavidya), a royal road to well being, freedom and rapture. Advanced\npranayama is done after much practice.&nbsp;\nIt\u2019s mastership does not come easy.&nbsp;\nThe result of it, is clear to a yogi because the dark mind space is\ncleared off and a brilliant light is perceived.&nbsp;\nThis light is illuminating (prakasa).&nbsp;\nThe regular practice of pranayama reduces the obstacles that inhibit\nclear perception.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2.53 - - </span>&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">dharanasu ch yojnata manasah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">The mind also becomes\nfit for concentration. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pranayama is not only\nan instrument to balance the mind, but also the gateway to concentration -\ndharana. &nbsp;Once the new light of knowledge\nhas dawned through the practice of pranayama, the mind is fit and knowledgeable\nto move on towards the realisation of the soul. The allusion here is clear that\nthe sadhaka who had to struggle initially to cultivate a yogic way of life by\nself-discipline and study, now finds his efforts transformed into a natural\nfervour to progress in his sadhana. The covering to the light of the Chitta is&nbsp; attenuated.&nbsp;\nThus the mind becomes fit for concentration.&nbsp; Dharana practice requires a preliminary\nmastership in certain aspects of prana energy control.&nbsp; This is why when someone sits to meditate\nwithout first doing pranayama , he cannot be successful even though he may\nimagine for himself in peace happiness and light. &nbsp;Dhara\u1e47a means single minded focus.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nprior limb Pratyahara involves withdrawing the senses from external phenomena.\nDh\u0101ra\u1e47\u0101 builds further upon this by refining it further to ekagrata or ekagra\nchitta, that is single-pointed concentration and focus. Samatha is done by\npracticing single-pointed meditation, through mindfulness of breathing.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All\nother operations of the mind are suspended or stopped. According to the Hatha\nYogic school, a Yogi who can suspend his breath by Kumbhaka for 20 minutes can\nhave a very good Dharana. He will have tranquillity of mind. Pranayama steadies\nthe mind, removes the Vikshepa and increases the power of concentration. Fixing\nthe mind on something is Dharana or concentration of mind. Dharana can be done\nonly if you are free from the distractions of mind.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nVrittis that arise from the mind obscure your native state. They are like\nclouds that screen the sun. During the time of concentration, the seer\nidentifies himself with his own native state. At other times of concentration,\nthe seer identifies with his Vrittis. This is a great distraction of the mind.</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When\nall the Vrittis are controlled and when the mind is one-pointed, it is\ntransparent like a crystal.
