The mind loses itself in the object concentrated\nupon. The mind acquires the power of appearing in the shape of whatever is\npresented to it, be it the knower, the knowable or the knowledge. Just as the\ncrystal becomes coloured by the colour of the object placed before it and then\nshines according to the form of the object, so also this mind is coloured by\nthe colour of the object presented to it, and then appears in the form of the\nobject.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vedantins\ntry to fix their mind on Atman, the Inner Self. This is their Dharana. When Hatha\nYogins concentrate their mind on Shat Chakras or the six centres of spiritual\nenergy, they concentrate their mind on the respective presiding Devatas and\nTattvas. Bhaktas concentrate their mind on their Ishta Devata. Dharana is an\nimportant stage for any kind of Sadhana.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the mind is\nintensely fond of anything, there will be no perception of pain even if\ndestruction awaits the body. You find lovers committing suicide together all\nover the world.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are five Yoga Bhumikas or stages\nor five states of mind, viz., (1) Kshipta (wandering); (2) Mudha (forgetful);\n(3) Vikshipta (gathering mind); (4) Ekagrata (one- pointed); (5) Nirudha\n(controlled or well-restrained). In Kshipta state the rays of the mind are\nscattered. It is always wandering. In Mudha state, the man does not know\nanything. He is quite dull. He will harm others. In Vikshipta state, the mind\nis centered for a short time only; but wanders about for a long time. In\nEkagrata state, it is one-pointed and concentrated. You can enter into Samadhi\nwith the help of this mind. In Nirudha state, all the Vrittis are controlled.\nThis is the state of Vritti-sunya. But Samskaras which are the seeds for\nVrittis are here. No Yoga is possible in the first three states of mind. Yoga\nis possible in the fourth and fifth states only.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Purify the mind\nfirst through the practice of Yama and Niyama. Then take to the practice of\nDharana. Concentration without purity is of no use.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ethical\nperfection is of paramount importance. A man whose mind is filled with passion\nand all sorts of fantastic desires can hardly concentrate on any object even\nfor a second. His mind will be jumping like a monkey.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There\ncan be no concentration without something upon which the mind may rest. The\nmind can be fixed easily on a pleasing object such as a ishta devata or a fresh\nfragrant flower. It is very difficult in the beginning to fix the mind on any\nobject which it dislikes such as a lump of stinking shit, a cobra or a bleeding\nbody.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Practise\nconcentration till the mind is well- established on the object of\nconcentration. When the mind runs away from the object of concentration bring\nit back again to the object. It is very difficult to practise concentration\nwhen one is very thirsty or when one is suffering from an acute disease. One\nhas to make the mind fit for yoga practice (yogyata manasah).&nbsp; The mind will prevent the attention from\nlinking to a higher concentration force or person if the mind itself is not\nsurcharged with a higher grade of pranic energy.&nbsp; It will be unable to make a higher linkage,\nexcept now and again, by a fluke, haphazardly.&nbsp;\nFor consistent practice one must do the asana with pranayama daily\nbefore meditation practice.&nbsp; Dhara\u1e47a is\nthe sixth stage, step or limb of eight elucidated by Patanjali's Ashtanga Yoga.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.54- - svasvavishayasanprayoge\nchittasy svaroopanukar ivendriyanan pratyaharah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Withdrawing the senses,\nmind and consciousness from contact with external objects, and then drawing\nthem inwards towards the seer, is pratyahara. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Now the mind is able to\nconcentrate and the senses no longer pester the mind for their satiation. They\nlose interest in the tastes and flavours of their respective objects, and are\ndrawn back from the external world in order to help the mind in its inner\nquest. This is pratyahara.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is the basis of\nthe path to renunciation. As a bird cannot fly if one of its wings is cut off,\nso is it in the case of the sadhaka. The two wings of yoga are practice, from\nyama to pranayama, and renunciation, from pratyahara to samadhi. Both are\nnecessary for flights. Then the yogi dwells in his soul, perceiving all things\ndirectly, without the intrusion of citta - the conscious faculty.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In ordinary everyday\nlife, consciousness helps the senses see the objects of the world with thoughts\nof acquisition, rejection and resignation. They become hypnotised by them, and\nare drawn outwards, towards pleasure. In pratyahara, the senses are directed\ninwards, towards the realisation of the soul. Pratyahara is the withdrawal of\nthe mind from its contact with the senses of perception and organs of action;\nthen its direction is towards the soul.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The relationship\nbetween the mind and the senses is justly compared to that of bees following\nthe queen bee. If the queen bee moves, the others follow. When she rests, the\nothers rest. They do not function independently from their queen. Similarly, when\nthe mind stops, the senses, too, stop working. This is pratyahara. It is the\nbeginning of man's return journey towards his Maker. It is the science of\nrestricting the senses by depriving them of that that feeds them - the external\nobjective world. It liberates them, by denying the supply of nourishment in the\nform of desires and their fulfilments.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nature consists of five\ngross elements : earth, water, fire, air and ether with their five subtle\ncounterparts : smell, taste, shape, touch and sound. These interact with the\nthree gunas - saliva, rajas and tamas. Citta, comprising ego, intelligence and\nmind is the individual counterpart of mahat, cosmic intelligence. This cosmic\nintelligence is the unevolved primary germ of nature, or the productive\nprinciple, for creation of all phenomena of the material world. There are also\nthe five senses of perception - ears, nose, tongue, eyes and skin - and five\norgans of action - legs, arms, speech and the organs of generation and\nexcretion.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The five senses of\nperception come in contact with sound, smell, taste, sight and touch, send\ntheir impressions to the mind and are stored in the memory. Memory craves for\nfurther experiences and propels the mind to evade intelligence and tap the\nsenses for yet more sense gratification. This in turn motivates the mind to\nseek further experiences through the organs of action. All through this\nprocess, intelligence measures advantages and disadvantages in order to\ncounteract memory, mind and senses which, recollecting the taste of past\npleasures, are passionate for more. Almost inescapably, intelligence stays\ndisregarded. Through over-stimulation and misuse, the organs of action lose\ntheir power and are no longer capable of stimulating the organs of perception\nor the mind.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Owing to the force of\npast impressions, one continues to ache after renewed sensation. But one can\nnever be satiated. This spawns unhappiness and dissatisfaction. Here lies the\ntrue role of pratyahara, the fifth aspect of yoga.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the senses\nwithdraw themselves from the objects and imitate, as it were, the nature of the\nmind-stuff, this is pratyahara.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Withdrawing the senses,\nmind and consciousness from contact with external objects, and then drawing\nthem inwards towards the seer, is pratyahara.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the mind is\nwithdrawn from sense-objects, the sense-organs also withdraw themselves from\ntheir respective objects and thus are said to imitate the mind. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The restraint of senses\noccurs when the mind is able to remain in its chosen direction and the senses\ndisregard the different objects around them and faithfully follow the direction\nof the mind.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the mental organs\nof senses and actions (indriyas) cease to be engaged with the corresponding\nobjects in their mental realm, and assimilate or turn back into the mind-field\nfrom which they arose, this is called pratyahara, and is the fifth step. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pratyahara means\nliterally \u201ccontrol of ahara,\u201d or \u201cgaining mastery over external influences.\u201d It\nis compared to a turtle withdrawing its limbs into its shell \u2014 the turtle's\nshell is the mind and the senses are the limbs. The term is usually translated\nas \u201cwithdrawal from the senses,\u201d At the stage of pratyahara, the consciousness\nof the individual is internalized in order that the sensations from the senses\nof taste, touch, sight, hearing and smell don't reach their respective centers\nin the brain and takes the sadhaka (practitioner) to next stages of Yoga,\nnamely Dharana (concentration) and Dhyana (meditation), and Samadhi (mystical\nabsorption), being the aim of all Yogic practices.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Indriya pratyahara involves\nwithdrawal of senses, or sensory inputs into our physical being, coming from\nour five senses, namely organs creating a sensory overload, and hence hinders\ncollection of the mind, as in Dharana, the next stage of Yoga.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Most of us suffer from\nsensory overload, the result of constant bombardment from television, radio,\ncomputers, newspapers, magazines, books etc. . Our commercial society functions\nby stimulating our interest through the senses. We are constantly confronted\nwith bright colors, loud noises and dramatic brain washing sensations. We have\nbeen raised on every sort of sensory indulgence; it is the main form of\nentertainment in our society.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The problem is that the\nsenses, like untrained children, have their own will, which is largely\ninstinctual in nature. They tell the mind what to do. If we don\u2019t discipline\nthem, they dominate us with their endless demands. We are so accustomed to\nongoing sensory activity that we don\u2019t know how to keep our minds quiet; we\nhave become hostages of the world of the senses and its allurements. We run\nafter what is appealing to the senses and forget the higher goals of life.&nbsp; Pratyahara is an important limb of yoga for\npeople today.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The old saying\n\"the spirit is willing but the flesh is weak\" applies to those of us\nwho have not learned how to properly control our senses. Indriya-pratyahara\ngives us the tools to strengthen the spirit and reduce its dependency on the\nbody. Such control is not suppression (which causes eventual revolt), but\nproper coordination and motivation.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Prana pratyahara- control\nof our senses requires mastery over the flow of prana, as that is what drives\nthe senses. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Unless our prana is\nstrong we will not have the power to control the senses. If our prana is\nscattered or disturbed, our senses will also be scattered and disturbed.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pranayama is a\npreparation for pratyahara. Prana is gathered in pranayama and withdrawn in\npratyahara. Yogic texts describe methods of withdrawing prana from different\nparts of the body, starting with the toes and ending wherever we wish to fix\nour attention \u2014 the top of the head, the third eye, the tip of nose, heart or\none of the other chakras.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">To stop the scattering\nof valuable vital energy of the body or prana, we need to seek control over its\nflow, and harmonize it. This is done through various practices including\nbringing the entire focus to a single point in the body. These two lead to the\nsubsequent two types of pratyahara, the Control of Action or 'Karma\npratyahara', which entails not just control of motor organs, but also right\naction or work, and Karma Yoga, surrender of every action to the divine and\nperforming it as an act of service.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">We cannot control the\nsense organs without also controlling the motor organs. In fact the motor\norgans involve us directly in the external world. The impulses coming in\nthrough the senses get expressed through the motor organs and this drives us to\nfurther sensory involvement. Because desire is endless, happiness consists not\nin getting what we want, but in no longer needing anything from the external\nworld. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Just as the right\nintake of impressions gives control of the sense organs, right work and right\naction gives control of the motor organs. This involves karma yoga \u2014 performing\nselfless service and making our life a sacred ritual. Karma-pratyahara can be\nperformed by surrendering any thought of personal rewards for what we do, doing\neverything as service to God or to humanity. The Bhagavad Gita says, \"Your\nduty is to act, not to seek a reward for what you do.\" This is one kind of\npratyahara. It also includes the practice of austerities that lead to control\nof the motor organs. For example, asana can be used to control the hands and\nfeet, control which is needed when we sit quietly for extended periods of time.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">This leads to the final\nform of pratyahara - the Withdrawal of Mind or 'Mano pratyahara', which is\npracticed by consciously withdrawing attention from anything that is unwholesome,\nand distracting for the mind such as by withdrawing attention from the senses,\nand directing it inwards .&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">We take in sensory\nimpressions only where we place our mind\u2019s attention. In a way we are always\npracticing pratyahara. The mind\u2019s attention is limited and we give attention to\none sensory impression by withdrawing the mind from other impressions. Wherever\nwe place our attention, we naturally overlook other things.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">We control our senses\nby withdrawing our mind\u2019s attention from them. According to this&nbsp; Yoga Sutra: \"When the senses do not\nconform with their own objects but imitate the nature of the mind, that is\npratyahara.\" More specifically, it is mano-pratyahara \u2014 withdrawing the\nsenses from their objects and directing them inward to the nature of the mind,\nwhich is formless. The mind is like the queen bee and the senses are the worker\nbees. Wherever the queen bee goes, all the other bees must follow. Thus\nmano-pratyahara is less about controlling the senses than about controlling the\nmind, for when the mind is controlled, the senses are automatically controlled.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">We can practice\nmano-pratyahara by consciously withdrawing our attention from unwholesome\nimpressions whenever they arise. This is the highest form of pratyahara and the\nmost difficult; if we have not gained proficiency in controlling the senses,\nmotor organs, and pranas, it is unlikely to work. Like wild animals, prana and\nthe senses can easily overcome a weak mind, so it is usually better to start\nfirst with more practical methods of pratyahara.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pratyahara is related\nto all the limbs of yoga. All of the other limbs \u2014 from asana to samadhi \u2014\ncontain aspects of pratyahara. For example, in the sitting poses, which are the\nmost important aspect of asana, both the sensory and motor organs are\ncontrolled. Pranayama contains an element of pratyahara as we draw our\nattention inward through the breath. Yama and niyama contain various principles\nand practices, like non-violence and contentment, that help us control the\nsenses. In other words, pratyahara provides the foundation for the higher\npractices of yoga and is the basis for meditation. It follows pranayama (or\ncontrol of prana) and, by linking prana with the mind, takes it out of the\nsphere of the body.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pratyahara is also\nlinked with dharana. In pratyahara we withdraw our attention from ordinary\ndistractions. In dharana we consciously focus that attention on a particular\nobject, such as a mantra. Pratyahara is the negative and dharana the positive\naspect of the same basic function.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Many of us find that\neven after years of meditation practice we have not achieved all that we expected.\nTrying to practice meditation without some degree of pratyahara is like trying\nto gather water in a leaky vessel. No matter how much water we bring in, it\nflows out at the same rate. The senses are like holes in the vessel of the\nmind. Unless they are sealed, the mind cannot hold the nectar of truth. Anyone\nwhose periods of meditation alternate with periods of sensory indulgence is in\nneed of pratyahara.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pratyahara offers many\nmethods of preparing the mind for meditation. It also helps us avoid environmental\ndisturbances that are the source of psychological pain. Pratyahara is a\nmarvelous tool for taking control of our lives and opening up to our inner\nbeing. It is no wonder some great yogis have called it \"the most important\nlimb of yoga.\" We should all remember to include it in our practice.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">One of the most common\npractices for Pratyahara is Pranayama, wherein we automatically withdraw from\nthe external and bring our focus inwards towards our breath, as connection with\nthe external senses and stimuli are all severed gradually.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">At the advanced levels,\nthe currents which pulsate through the nerves and even the involuntary muscles\nare turned off by the practitioner. This may also be accomplished through\nPranayama or breath-control.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pratyahara or\nabstraction is that by which the senses do not associate with their own objects\nand imitate, as it were, the nature of the mind-stuff (Chitta). The senses are\nassimilated in the mind which is rendered pure through the practice of Yama,\nNiyama and Pranayama. The mind becomes more calm now. The nature of the\nIndriyas is to have always connection with the objects. Where the vision is\nturned outward (Bahirmukha Vritti), the rush of fleeting events engages the mind.\nThe outgoing energies of the mind begin to play. When they are obstructed by\nthe practice of Pratyahara, the other course for them is to mix with the mind\nand to be absorbed in the mind. The mind will not assume any form of any\nobject. Hitherto, the Indriyas were following the mind like the other bees\nwhich follow the queen bee.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pratyahara itself is\ntermed as Yoga, as it is the most important Anga in Yoga Sadhana. This is the\nfifth rung in the Yogic ladder. The first four rungs deal with ethical training\nand purification of body, mind and Nadis. Now with Pratyahara, proper Yoga\nbegins which eventually culminates in Dharana, Dhyana and Samadhi. Hence in\nKathopanishad also in Part VI, Sloka 11, you will find: That firm control of\nthe senses, they regard as Yoga. Again in the same Upanishad it is stated in\nPart IV, Sloka 1: The Self-existent created the senses outgoing, therefore, one\nsees outside and not the Atman within. Some intelligent man, with his senses\nturned away from their object, desirous of immortality, sees the Atman within.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">From the practice of\nPratyahara, comes the supreme mastery over the senses.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Worldly persons enjoy\nwith Raga and Dvesha.The Yogi, will not become a slave of the Vishayas, as he\nis a maaster out of his own free will. The Indriyas cannot grasp the objects\neven though they are placed before them. This is Indriya Jaya. There is a\ndifference between control and supreme control. By controlling one Indriya\nalone, the other four will not come under your control. When the mind is\nrendered pure and one-pointed and when it is turned inwards towards the\nPurusha, then and then alone supreme control of all organs follows. He who has\npractised Pratyahara can have good concentration and meditation. His mind is\nalways peaceful. This demands patience and constant practice. It takes some\nyears before one is well-established in Pratyahara. He who has mastery over\nPratyahara will never complain of Vikshepa or distraction of mind. He can sit\nin a place in a busy city where four roads meet and meditate whenever he likes.\nHe does not want a cave for meditation. Just as the tortoise draws in on all sides\nits limbs, so also, the Yogi withdraws all his senses from the objects of sense\nthrough the practice of Pratyahara. Pratyahara gives power to the practitioner.\nWhen the Indriyas are withdrawn from the objects, then you can fix the mind on\na particular point. Pratyahara and Dharana are interdependent. You cannot\npractise one without the other.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.55- - Tatah parama\nvasyata indriyanam,</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Pratyahara results in\nthe absolute control of the sense organs. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The effect of\npratyahara is felt when the senses are mastered, and the mind is mature and\nfervent for its spiritual quest. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;When\nthe senses have ceased to pursue after pleasures obtained from the phenomenal\nworld, they can be yoked to serve the soul.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sadhana pada instructs\nthe sadhaka how to study his own weaknesses in every domain - moral, physical,\nphysiological and intellectual - and how to eradicate them, since they are not\ncontributory to yogic discipline and spiritual emancipation.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yama germinates the art\nof living in society honestly; niyama, that of cleansing one's impurities.\nAsana eradicates physical and mental disturbances, and pranayama maintains\nharmony and prevents dissipation of the flow of vital energy, making the mind a\nfit instrument for meditation. Pratyahara sublimates both senses and mind.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pratyahara </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">practice when mastered, gives the student\nyogin, the qualification to practice higher yoga, which are mainly actions on\nthe mystic plane.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mastery of the senses\ncomes about by learning to withdraw them.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Through that turning\ninward of the organs of senses and actions (indriyas) also comes a supreme\nability, controllability, or mastery over those senses inclining to go outward\ntowards their objects. Since five senses create sensory overload, Indriya\nPratyahara thwarts the collection in the mind. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Indriyas (senses)\nhave two states, static and dynamic. When the desire begins to operate, the\nIndriyas are put in motion. This is the dynamic state. As soon as the desire is\ngratified, the Indriyas shrink through Tripti (satisfaction). This is the\nstatic or passive state. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Indriya is a\nprolongation of the mind. The sea is fed by the rivers; the sea cannot exist\nwithout the rivers. Even so, mind is fed by Indriyas and cannot exist without\nIndriyas. If you have controlled the Indriyas, you have already controlled the\nmind. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mind is a consolidated\nIndriya. Indriya is mind in manifestation. Just as a minister obeys the king,\nso also, the five Jnana-Indriyas act in accordance with the dictates of the\nmind. Indriyas represent backwaters. The desire in the mind to eat has\nmanifested as tongue, teeth and stomach. The desire in the mind to walk has\nmanifested itself as legs and feet. The desire to keep away from sex ( withhold\nsemen ) </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">can be achieved by the mind. There\nis no need to sleep under the same blanker with two naked underage girls like\nGandhi or </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">give enemas to them. If you\ncan control mind, you can control the Indriyas. Eyes can only see. Ears can\nonly hear. Tongue can only taste. Skin can only touch. Nose can only smell.\nBut, the mind can see, hear, taste, touch and smell. Mind is the common\nsensory. The five senses are blended there. It can directly see, hear, smell, taste\nand feel independent of the senses. It is an aggregate of the five senses. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mind is termed the\nsixth sense: \"Manah shashthanindri-yani-the senses of which mind is the\nsixth\" (Gita, XV-7). The five senses are the five Jnana-Indriyas (organs\nof knowledge, sensation or perception). Ayatana means mind (Chhandogya\nUpanishad, IV-vii) which is the substratum of the experiences of all other\norgans. Senses cannot do anything, if the mind is not connected with them. The\neyes may be wide open during sleep. They do not see anything, because the mind\nis not there. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are six ways of\ncontrolling the Indriyas: (i) through Vichara, (ii) by will-force, (iii) by\nKumbhaka (retention of breath in Pranayama), (iv) by Dama (restraint), (v) by\nPratyahara (abstention) and (vi) by Vairagya and Tyaga. Perfect control can be\nmade only through Vichara. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tapas thins out the\nIndriyas and eventually leads to control of mind. When the Indriyas are\nwithdrawn from their respective objects, it is Indriya-Pratyahara. Mental\nabstraction takes place when the mind is disconnected with the Indriyas.\nPratyahara is a general, broad term which includes Dama also. The effect of\nDama (restraint of Indriyas) is Pratyahara. Pratyahara is the stepping-stone to\ninner spiritual life. He who has succeeded in Pratyahara can concentrate his\nmind quite readily for a very long time. Dharana and Dhyana come automatically\nif Pratyahara is perfect. An aspirant has to struggle hard to have mastery over\nPratyahara. Perfect Vairagya is indispensable for success in Pratyahara. You\ncan succeed after strenuous and incessant struggle for some years. If\nPratyahara is perfect, all the organs are under perfect control. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">If you have the reins of the horses under your\ncontrol, you can have a safe journey. The Indriyas are the horses. If you have\nthe senses under your efficient control, you can have a safe journey in the\npath of Moksha. Indriyas cannot do anything without the help of the mind, their\nmaster and commander. Control of the Indriyas means control of the mind only.\nControl of thoughts leads to the control of mind and Indriyas also. It leads to\nthe attainment of infinite bliss and eternal life. Control of thought is\nindispensable. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the advanced stages, the electrical\ncurrents, which pulsate through the nerves and even the reflex muscles, are\nturned off by the practitioners. This may be achieved through Pranayama.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thus ends the external quest (bahirahga\nsadhana). Now the sadhaka crosses the threshold of the internal quest\n(antarahga sadhana) of yoga. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Here ends the\nexposition on sadhana, the second pada of Patanjali's Yoga Sutras.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-rJ2j04ss6nk/V599iyGaXyI/AAAAAAABLN8/KbyzTn3kY4YCblMoWDw3RSxYjEbqB8oEgCLcB/s1600/Eight%2BLimbs%2BbJPEG.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"492\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-rJ2j04ss6nk/V599iyGaXyI/AAAAAAABLN8/KbyzTn3kY4YCblMoWDw3RSxYjEbqB8oEgCLcB/s640/Eight%2BLimbs%2BbJPEG.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>VIBHUTI PADA- CHAPTER 3</b></span><br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">3.01\u2014 deshabandhashchittasya\ndharana</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Fixing the\nconsciousness on one point or region is concentration (dharana). </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dharana means focus of\nattention. Centreing the attention on a chosen point or area, within or outside\nthe body, is concentration. By it the functions of the mind are checked and\nbrought to one focal point. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Once mastery of the\nfive stages of yoga from yama to pratyahara is achieved, the art of focusing\nthe mind and consciousness is guaranteed. Dharana is established when the mind\nlearns to remain steady on its own, or hold on to an unmoving object.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Through the practice of\nyama and niyama, the sadhaka develops emotional firmness. Through asana, he\nkeeps his body, the abode of the soul, free from disease. In pranayama, he\nlearns to stop the dispersion of energy by regularising its flow for proper\ndistribution all through his body and mind. Through pratyahara, he develops\nwill-power, detaches himself from the organs of senses and acquires precision\nin thought.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is the beginning\nof culturing the brain. Once he has become unresponsive to worldly matters, he\nis fit to continue on the inner quest, enriching the mind through dharana.\nDhyana and samadhi lead the consciousness on the innermost quest (amaratma\nsadhana), to the soul itself.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The eight components of\nastahga yoga are interwoven, though each is delineated individually for the\nsake of convenience. They are subdivided into the external quest (bahiranga\nsadhana), the internal quest (antarahga sadhana) and the innermost quest\n(antaratma sadhana), which facilitates even the naive to learn to concentrate,\nstep by step, on concrete forms by systematic practice. Having readied maturity\nand refinement, they are able to fathom their inmost thoughts and feelings. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Most people, even most\nyoga practicians, are under the impression that asanas are only external and\nphysical. This sutra removes that misapprehension. Patanjali defines\nconcentration as the centering of attention either within or outside the body.\nIf, in performing an asana, one directs the organs of action and senses of\nperception towards the mind, and the mind towards the core, external sadhana is\ntransformed into internal sadhana. If the limbs, the senses of perception, the\nmind and the discriminative intelligence are then repressed and merged with the\nenergy of the soul, this becomes the innermost sadhana. If one performs each\nasana passionately, blending with integrated attention every part of the body,\nthe digressing mind and the discriminative intelligence with the soul\nconstitutes spiritual practice. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In asana, the initial\ncommitment or passion lifts itself, through concentration, to the level of\ntotal absorption. Such practice brings modesty, without which dissemination of\nthe subtle levels is impossible. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dharana is the art of\nreducing the disturbances of the mind and ultimately eliminating them entirely,\nso that the knower and the known become one.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dharana may be focused\non external or internal objects. External objects should be auspicious and\nassociated with transparency. Internally, the mind penetrates the soul, the\ncore of one's being - the object is, in reality, pure existence.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">For higher meditation,\neverything is within the mental and emotional energy fields.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The paradox of it is this: the very&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">same mental and\nemotional energy which caused us to become attached to this world, can also&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">in turn, cause\nliberation. The gate for exiting this world is in the same mento-emotional\nenergy&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">(cittasya).&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Concentration (dharana)\nis holding the mind within a center of spiritual consciousness in the body, or\nfixing it on some divine form, either within the body or outside it.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The mind has reached\nthe ability to be directed [dharana] when direction toward a chosen object is\npossible in spite of many other potential objects within the reach of the\nindividual.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">A perennial flow of\ndharana is called dhyana or meditation. If dharana is the drop, dhyana is the\nriver. Many concentrations make a meditation. Qualitatively they are non-different,\nbut functionally there is a distinction between them.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the student enters\ninto dharana, he can know something of his personal structure. He becomes an\nobserver of himself and an object of his study.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The rationale behind\nthe practice of dharana has been earlier explained under the context of\npratyahara. The reason behind the effort at concentration of mind is the same\nas that underlying the need for pratyahara. It is a psychological necessity\nwith a deep philosophical background. Unless the 'why' of concentration is\nproperly answered, one will not have satisfaction within and hence cannot take\nto the practice wholeheartedly. Concentration is the channelizing of the chitta\nor the psychic structure within towards universality of being. This goal is\nachieved by many stages, with a graduated movement of the finite to the\ninfinite.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sincere effort is\nnecessary on the path to keep the mind in balance; for balance is yoga. It is\nonly when the balance is upset, due to some factor in life, that worry sets in.\nHence, the first step in yoga is not pratyahara or dharana, but a psychological\ndisentanglement, or a stock-taking as people do in business, and a striking of\nthe balance-sheet of the inner world. One has to find out where one stands.\nYoga is a positive state, different from all moods of the day. There is nothing\nof the negative in the yoga way of life, neither in the mind nor in the\nperspective of one's vision. Misgivings about yoga are due to a want of proper\nunderstanding of its meaning. All anguish is to be set right. How to do this is\na personal problem. It has to be dealt with on an individual consideration, as\nthe answer varies from person to person. Just as a physician does not treat\npatients collectively but pays them all individual attention, each question has\nto be taken separately and solved, unless they are all of a similar character.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yoga techniques are\nbased on natural laws of universal application and not on dogmatic or religious\nbeliefs.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It need not be\nemphasized that a Guru is necessary, and also one should be capable of\npracticing sense-control, especially sex-control. Treading the path of yoga\nalways implies some loss in the eyes of the sense-world. The student should\ndecide what he wants. Does he want comfort, praise, name and fame, etc., or is\nhe honest in pursuing the way of self-restraint , concentration of mind and\ndeep inner bliss ? </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Concentration of mind\nhas much to do with inner satisfaction, there cannot be concentration of mind\nwhen there is unhappiness. An unhappy man cannot be a student of yoga. We do yoga\nbecause there is something substantial and positive in yoga.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Psychological\ncontentment brought about by self-analysis is a great help in concentration.\nSometimes, when one is affected too much by thoughts of the contrary, thoughts\npertaining to things and conditions opposed to or different from the aim of\nyoga, Patanjali says that one has to practice thinking or the feeling of the\nopposite (pratipaksha-bhavana). This is to affirm the opposite of what is\nhappening. If a particular sense-organ is troubling the student, he gives\nintense work to the other organs so that the energy will be drawn by them, and\nthe troublesome element is divested of strength. If one is sexually agitated\none might think of Bhishma . The desire would slowly wane because of the higher\nthought occurring to the mind by continued contemplation. Daily practice will\ncreate in the mind samskaras or impressions which will in course of time\nprevent the rise of such negative thoughts and, even if they come, they will\nnot be vehement or powerful enough to disturb internal peace. This is the\nmethod of 'substitution' </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">which was\nlifted and patented by Western thieves </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">as psychoanalysis.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The three methods which\nthe mind employs usually are repression, substitution and sublimation.\nSublimation is the proper course to adopt, but it cannot always be done for\nobvious reasons. People repress desires into the subconscious due to social\ntaboo, but later on this causes complexities. Repression is not a remedy.\nGandhi achieved SHIT by sleeping under the blanket with underage girls </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">and giving/ taking enemas from them. When one\ncannot fulfil one's desires, one swallows them, which, in the long run, become\ncomplexes that may turn into illness of various kinds. Nothing inspires\nmurderous mayhem in human beings more reliably than sexual repression.If\nexpression of sexuality is thwarted, the human psyche tends to grow twisted\ninto grotesque, enraged perversions of desire. We know what the sexually\nrepressed Catholic clergy does, right ? We know how many billions of dollars\nthe pope has shelled out to buy silence.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">There's little question\nthat the centuries-long campaign of child rape enabled by</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">institutional cover-up is a direct result of\nthe Church's inhumane teachings concerning human sexuality. If Catholic priests\nwere allowed to form erotic connections of our wedlock or even with consenting\nadults, who can doubt that countless children would have been spared outrageous\ntorture at the hands of these sick, distorted men?</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Suppression of core emotions and the denial\nof their resolution in healthy society accepted love always always leads to\npersonal distortion, &nbsp;</span><span style=\"line-height: 24px;\">compulsion</span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;and loss of&nbsp;perspective.&nbsp;</span></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The moods of people are\nnothing but the occasional eruption of repressed emotions and attitudes.\nRepression is not the method prescribed by Patanjali, though he suggests\nsubstitution as a middle course leading to sublimation by yoga.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Before starting the\npractice of concentration, the student has to establish a proper relation with\nthe world and society by the practice of the yamas and niyamas. If the world is\nup in debauchery , </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">arms and cudgels, one\ncannot practice yoga by being in it. For peace with the world and peace with\noneself, Patanjali prescribes the yamas and niyamas, respectively. Asana and\npranayama are intended for establishing peace and harmonious relations with the\nmuscles, nerves and the vital force. Pratyahara establishes peace with the\nmind. Yoga is the science of peace. The world outside having been properly\ncoordinated with our personality by the yamas and our having come to proper\nunderstanding of ourselves by the niyamas and by vichara or self-analysis,\nhaving also achieved some sort of control over the muscles by asana, the nerves\nand prana by pranayama, having brought compromise within by pratyahara, the\nstudent is face to face with the problem of concentration.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">What is one to\nconcentrate upon? First of all, the point of concentration has to be external,\nso that one may concentrate with greater ease, because the mind has always a\ntendency to go outward. But this need not mean going senseward. We may give the\nmind some freedom, of course, but it should be within a limited circle. The\nambit of the activity of the mind should gradually become smaller and smaller.\nOne moves, but in more and more limited circles. The circle of the mind's work\nbecomes smaller as it rises to higher states of concentration. In the most\ninitial stage, the student can concentrate on any one point. A wide leash is\ngiven in the beginning as is done with a wild animal under training.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Satsanga and svadhyaya\nare some of the methods which one can adopt in limiting the activity of the\nmind to smaller circles. Instead of going to any place at leisure, one attends\nSatsangas or visits holy places or shrines. And instead of browsing through all\nsorts of sick and dirty literature </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">one\nreads philosophical and elevating scriptures. All this is an achievement in the\nconcentration of mind by way of limitation of the circle of its activity.\nInstead of chatting with persons at any time, one restricts speech only to a\nnecessity. The long leash has been cut short. The radius has been reduced in\nlength. This practice is the beginning of a true religious life. Having lived a\nlife of religiousness rather than that of worldliness one further tries to\nlimit the circle of the mind in yoga. And now, the stage has come when, instead\nof going to holy places, one settles down in one place for a spiritual way of\nliving, and one has pinned the mind to a still smaller circle. Having settled\nin a particular place, one chalks out a daily programme which should be such\nthat it will not contain any item that is not directly connected with the\npractice of yoga. Occasionally, a few may be indirectly related, which,\nhowever, are to be slowly snapped later by gradual effort and only the direct\nconnections with yoga be maintained. The programme of the day which the student\nchalks out for himself depends entirely upon the aim of yoga, which is the\ndetermining factor in the day's programme. What he will do during the whole day\nwill depend on what he wishes to make of his entire life, for many days put\ntogether constitute life. The daily programme should therefore correspond to\nthe life's programme. Nothing non-spiritual may engage the attention of the\nstudent on any occasion. In the programme of the day, certain items should be\nessential, such as study of scriptures (which one cannot dispense with until\none gets so absorbed in the mind that there is no need for any study). Sacred\nstudy is necessary because in such study one keeps oneself open to higher\nthoughts, ennobling one's character. Simultaneously with this practice, there\nshould be recourse to japa (repetition) of the mantra (mystic formula). Japa is\ndirectly connected with dhyana. The relation between svadhyaya, japa and dhyana\nis sequential and very significant and they form a complete course of yoga.\nJapa is a more intensive sadhana than svadhyaya and dhyana more intensive than\njapa.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dharana, dhyana and\nsamadhi are considered as the internal and true yoga, while everything else is\nan external accessory to it. Yama, niyama, asana, pranayama and pratyahara\nconstitute the external (bahiranga) yoga, while dharana, dhyana and samadhi are\nthe internal (antaranga) yoga. The internal yoga is a pure activity of the\nmind-stuff (antahkarana), independent of the senses. While the senses had a\npart to play in pratyahara, they do not operate in dharana, any further. We have\ncome nearly to the innermost point of the personality and the outer activities\nas well as relations are given up. The mind has become powerful because now it\ndoes not waste energy through sensory activity. Most people complain that the\nmind is weak, that the will has no strength, because much of the energy leaks\nout through the channels of the senses. The senses are factors of dissipation\nof the centralized energy in the human system and until this channelization of\nenergy by way of sensory activity is stopped, the will would remain naturally\nweak and this is why so much emphasis is laid on the control of senses. The\nmind which conserves energy in itself becomes more powerful than it appeared\nearlier. It is now ready to gird up its loins for the ultimate steps in yoga,\nconcentration and meditation. It has nothing to vex it, because it has severed\nall its connections outside by an inner withdrawal. Concentration now begins.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Concentration does not\ncome suddenly, in spite of all efforts on the part of a student. The mind has\nbeen habituated to think in terms of diversity and to turn it away from\nmultitudinousness and to bring it to a point is really hard to achieve. The\nmind does not accept it. In the beginning, there is repulsion and later on\nthere arises difficulty in the practice of concentration. But if the practice\ngoes on with proper self-analysis and understanding, the mind will be able to\nappreciate what it is for and what it is expected to do. Any unintelligent\nactivity is not easily taken in by the mind because thought is logically\nconstructed. Before making preparations for chalking out a programme one should\ntry to be methodical and logical in thinking, for the mind will not accept\nchaotic ideas. It appreciates only system, symmetry, harmony, beauty, order,\netc. The mind dislikes any thing thrown pell-mell, because it is made in an\norderly fashion. Without knowing the why of it one does not like anything\nspontaneously. The way in which the mind functions is what is known as logic.\nOne should not hastily move to things and jump into any conclusion. Many people\nsuffer from this travesty, because they cannot take all aspects of the matter\ninto their judgements. All persons cannot consider every side of an issue, and\nthis pinches the mind from various directions. A programme that one may have to\nchange constantly is not a well-thought-out programme. Let there be no need to\nchange what one has decided to do. Let it be thought and arranged well, even if\nit would take many days to make the decision. Let there be beauty in thinking,\nas there is beauty in the outer world. The more is one logical, the more is\nalso one's happiness. Hence, it is necessary to prepare the ground with a\nthorough-going analysis of the situation of one's personality. 'I want God',\nshould not be the student's sudden answer when he is asked what he is up to\nachieve.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Logical thinking is,\ntherefore, a help in bringing about concentration of mind. The test of\nlogicality in thought is that one feels a delight the moment one arranges one's\nthoughts in a method. One feels a comfort within because of the completeness\nintroduced by the system of logic in the mind. Logicality is a form of\npsychological perfection, and all perfection is joy.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">After having properly\nthought out the programme for life and for the day, the programme of one's\nsadhana has to be considered. 'What is my sadhana going to be?' Thus may the\nstudent of yoga cogitate seriously. Merely because one has heard a lecture on\nyoga, it does not mean one has a clear path set before oneself. After much\nhearing, there may still remain some fundamental difficulty, that of choosing a\nproper method of practice and coming to facts, not merely doctrines. When one\ntouches the practical side, an unforeseen problem arises. This is an individual\ndifficulty and cannot be cleared in a public lecture. It is, therefore,\nnecessary to find out one's temperament, first, and decide upon the nature of\none's case. In as much as every mind is special in its constitution, proclivity\nand temperament certain details peculiar to one's mind have to be thought out\nclearly for oneself. Though it is true that concentration is the purpose of all\nsadhana, the kind of preparation for this concentration varies in different\ntypes of yoga. Concentration is an impersonal action of the mind, because, in\nthis inner adventure, the mind attempts gradually to shed its personality by\naccommodating itself, stage by stage, with the requirements of the law that\ndetermines the universe.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Patanjali, in his\naphorisms on yoga, has suggested varieties of concentration of the mind on\npoints which can be external, internal or universal. A protracted and\nintensified form of concentration is called meditation.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The sixth limb of yoga,\ndharana, is referred to as \u201cconcentration.\u201d It\u2019s a limb that can get overlooked\nas either unimportant or too difficult to bother with, especially since its\nfuller, less tangible translation is \u201cthe binding of the mind to one place,\nobject or idea.\u201d This conjures up images of master yogis staring at objects\nuntil they\u2019re \u201cone\u201d with them. And while there can be some truth to this\nscenario, it\u2019s not entirely accurate. Dharana, in reality, is one of the most\nimportant parts of yoga there is, and learning how to practice it (because it\nis definitely a practice) may be one of the most worthwhile things we can do\nfor our brains.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is party because\ndharana and the next limb of yoga \u2013 dhyana, or meditation \u2013 are two sides of the\nsame coin. Conceptually they can be separated, but in practice, that makes less\nsense. Dharana, at its very heart, can be thought of as the work it takes \u2013 the\npractice \u2013 to get your mind to the point where it\u2019s ready for meditation. So\ndharana isn\u2019t so much the state of concentration, but it\u2019s more the act of\nbrining your \u201cmonkey mind\u201d back to whatever it is you\u2019re focusing on. Again,\nand again, and again.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Many yogis say that for\nbeginners, choosing a thing to focus on, rather than an idea, is the way to go.\nThe object can be a physical object, the breath, or an oral mantra. The idea is\njust to have something outside yourself that serves as a point to draw the\nattention toward. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">If you\u2019re not using a\nmantra, though, and you\u2019re practicing concentration with an image or an object,\nthe most important thing to remember is that the goal is in the practice. The\npractice of dharana is not concentrating on a object \u2013 it\u2019s the act of redirecting\nthe mind, again and again. This very practice itself is called concentration:\nthe mind running, your bringing it back; its running, your bringing it back.\nYou are taming a monkey. Once it\u2019s tamed, it will just listen to you.. Training\nyour mind to meditate is what is called dharana.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dharana can help us\nwith our focus in any walk of life, not just when we sit down to meditate. Concentration\ngets easier as you practice it. It\u2019s joyous to concentrate on something,\nthere\u2019s pleasure in it. When you get familiar with dharana, the mind becomes a\nmuch less restless place to be.\u201d&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">While describing the\neight aspects (angas) of Ashtang Yoga, Patanjali has stated Dharana, Dhyana and\nSamadhi as the last three aspects. It is also stated by him that all the three\naspects are collectively termed as \" Sanyam\" (Control). This implies\nthat all the three aspects should be considered together. We should also bear\nin mind while studying that Dharana, Dhyana and Samadhi are progressively\nadvanced stages of concentration. The highest stage of mental concentration\ndescribed by the modern psychologists is more or less similar to the\ndescription of Dharana i.e. the primary stage of concentration as described by\nPatanjali. This indicates the thoughtfulness of Patanjali while describing the\nthree stages.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Another characteristic\nof these three stages is that there is no dividing line in between these\nstages. When certain progress is made in the studies of Dharana, Dhyana stage\nis automatically entered into and with the progress in Dharana stage, Sadhaka\nautomatically enters in the Samadhi stage. The three stages mingle into each\nother as easily as three colours are mixed into each other on the canvass of an\nartist.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Patanjali has stated the\ndefinition of Dharana in this sutra.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Patanjali states the\npreliminary process of Dharana, a primary step in the lengthy process of\ncontrolling the mind. The restriction put on the mind is known as\n\"Alamban\". With the help of the \"Alamban\", the mind is\nfixed and engaged in a particular area.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The study of Dharana is\nthe study of concentration of mind. Hence, certain preliminary preparations are\nnecessary. We get various perceptions, through the five sensory organs. The\nmind usually runs behind such sensory perceptions. To stabilise the mind,\nattention has to be paid as to how these perceptions can be reduced. The\nsurroundings should be pleasurable to the mind and not repulsive or\ntroublesome. There should not be any external disturbances. The general chaos,\nother sounds, strong breeze, different smells, extremely bright light are\nvarious disturbances that should be avoided. When these are removed, the\ncauses, which seek the attention of the mind, get reduced. Then one should sit\non a comfortable seat in a pose conducive to Dhyana such as Padmasan,\nSwatikasan or Siddhasan. One should have the practice of sitting firmly, yet\ncomfortably in a particular pose for a longer duration. Otherwise, the mind\nwill get diverted towards the signals from various muscles. The pose should be \"samkay\nshirogreevam\" and the eyes should be fixed on the picture of OM in the\nfront. The picture should be at the eye level and placed under sufficient\nlight. Whenever the eyes try to avert itself beyond the picture, an effort\nshould be made to lock it on the picture again. The mind generally follows the\neyesight, so fixing of the gaze will result in locking the mind too. Start the\nJapa of OM with calm attitude. The way with which the sound of OM is emitted\nthrough the mouth should be gradual and effective. The vocal cords or the lungs\nshould not feel strained while doing the japa. The japa is automatically heard\nby the ears and as such again felt by the mind. Thus, the mind will be firmly\nkept onto the OM.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Out of five sensory\norgans, the eyes, the tongue and the ears are concentrating on only one subject\nof OM, so the mind, which runs after the sensory perceptions, will also be\nfirmly engaged on OM. Here, Om is an \"alamban\" and the dimension\ncovered by Om is the restricted area in which the mind can move (deshbandh).\nAfter some period, stop the japa, close the eyes and try to concentrate the\nmind on the memories of OM sensed through the gaze, the tongue and the ears.\nThis experience transcends the sensory organs and the engagement of mind in\nthis is the real dharana. While practising this, the mind may sway beyond the experience\ntowards other things. This discontinues the dharana. Then the mind has to be\nbrought again into the experience. There will be several disturbances; however\nwith practice, they get reduced. The concentration without any disturbances is\ndharana. In that stage, there is no other experience than the\n\"Alamban\". It is a soothing, pleasurable stage giving intense\nsatisfaction and peace of mind. When Dharana is practised for half an hour or\nso, the stage is experienced only for a few minutes, the other moments spent in\ncontrolling the wandering mind. However, with continuous practice, the duration\nof the pleasurable stage increases and the sadhaka becomes prepared to enter\ninto the next stage. With further practice, the area of the \"alamban\"\nor its limits is to be reduced. With the reduction of the area, the dharana\nwill be more effective and the sadhaka will get nearer to the next stage of\ndhyana.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">If the\n\"Alamban\" is subject of only one sensory organ, then the other organs\nwill choose their own subjects and try to pull the mind towards them. This will\nmake mind unsteady further. All this should be considered while choosing the\nsubject of the \"alamban\".&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dharana is the stage of\nhigh concentration of the mind. The modern psychologists have described the\nhighest stage of concentration of the human mind.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The mind is kept firm\nat one place instead of letting it wander here and there. This reduces strain\non the mind. The mental strength increases. The daily practice of dharana\nreduces the wavering attitude of mind and a different kind of peace can be\nobserved throughout the day.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The last three rungs of\nYoga: Dharana (concentration), dhyana (meditation), and samadhi are the final\nthree rungs of Yoga.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dharana is concentration\nis the process of holding or fixing the attention of mind onto one object or place.&nbsp; Dhyana or meditation is sustained\nconcentration, whereby the attention continues to hold or repeat the same\nobject or place. Samadhi is the deep absorption, wherein only the essence of\nthat object, place, or point shines forth in the mind, as if the mind were devoid\neven of its own form.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is attention itself,\nwhich is progressively moving inward through these few stages:&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Attention leads to\nconcentration (dharana). Concentration leads to meditation (dhyana). Meditation\nleads to absorption (samadhi).</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dharana means \u2018focused\nconcentration\u2019. Dha means \u2018holding or maintaining\u2019, and Ana means \u2018other\u2019 or\n\u2018something else\u2019.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Each limb of the Eight\nlimbs of Yoga prepares us for the next. Whereas Pratyahara teaches us to\nwithdraw our focus from the external to the internal, the practice of Dharana\nteaches us to \u2018zoom in\u2019 so we\u2019re able to focus on one thing alone.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">This, of course, is not\nan easy thing to do! Most of us have experienced what we call in yoga the\n\u2018monkey mind\u2019 - restless thoughts jumping around like clamorous monkeys leaping\nfrom from tree to tree - so it takes some discipline and patience to learn how\nto focus our attention on a single thing.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It\u2019s impossible to\n\u2018empty\u2019 the mind but we can train it to become so completely and utterly\nabsorbed with one thing that we lose all sense of time and space and most\nsignificantly, Self.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">We all had the\nexperience of \u2018losing track of time\u2019 because we\u2019ve been immersed in something that\nhas held our undivided attention.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Often these moments are\nentirely unplanned.. One minute we\u2019re tackling the task at hand, the next, 3\nhours have flown by and we don\u2019t know where the time went. However, it\u2019s often\nwhen we consciously set out to focus our attention while sitting quietly that\nthe mind decides it doesn\u2019t want to play ball.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mantra chanting is a helpful\npractices of Dharana.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">One-pointed focused\nconcentration needs intention, relaxation, softness, and ease - and for these\nto arise, we also need patience and practice.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Antar darshan is a\npractice of pratyahara. Pratya comes from the word pratyaya. Pratyaya are the\ninternal seeds, the basic tendencies in our nature which are there from birth\nto death. They are the basis of our personality. The word ahara means food or\nnutrition. Normally in our day-to-day lives, we are concentrated and\nextroverted in the outside world, so the mind, the senses and the pratyaya,\nthese internal tendencies and seeds of consciousness, are receiving nutrition\nfrom outside, from objects, events, situations and interactions in the external\nworld. So, pratyahara means a practice which internalizes the senses and the\nmind so that the mind begins to receive its nutrition from within. The pratyaya\nbegin to receive nutrition from within. &nbsp;&nbsp;This is the first stage in mental training,\nwhen we can learn to internalize the senses and the mind at will.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pratyahara is not just\none practice but a series of practices which aid the mind to complete this\nprocess and to be able to internalize at will. Perhaps at some point we will be\nable to internalize and externalize at the same time. This is total perfection\nof this stage, where we are aware internally and externally at the same time.\nRight now, however, we are only aware outside, and when we are aware outside\nthen we are not aware inside. Sometimes we shut it all off, we go into a room\nand put on some music, or we sit in a chair, close our eyes, relax and go\ninside. Then we become aware inside, depending on the degree to which we have\ndeveloped. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pratyahara means to go\ninside but to keep the awareness at the conscious level, around the level of\nmanas. In the stage of pratyahara we are not attempting to go deep. Only when\nwe have mastered pratyahara will we begin to dip into chitta, the subconscious\nmind. Dipping into the subconscious mind while we are still awake is actually\nan achievement. This can be done when the mind is in the alpha mode.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When we practise\nmeditation techniques, beginning with pratyahara, we gain the ability to go\ninto this subconscious dimension consciously. This will come only in the last\nstages of pratyahara, not in the beginning. In the early stages we try to work\non developing our internal conscious state and becoming aware of what is\nhappening in manas. Watching the thoughts, watching the emotions, seeing how\nthey interrelate, how a thought engenders an emotion and how that emotion\nengenders another emotion.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is the stage where\nthe practice of antar darshan comes in. Antar darshan is not a kind of\nrebirthing technique where you go very deep into your subconscious and\nunconscious emotions and try to bring them up. That practice comes later when\nwe have mastered and understood exactly what is happening at the conscious\nlevel. We have to clean out the area where we live \u2013 our bedroom, the living\nroom, the sadhana room, the workplace. We do not try to clean out the attic or\nthe cellar first; we have to start where we are.
