, &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tatra dhyanajam\nanashayam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">karmashuklakrishnnam\nyoginah trividham itaresham<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tatastadvipakanugunanam\nevabhivyaktirvasananam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">jatideshakalavyavahitanam\napyanantaryamsmritisanskarayoh ekaroopatvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tasam anaditvam\nchashisho nityatvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">hetufalashrayalambanaih\nsangrihitatvad eshamabhave tadabhavah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">atitanagatan\nsvaroopatostyadhvabhedad<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">te vyaktasookshma\ngunatmanah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">parinamaikatvad\nvastutattvam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">vastusamye chittabhedat\ntayorvibhaktah panthah <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">taduparagapekshatvat\nchittasya vastu jnatajnatam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">sada jnatashchittavrittayastatprabhohpurushasyaparinamitvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">na tat\nsvabhasandrishyatvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">ekasamaye\nchobhayanavadharannam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">chittantaradrishye\nbuddhibuddheratiprasanggah smritisankarashcha<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">chiterapratisankramayastadakarapattausvabuddhisanvedanam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">drashtridrishyoparaktan\nchittan sarvartham<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tadasankhyeyavasanachitram\napi pararthan sanhatyakaritvat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">visheshadarshin\naatmabhavabhavanavinivrittih<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tada vivekanimnan\nkaivalyapragbharan chittam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tachchhidreshu\npratyayantarani sanskarebhyah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">hanam esham\nkleshavaduktam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">prasankhyanepyakusidasy\nsarvathavivekakhyaterdharmameghah samadhih<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tatah\nkleshakarmanivrittih<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tada\nsarvavarannamalapetasyjnanasyaanantyajgyeyam alpam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">tatah kritarthanan\nparinamakramapari samaptirgunanam<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">kshannapratiyogi\nparinamaparantanigrarhyah kramah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">purusharthashoonyanan\ngunanan pratiprasavahkaivalyan, svaroopapratishtha va chitishaktireti<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">2.44\u2014 svadhyayad\nishtadevatasanprayogah<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Self-study leads\ntowards the realisation of God or communion with one's desired deity.&nbsp;</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The word\n\"ishta\" means desired or preferred and \"devata\" means a\ndeity. Ishta Devata thus refers to one\u2019s deity of choice.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ishta devata deity can\nbe visualized when a mantra to the deity is chanted with total devotion and\nardor.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red;\">The necessity to\nvisualise God as an object, or an ishta devata, arises on account of the\n</span><span style=\"color: red;\">difficulty of the mind in transcending space and time ( mere Sanskrit language knowing halfwit indophiles wont understand quantum physics inherent in Vedas) .</span> Halfwits cannot understand this concept.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In Hinduism we are given\na free choice on what we want to focus our mind on . We are not armtwisted to\nfocus our mind on a man bleeding to death on a cross.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Muslims make fun of\nHindus as being idol worshippers. What do they know ? </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Allah is a straight lift from brahmAn. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ishta Devta can be find\nout from your horoscope alone. Though in modern times ishtadevata is your free\nchoice.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ishta devata\nbecomes, for our purposes, a conceptual ideal that we have placed before us, on\nwhich we foist all the greatest qualities of God. We consider the ishta devata\nas an all-pervading essence concretised in one form.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Shallow minded people who do not understand\nthe essense of meditation , will never understand why Hindus worhsip idols,\nthough our god is brahmAn ( the morphogenetic consciousness field ) which\ncannot be picked up by the 5 senses . Kula Devata is the God/Goddess worshipped\nby the family, by tradition. This Kula Devata is the God to whom the family\nwould do prayer before any auspicious occasion is done at home: like marriage,\nupanayan sanskar etc. Kula Devata cannot be substituted by Ishta Devata as\nIshta Devata can be specific to each person, even in a family. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ishta Devata is the personal Deity who will\nguide the soul to its real home- Moksha. You need to necessarily search through\nyour aged relatives to find the Kula Devata.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">An ishta devata is our\nown God, whom we worship and adore.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Though\ntheoretically it is conceded that God is everywhere, the mind cannot conceive\nthis everywhereness. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even when we agree\nthat God is everywhere, the idea of God being everywhere will be a kind of\nexternalisation of form. Even if we think of God as the universal Virat\nHimself, when we think of the Virat, He will appear to be an object which we\nare cognising.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Remembering the deity\nand internally building a relationship with (or through) them is considered essential\nto the yogic practise. Within the Advaita schools it is held that the human\nmind needs a concrete form to understand the divine that ultimately can never\nbe defined. Just as one can understand the abstract concept of a color only\nafter one has seen a concrete form, one can only realize the deity through a\nform of murti. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The advaita god of\nbrahmAn cannot be picked up by the 5 human senses.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The immoral white\ninvader used this Ishta devata concept to drive wedges. They made devotees of\nVishnu and Shiva fight and abuse each other using the FAKE and backdated mutts.\nHindus must know that the TRINITY works in tandem and in harmony.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Typically a practitioner worships their\nIshta-Deva through the form of a murti. This worship may involve offering items\nwhile in a grateful disposition to their chosen divinity such as incense or\nflowers, reciting mantras, singing their names and offering prayers.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mantra sadhana done\nwith faith and intensity leads to ishta devata samprayogah, which means that\nthe ishta devata appears before the sadhaka in a human form, a sound vibration\nor a light.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Svadhyaya has been\nmentioned twice in the sutras, first in sutra 2.1 as part of Kriya Yoga and\nlater on as one of the five niyamas. Since the practice of Svadhyaya brings one\nface to face with their deity of choice, it means that the practicing yogi is\nexpected to have an ishta-devata.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Though consciousness\nsurvives within the body, it needs to be knocked by the practice of yoga asana\nand pranayama, wherein the intelligence acts as a bridge to connect awareness\nof the body with the core and vice versa. This connecting intelligence alone\nbrings harmony of body, mind and soul, and intimacy with the Supreme Soul\n(Istadevata). </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Traditionally, svadhyaya\nhas been explained as the study of the sacred scriptures and recitation mantra,\nthrough which the sadhaka earns a vision of his tutelary or chosen divinity,\nwho meets each of his wants.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Svadhyaya\nis the study of scriptures and also practicing our individual sadhana\n(spiritual pursuit) that we have been initiated into. Through this practice we\ncan get a \"darshan\" or a vision of our own deity of choice. Every\nmantra that we chant is usually identified with a deity and through intense\nsadhana, the deity may appear in human form or in the form of light or a sound.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Svadhyaya literally means self-study but also\nrefers to study of sacred texts. In Vedic times, it involved recitation of\nvedic hymns until memorized.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">OM has been referred to\nas the representative sound for Ishvara (sutra 1.27), it is apparent that\nPatanajli is referring to Ishvara and its manifest forms as ishta devatas.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When we surrender to God, we essentially\nbecome free of material possessions and thus free of any worries. This leads us\nto an attitude of detachment which is a requirement for the state of Samadhi.\nSamadhi means tranquility of mind which is achieved when we dedicate everything\nto God and are free of attachments.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Of all the attainments\nmentioned in the sutras which result from practicing the various yamas and\nniyamas, it is only through the practice of Ishvara-pranidhana that samadhi,\nthe goal of yoga, can be attained. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">As we\nrecall, in sutra 2.1, Ishvara-pranidhana is mentioned as a part of Kriya Yoga,\nand now again it is mentioned as one of the five niyamas. Even though in\nchapter 1 on Samadhi Pada, Ishvara-pranidhana was mentioned as one of the\noptions to attain peace of mind. However, in chapter 2, Patanjali makes it a\nrequirement if we want to follow the eight limbs of yoga.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ultimate goal of\nyoga is realization of atman (individual soul) as a part of brahmAn, the mother\nfield. In the Bhagavad Gita, Arjuna asks Krishna as to which of two paths is\nsuperior \u2013 the path of knowledge based on the imperishable, unmanifest or the\npath of devotion (shloka 12.1). Krishna states that even though one can attain\nliberation using the former path, but that path is difficult to follow. He adds\nthe one following the path of devotion is the best among the yogis.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even though Patanjali\u2019s\nmain focus is calming the mind and realization of brahmAn, he has given ample\nevidence of the use of bhakti (devotion) as a means to that attainment.</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Svadhyayam is the\nexercise of the self, by the self, and for the self as in exercises at the end\nof chapters in technical textbooks. Aspects of the phenomenal universe as\napprehended are exercised through the model of the cognitive process. The three\nfundamental questions are 1) how do I happen to be aware of this now?, 2) why\ndoes it appear to me in this way instead of another way?, and 3) what about me\nthat latches on to this particular manifestation? &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The phenomenal universe\nis surrendered to Ishvara who will present the impression of the\nundifferentiated subject to a clear mind. When one experiences who the subject\nis one is distanced from the body which feels pain and suffering.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The following five\npoints emerge regarding the meaning, sadhana and outcome of swadhyaya:--&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Study of scriptures,&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Study of one\u2019s own self,&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mantra japa,&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some form of meditation\npractice,&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Attainment of the ishta\ndevata..</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The study of sacred\nscriptures such as Bhagavad Gita constitute a great aid to sadhana. A broad\nintellectual background is necessary for achieving success in any sphere of\nscientific endeavour. Since yoga is a science par excellence, this is also true\nof yoga. This part of swadhyaya, however, is only the first step. Constant\nintrospection on the fundamental truths and deeper problems that have been\nstudied is more important. This constant reflection gradually and imperceptibly\nbegins to take the form of meditation in the ordinary sense of the term, i.e.\nthe mind becomes increasingly engrossed in the object of the search. Thus it\nslowly becomes ready to receive real knowledge from within and the aspirant\nbegins to obtain a deeper insight into the problems of yogic life.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The scriptures are\nmeant not only for rational, intellectual, logical understanding. The value of\ntheir teaching lies in being able to apply what we have understood in everyday\nlife. Our study will have no benefit if we do not make an effort to live up to\nthe teachings.&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Practical application of material suitable for\nour temperament and relevant to our mode of life is necessary if we wish to\nderive any permanent, substantial benefit from our study. Studying the\nscriptures does not mean just scanning the pages, but trying to understand\nevery word, studying with heart. The more often we read, the more we\nunderstand. We see things in a new light. That is the greatness of the holy\nscriptures. We gradually rise upwards. This implies elevation of the mind and\nexpansion of its horizon, which further implies a better understanding of\neverything within and around. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">We are\nattuned to the authors who were realized souls, great saints, seers and gurus\nwho trod the path of truth, and encountered and removed difficulties. Thus they\ngive us hope and vigour.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Daily reading is one of\nthe most powerful methods of keeping the mind fully alive to one\u2019s ideal. A\nhost of powerful, positive ideas rushes to the mind and the mental powers are\nat once sharpened. The reader is inspired and uplifted, and enabled to conquer\nthe lower forces in everyday life. Therefore, a sadhaka should not give up swadhyaya,\neven for a single day.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">By reading\ninspiring sentences over and over again, they become indelibly engraved in the\nheart and a part of one\u2019s inner nature. Such repetition gives strength and\npushes an idea into the innermost chambers of the heart and mind. Then the idea\npercolates into the subconscious mind. As a result, the negative thoughts\nlurking there are gradually annihilated.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Spiritual books like Bhagawad Gita </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">act as consoling companions under all vexing\ncircumstances, ideal teachers in all difficulties, as a guiding light in the\nnights of nascence and folly, as a panacea for evils and as shapers of destiny.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Witnessing yourself and\nstudying one\u2019s own personality is another equally valid and widely accepted\nview of swadhyaya. This implies the ability to read one\u2019s life like a book, to\nbe aware of each and every page. In other words, it is the analysis of our own\npersonality, being aware of our individual qualities, strengths and weaknesses,\nin order to know what and who we are.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Introspection\nand self analysis is useful only if translated into action. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">A yogi will not cheat himself during self\nanalysis.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">He can fail himself. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Self reflection for a yogi is a humbling\nprocess. Always use adversity to introspect. These are god given opportunities\nto drive real change. The heart and mind of a person can be understood by knowing\nwhat he aspires to be-</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">not what he is or\nwhat he was.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is only one thing in\nthis cosmos which you can be cock sure is bringing change to yourself with self\ndiscipline. The other is death. Everything which irritates us about others can\nlead to an understanding of ourselves. Your current comfort zone and safe\nboundaries were once unknown frontiers. You can take off your clothes and show\nyourself to a whore. This is not the real opening up. Rather opening up is\nabout revealing your soul</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">( dreams,\nthoughts, fears</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">etc )\u2014 this is the true\nmeaning of being naked.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Swadhyaya is a process\nof witnessing our own consciousness. Swadhyaya implies continually watching our\nactions and reactions in different situations, circumstances and events with\nmore awareness. We should try to know the reasons for our happiness and sorrow,\nanger, greed and attachment. As a result, we will gradually find out how our\nmind works and will become more aware of the things that disturb our mind. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">With an understanding of our weaknesses in\nparticular, we can chart out a multi-faceted program to weed them out, and thus\nprepare the ground for our gradual upliftment. Thus this type of self-analysis\nis of great value in our life.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mantra repetition is a swadhyaya\nbecause it helps to explore the inner recesses of consciousness. Such a sadhana\nharmonizes the lower vehicles of consciousness, makes them sensitive to the\nsubtle vibrations, and ultimately brings about a partial fusion of the lower\nand higher consciousness.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Each mantra\nhas a deity, or a name and form. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Every\nSuryanamaskara asana pose has its own mantra.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mananat trayate iti mantrah is the definition of mantra. It means that\nas a result of regular and intensive mantra sadhana, the distractions,\ndeviations, fluctuations, turbulence and disturbances of the mind slowly cease.\nThe mind is relatively harmonized, calm and quiet. Such a mind is capable of\nfocusing, looking within, and communing with the inner nature. Another relevant\nview of swadhyaya relates to meditation experiences. Accordingly, if an\naspirant sees visions in meditation, he should let them come. They should not\nbe suppressed as they will tell the aspirant a lot about the things that are\nembedded in the subconscious mind: memories, deep-rooted problems, etc. Many\nmay be causing persistent problems without the aspirant\u2019s knowledge. By\nconscious observation, the aspirant may easily face them and get rid of them.\nIn the context of meditation, swadhyaya also means closing the eyes and\nobserving one\u2019s own self, as is done in antar mouna practice. This gives rise\nto a faculty by which one is able to focus deeply on the god or goddess of\none\u2019s choice. Meditation, as understood in the usual sense of the term, may\nalso be regarded as swadhyaya. When we meditate on a mantra, an image or a\nthought, an abstract form or the formless, this is swadhyaya. This type of\nmeditation deepens our understanding and brings us closer to our nature.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Self-analysis is a great tool of jnana yoga.\nIt can be concluded that if these approaches and techniques are practised with\nfaith, sincerity and regularity, and under the right guidance, they will lead\nto mental peace, emotional harmony and bring the aspirant closer to the inner\nnature. Ishta devata darshan, or experience of the self, will not remain too\ndistant a goal.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Swadhyaya is the\npractice of self-study and self-analysis.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sva is interpreted as \u2018self\u2019 and adhyaya means \u2018investigation or\ninquiry\u2019.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yogis, we are encouraged to\nself-inquire daily through practices such asana, pranayama and meditation.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Traditionally, swadhyaya is attributed to the\nstudy of sacred texts.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to\nPatanjali, in order to attain a greater understanding of one\u2019s true being, the\nstudy of scriptures is important.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nscriptures are used to assist one in engaging in life spiritually through\nself-inquiry.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">We can often go through\nlife without looking deeply within ourselves, our values, actions and the\nimpact we have on others by our thoughts, words and actions.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The yogi is encouraged to engage in\nself-reflection by analysing the impact they have on others.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">You may think you come to yoga to build fitness\nand build strength and flexibility; which of course is true; however, through\nthese practices we are engaging in the act of swadhyaya.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">We flow through postures using breath and\nmovement, building concentration\u2026 we scan the body, we bring our awareness to\nour breath, we still the mind\u2026all practices of self-reflection.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">By doing this, we get to know ourselves more\nhonestly and see ourselves for what we are, not who we think we are.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Svadhyaya inspires and elevates the mind to\nhigh spiritual altitude. It clears doubts. It weeds&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">out unholy ideas. It\ncuts new spiritual grooves for the mind to move on. It reduces wandering of the</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">mind or Vikshepa. It helps concentration. It\nforms a kind of lower Savikalpa Samadhi. It serves pasture for the mind to\ngraze upon. When you study the sacred books, you are in tune with the authors\nwho are realised souls. You draw inspiration and become ecstatic.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Svadhyaya clears\ndoubts. It&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">strengthens the flickering\nfaith, it induces aspiration or strong yearning for liberation. It fills the\nmind with Sattva</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">or purity; it inspires\nand elevates the mind. It helps concentration and meditation. It cuts new\nSattvic grooves and makes the mind run in these new grooves. To translate the\nprecepts contained in the books of the sages and saints into action is to have your\nafflicted body soothed, to have your bruised soul healed, and to save yourself\nfrom all kinds of ills of life which are due to ignorance. Spiritual books act\nas consoling companions under all vexing circumstances, as ideal teachers in\nall difficulties, as guiding lights in the nights of nescience and folly, as\npanacea for evils and as shapers of destiny. Acquire wisdom by digesting the\nbooks of sages and saints, philosophers and mystics. By wisdom, master the\nsecrets of all sciences, know the exact nature of things, tune your localized being\nor individualised personality with the workings of the divine nature of the\nLaws of Truth. Wisdom is the key to the plenitude of power and joy. Wisdom\nannuls countless sufferings, innumerable sins, cuts the root of ignorance, and\nconfers upon you peaceful harmony and absolute perfection</span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Someone asked me about\nmind and space time.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The mathematical space-time\nmodel that joins space and time into a single idea called a continuum was\nwritten in Vedanta 7000 years ago. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">German Jew Albert\nEinstein lifted from it and made himself famous. &nbsp;&nbsp;Wherever an important quantity of matter\nexists, it bends the geometry of spacetime. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">THIEF &nbsp;Einstein wrote that space and time are\nrelative -- an object in motion actually experiences time at a slower rate than\none at rest. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is a direct lift\nfrom a Vimana travel story of King Kakudmi and his daughter Revati.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-XkZeL4oUhWY/V5tEePDJgGI/AAAAAAABLJg/pmGrxNWAJDEiGcEmLKg3vZG0MD0cQQlOwCLcB/s1600/doDwnload.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"640\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-XkZeL4oUhWY/V5tEePDJgGI/AAAAAAABLJg/pmGrxNWAJDEiGcEmLKg3vZG0MD0cQQlOwCLcB/s640/doDwnload.jpg\" width=\"477\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n</div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Let me quote Wikipedia-<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">QUOTE:&nbsp; Kakudmi was able to take his daughter Revati\nwith him and travel to Brahma-loka (the plane of existence where Brahma, the\nCreator, resides) and to speak with Brahma at will.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Meeting with\nBrahma[edit]<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Kakudmi's daughter\nRevati was so beautiful and so accomplished that when she reached a\nmarriageable age, Kakudmi, thinking no one upon earth was worthy of her, went\nto the Creator himself, Lord Brahma, to seek his advice about a suitable\nhusband for his daughter.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">When they arrived,\nBrahma was listening to a musical performance by the Gandharvas, so they waited\npatiently until the performance was finished. Then, Kakudmi bowed humbly, made\nhis request and presented his shortlist of candidates. Brahma laughed loudly,\nand explained that time runs differently on different planes of existence, and\nthat during the short time they had waited in Brahma-loka to see him, 27\ncatur-yugas (a cycle of four yugas, totalling 108 yugas, or Ages of Man) had\npassed on earth.&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Brahma said to Kakudmi, \"O King, all those whom you may\nhave decided within the core of your heart to accept as your son-in-law have\ndied in the course of time. Twenty-seven catur-yugas have already passed. Those\nupon whom you may have already decided are now gone, and so are their sons,\ngrandsons and other descendants. You cannot even hear about their names.[2] You\nmust therefore bestow this virgin gem (i.e. Revati) upon some other husband,\nfor you are now alone, and your friends, your ministers, servants, wives,\nkinsmen, armies, and treasures, have long since been swept away by the hand of\ntime.\"[3]<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">King Kakudmi was\novercome with astonishment and alarm at hearing this news.[3] However, Brahma\ncomforted him, and added that Vishnu, the preserver, was currently incarnate on\nearth in the forms of Krishna and Balarama, and he recommended Balarama as a\nworthy husband for Revati.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Kakudmi and Revati then\nreturned to earth which they regarded as having left only just a short while\nago. They were shocked by the changes that had taken place. Not only had the\nlandscape and environment changed, but over the intervening 27 chatur-yugas, in\nthe cycles of human spiritual and cultural evolution, mankind was at a lower\nlevel of development than in their own time (see Ages of Man). The Bhagavata\nPurana describes that they found the race of men had become \"dwindled in\nstature, reduced in vigour, and enfeebled in intellect.\"<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Daughter and father\nfound Balarama and proposed the marriage which was accepted. The marriage was\nthen duly celebrated. UNQUOTE</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kakudmi\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kakudmi</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/08/yellapragada-subbarow-nobel-prize-and.html\" style=\"background-color: cyan;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/08/yellapragada-subbarow-nobel-prize-and.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-AG8UzUTZ3Cw/V5tE5oVG1TI/AAAAAAABLJk/blx1kXJe_jYQJucgWv0hnXO6TP2o-TWkgCLcB/s1600/images.jpgEcffer4h6.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"606\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-AG8UzUTZ3Cw/V5tE5oVG1TI/AAAAAAABLJk/blx1kXJe_jYQJucgWv0hnXO6TP2o-TWkgCLcB/s640/images.jpgEcffer4h6.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 16px;\">Wherever an important quantity of matter exists, it bends the geometry of spacetime.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 16px;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">This results in a curved shape of space-time\nthat can be understood as gravity. In classical mechanics, the use of spacetime\nis optional, as time is independent of mechanical motion in the three\ndimensions of Euclidean space.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When a body is moving at speeds close to the\nspeed of light (relativistic speeds), time cannot be separated from the three\ndimensions of space as time then depends on how close to the speed of light the\nobject is moving.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The mind of a liberated\njivan mukt can transcend space time. He has extended his consciousness into the\ninfinite.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ordinary folks like you\nand me can do it only during REM sleep. At about 70 to 90 minutes into your\nsleep cycle, you enter REM sleep. You usually have three to five REM episodes\nper night. Your eyes jerk rapidly in various directions under your eyelids,\nthus the name Rapid Eye Movement (REM) Sleep, where most muscles are paralyzed\nwith occasional twitches.&nbsp; This level is\nalso referred to as paradoxical sleep because the sleeper, although exhibiting\nBeta EEG waves similar to a waking state, is harder to arouse than at any other\nsleep stage. Vital signs indicate arousal and oxygen consumption by the brain\nis higher than when the sleeper is awake.&nbsp;\nThere is shallow rapid breathing.&nbsp;\nREM stage has increased heart rate, raised blood pressure, erection in\nmales, and the body does not regulate its temperature. Most of the vivid dreams\noccur during REM sleep, once awaken at this stage a person can remember the\ndream. Adults spend&nbsp; 20% in REM. Older\nadults spend progressively less time in REM sleep. People are more likely to\nremember the dream if they are awakened during the REM phase. Males have an\nerection and females have enlarged clitoris during REM sleep.&nbsp; However this is NOT because of thoughts of\nsex, sorry.&nbsp; No matter what a dream is\nabout, REM sleep will cause an erection in a man who is not impotent.&nbsp;&nbsp; Even newborn boys have a boner during REM\nsleep!&nbsp;&nbsp; The reason why men sometimes\nwake up with a hop is simply because they were having a dream when they woke\nup. In females, nocturnal clitoral tumescence or NCT is accompanied by vaginal\nblood flow and transudation ( lubrication ).&nbsp;&nbsp;\nTwice the amount of blood flows to your brain during REM than when you\nare conscious. Unless a dream is particularly vivid and if one wakes during or\nimmediately after it, the content of the dream is not remembered, unless you\nwrite it down immediately within a few seconds . Primarily REM is the brain's\nway of&nbsp; ensuring that the consciousness\ncan be \u201cbooted up\u201d, in the absence of an external trigger. In the absence of\nexternal stimulus, the brain might stay in&nbsp;\ndeep sleep coma continuously until dehydration causes death.&nbsp; Humans cannot go into hibernation.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Non REM sleep restores\nour body physiologically , as when the body is at reast more cell division and\nrepair happens..</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">REM sleep restores us\nmentally.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">REM sleep thus plays a huge\nrole</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">in learning and memory. During REM\nsleep, your brain consolidates and processes the information you\u2019ve learned during\nthe day. REM has an UNLEARNING and</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">memory-consolidating function .</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some\nof these memories taken in by our senses may be rejected by the mind as\nuseless, while others may be seen as valuable and retained.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is information\nexchange from the conscious left lobe ( for right handers ) to be sub conscious\nright lobe. Learned skills consolidate in the brain during the REM sleep. This\nis why after a brain storming session, the thoughts must be left to incubate\ntill an REM sleep.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Major decisions are\nkept pending till then. REM has been shown to have links to memory consolidation\nand to learning. Adults who are deprived of REM sleep have trouble remembering\nand learning new things.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">REM sleep\nstimulates the brain regions used in learning.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">People taught a skill and then deprived of non-REM sleep could recall\nwhat they had learned after sleeping,</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">while people deprived of REM sleep could not. People participating in an\nintensive language learning course experienced an increase of REM. This\nindicates that the brain requires more REM sleep in order to assimilate the new\ninformation.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">REM sleep provided\nendogenous stimulation to prevent the brain from being shut down too long.&nbsp; REM sleep also acts as an escape valve for\nletting off the \u201cpsychic steam\u201d that accumulates from emotional stresses during\nthe day.&nbsp; During REM sleep, the body\u2019s\ninner temperature is no longer well regulated and tends to shift toward the\ntemperature of its surroundings,&nbsp; just as\nin reptiles. Astronauts take a Schumann field generator with them to produce\n7.83 Hertz ( which is also the frequency of the earth and Hindu king mantra OM\n) , to get proper REM sleep. &nbsp;&nbsp;This\nSchumann generator can generate full strength Schumann resonance which is in\nharmony with the 7 chakras of the human body. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Without this resonance,\nthe top 3 chakras in your body are rendered ineffective. HAARP can deprive you\nof your REM sleep.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Time is a pool out of\nwhich we can pull up the past, the present and the future; and time, mind and\nconsciousness are synonymous. If past , present, and future are happening\nsimultaneously within us at all times, this means that by examining our past\nlives, we should be able to see what our futures hold. But in truth, the future\nis not fixed. This is because through exercising our free will, or our ability\nto make choices, we have the capacity to re-create our renegotiate our future.<span style=\"background: white;\"> </span>The concepts of past and future\nexist only with reference to the concept of the present moment, which is the\ncentral point in time. What was once present is now past, and what will once be\npresent is now future. Both the past and the future are the present when they\noccur. But more importantly, the past and the future are both concepts that\nexist only in the present moment. Therefore, relatively speaking, the present\nis the only point in time that is real.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">6000 year old Bhagawad Gita is all\nabout being in the moment. It asks us to seize the moment. Though all that\npasses by it is constantly changing, the present moment itself always remains\nwithout undergoing any change, and hence it is the static gateway through which\nwe may pass from the illusion of ever-changing time to the reality of our\never-unchanging being.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If something travels\nfaster than light, it means that it can penetrate any matter as though it\nwasn\u2019t there.&nbsp; Therefore scalar waves\npervade all matter and cannot be shielded against by Faraday cages . Vedic\nhealing waves ( lifted by Reiki ) waves pass through the earth.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\nBelow: <b><span style=\"color: red;\">4000 YEARS AGO ADI SHANKARACHARYA WRITES ABOUT <span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">SPACE TIME</span> ( 2.49 OF VIDEO )- THIEF EINSTEIN JUST STOLE THE VEDIC CONCEPTS&nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-decoration: none;\">July 29, 2016 at 5:54 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_1MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\ncaptainji<br />\nif i am not mistaken melpathur narayana bhattatirippad has in the opening verses of \"narayaneeyam\" composed around 400-500 years back has mentioned kala and desa which means time and space. what is this \"beyond space and time?\"<br />\n<br />\nthanks</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_1BR\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; display: inline-block;\"><span class=\"thread-count\" id=\"bc_0_0TN\">\n</span></span><br />\n</span><br />\n<ol class=\"thread-chrome thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_0TC\" style=\"list-style-type: none; padding: 0px;\"><span id=\"bc_0_1b+seedPa5vD\" kind=\"d\">\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_0B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"border-bottom-width: 0px; margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 16px 0px 0px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c5979676611278354668\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_0M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/07/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_29.html?showComment=1469796626178#c5979676611278354668\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">July 29, 2016 at 6:20 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_0MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nhi rs,<br />\n<br />\nADI SHANKARACHARYA WROTE 4000 YEARS AGO-<br />\n<br />\n\"time and space, are creations of MAYA (`maya-kalpita-desha-kala-kalanat' -- dakshinamurti-stotra, sloka no.4).<br />\n<br />\nThe very fact that we are conscious of the passage of time is a consequence of maya.<br />\n<br />\nUltimate reality is beyond space time. Time, space and causation are like the glass through which the Absolute is seen. The Universe is the Absolute seen through the screen of time, space, and causation (kala, desha, nimitta).<br />\n<br />\nAs in the field of modern physics, so in the field of vedanta, time and space are modes incidental to sense perception and should not be applied to what is trans-empirical.<br />\n<br />\nThe acceptance of the reality of the dream to the dreamer is the king-pin of Shankara's explanation of Advaita.<br />\n<br />\nThis reality, called `vyAvahArika-satyaM' is in between the total unreality - `asat' - of the barren mother, and the total reality - `sat' - of brahman.<br />\n<br />\nThe dream and similarly the perceptible universe is neither `sat' nor `asat'. It is `mithyA'. The meaning of the word `mithyA' is not falsehood but comparative unreality.<br />\n<br />\nTTime and space come into the divine geometry of Sri Yantra as a pair of opposites, so that if the space separation and the time separation between two events, say here-now and there-then, are equal, the total separation between those two events is zero.<br />\n<br />\nWerner Heisenberg's uncertainty principle is MAYA.<br />\n<br />\nHeisenberg pointed out that the product of our necessary uncertainty in where a particle is and our necessary uncertainty in its momentum can never be smaller than Planck's constant over two pi. Also that the product of our necessary uncertainty in when something happens and our necessary uncertainty in the energy of the happening can never be less than that same amount.<br />\n<br />\nOnce science breaches Vedanta, the last frontier falls.<br />\n<br />\ncapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</span></ol>\n<span id=\"bc_0_1b+seedPa5vD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_1b+seedPa5vD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/TQKELOE9eY4/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/TQKELOE9eY4?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Quantum physicists went\nto the heart of matter and were astounded by what they saw. Matter was not\nsolid at all as our senses tell us but merely energy in motion. It is written\nthat time and space are relative. This is the heart of Vedanta. 6000 years ago\nthe Bhagawad Gita declared that what binds us to wheel of samsara are the three\nmental bonds known&nbsp; as desa, kaala and\nnimitta, - space, time and causality and that these are purely mental bonds\nwhich we have created ourselves. We have created this world of concrete objects\nand superimposed a false reality on them. Again and again our scriptures tell\nus that Absolute reality is beyond these three upadis -desha, kaala and nimitta\nor space time and causality. This world which we think we see is maya or an\nappearance. It has no permanent reality. It is only a passing show and has no\npermanence. Our bodies which are made of the same material - the five elements\nare also perishable.&nbsp; BUT we are not\nsolely these bodies. Our reality is something far greater since we are actually\nthe atman - which is imperishable and eternal and untouched by the changes of\nthe body which take place in the world of space /Time. The moment we demarcate\nourselves as belonging to a specified place and time, that moment we separate\nourselves from our roots and thus bring suffering on ourselves. We are the\ncreators of time and space. When we bring energy to conscious awareness, through\nthe act of perception we create separate objects that exist in space through a\nmeasured continuum called time. By creating time and space we create our own false\nseparateness. If we want to understand the universe we will have to see it as a\ndynamic web of interconnectedness. Human beings are a coalescence of energy in\na field of energy which is connected to every other thing in this universe.\nThis energy field is the central engine of our being. We can never be estranged\nfrom the other aspects of this universe since we are all bound fundamentally to\nthis field ( brahmAn )!. Our soul is just a part of brahmAn, the mother field &nbsp;sheared off with lowered frequency and sent to\nplanet earth for gaining experience and evolution. As the soul evolves its frequency\nincreases. When the frequency is increased to match the frequency of the mother\nfield , moksha happens and the soul merges with brahman. YOU are now god. YOU\nshare your experience with god in a closed loop. BrahmAn knows everything .\nHuman suffering stems from this very fact, that we have cut ourselves off from\nour roots and have condemned ourselves to a life of isolation. This was not how\nnature meant us to be.&nbsp; Modern\nphysics&nbsp; has thus given us a correct\nevaluation of our place in the world. The human consciousness (as our\nscriptures have always told us) is a crucial factor in making up this universe.\nSub atomic particles settle down from their constant erratic movements and take\non solid shapes only when we observe them.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Matter is composed of subatomic particles that\nhave no design or shape and do not follow any standard order. Sometimes they\nbehave like waves and sometimes like particles and sometimes they are both as\nwell as many things at same time. Hence these physicists actually proved the\nmaya theory in a scientific way. The entire white skinned Quantum physicists\nwrote in their wills that they want to be cremated and not buried.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">As the Gita tells us in\nchapter 3, \u201c Sahayajna praja sristwa purovacha prajapati.\u201d - The creator\ncreated all of us and instilled the idea of yajna or selfless action in us. No\nman is an island and no one can live without any sort of dependence on others\nand on nature. There is no me and mine as we think but all things are connected\nin an amazing way to the energy field. \u201cMamta and ahamta\u201d (me and mine) have\nalways been considered to be the two knots which alienate us from god. In this\nunified field there is no place for EGO laden me and mine. Any selfish act\nimmediately isolates us from the world and from nature and many such acts\neventually bring unhappiness, discontent, ill health and continuous bad luck\nwhich we blame on others and on our fate etc. never realizing that it is only a\nconsequence of our own selfish actions. Here is where the law of karma comes\ninto play. Our world is shaped by our own actions. In this respect we must\nunderstand that our thoughts are also actions. As Krishna says in the human\nbeing, INTENT is even more important than the actual action. Pure energy as it\nexists on the quantum level is not bound by time or space but exists as a vast\ncontinuum of fluctuating change which exists here and now. This moment, this\ntiny bit of time and space we are existing now is the only truth and reality.\nThe past is a dream and the future a fantasy. What exists is the present which\nagain has only a fleeting reality. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhagawad\nGita tells us to be in NOW- to seize the moment. This is this planet\u2019s ultimate\nlesson and can never ever be surpassed.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Quantum physicists agreed\nwith Bhagawad Gita ,that individual consciousness does not die with the death\nof the body . This state of being is also known as\n\u2018creative surrender\u2019, as it is a deliberate and conscious relaxation of the\nmind and body. When we reach this state, we surrender and open up to reality,\ncreating space in the mind for reality to flow through. The hypnagogic state\nsheds light on how our thought processes can be very different when we\u2019re truly\nrelaxed than when we\u2019re in our usual mindset. It is said that the hypnagogic\nstate is one in which there is a \u2018loosening of ego boundaries\u2019 and creative\nideas are more fluid. Yoga is about creative surrender and entering a state of\ndeep relaxation. In the borderlands between wakefulness and rest is a strange\nand fascinating state of consciousness characterized by dream-like visions and\nstrange sensory occurrences. Psychologists call this stage\n\"hypnagogia,\" but centuries before they created a term for it, artists\nwere using the hypnagogic state to tap into some of their best ideas. During\nthis state, the mind is \"fluid and hyperassociative,\" giving rise to visions\nthat can \"express layers of memories and sensations\". Similar to REM\nsleep -- the state of deep sleep when our dreams occur -- the mind is cycling\nthrough thoughts, ideas, memories and emotions, making free and often distant\nassociations between diverse concepts. But unlike REM, during hypnagogia you're\nconscious enough to be at least partially aware of what's going on. Scientists\nhave observed the presence of both alpha brain waves -- which are the dominant\nbrain wave mode when we are conscious but relaxed, for instance when\ndaydreaming or meditating -- and theta brain waves, which are associated with\nrestorative sleep, during hypnagogia. Typically, these brain waves occur only\nseparately, and it may be the unique combination that gives rise to unusual\nvisions and sensations. The state is also marked by reduced activity in the\nprefrontal cortex of the brain, which is involved in planning, decision-making\nand social behavior. In some ways, hypnagogia is the best of both worlds. You\nget the free flow of ideas and associations that occurs during REM sleep --\nwhen the brain reviews and processes memories, thoughts and feelings -- but\nyou're still awake enough to be somewhat conscious of what's going on. For this\nreason, creative people have entered the ZONE OF THE MAHARISHIS and found\nhypnagogia to be a rich source of ideas and inspiration.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">By surrendering the\nresults of our actions, as told by Krishna 6000 years go, or simply learning to\ntrust in the universe a little more; each time we do choose to surrender, we\nmove closer to freedom.
