Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/07/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_41.html?showComment=1469623250888#c2014112562138100427\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">July 27, 2016 at 6:10 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_78MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nhi rs,<br />\n<br />\nthe white invader created the FAKE and back dated kanchi mutt -- and put adi shankaracharya as its first acharya<br />\n<br />\nthe white invader dated adi shankaracharya's death as <span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b>477 BC.</b></span><br />\n<br />\nQUOTE: The chronological list of Guru Paramapara of the matham follows:[citation needed]<br />\n<br />\nAdi Sankara Bhagavatpada (482 BC-477 BC)<br />\nSuresvaracharya (477 BC-407 BC)<br />\nSarvajnatman (407 BC-367 BC)<br />\n:UNQUOTE<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: 16px;\">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanchi_Kamakoti_Peetham</span><br />\n<br />\nbut as usual they screwed up the dates<br />\n<br />\nthe same wikipedia records adi shankaracharya death at <span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b>820 AD</b></span> ( NEARLY 13 CENTURIES LATER )<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: 16px;\">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adi_Shankara</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: blue;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2013/06/kanchi-mutt-creation-of-white-invader.html</span><br />\nIT WAS JEW ROTHSCHILD WHO INTRODUCED TELUGU TANTRI IN SABARIMALA ( AND BACK DATED THEM )<br />\n<br />\nIT WAS JEW ROTHSCHILD WHO MADE TAMIL BRAHMINS USURP THE LEGACY OF A KERALA NAMBOODIRI ADI SHANKARACHARYA<br />\n<br />\nTHERE IS NO LOVE LOST BETWEEN NAMBOODIRIS AND OPPORTUNISTIC SIDEKICKS OF JEW ROTHSCHILD-- THE TAMIL BRAHMINS<br />\n<br />\ncapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n<br />\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><br /></b>\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\">IN THE PREVIOUS POST ( PART 55 ) I WROTE ABOUT BRAHMACHARI VIVEKANANDA WHO TOOK UP ONE EXTREME OF WITHHOLDING SEMEN .</b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><br /></b>\n<b style=\"background-color: cyan;\">WHAT ARE WE TO DO WITH HIS SHIT WHICH CONTAINS BEEF ?</b><br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">&nbsp;2.33 --- vitarkabadhane pratipakshabhavanam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Principles which run\ncontrary to yama and niyama needs to be contradicted with the knowledge of\ndiscrimination. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">From Sanskrit,\npratipaksha means \u201copposite\u201d and bhavana means \u201ccultivation.\u201d&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When presented with\ndisquieting thoughts or feelings, cultivate an opposite, elevated attitude. This\nis Pratipaksha Bhavana. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is a\npersonal practice that \"helps to change your ATTITUDE rather than hoping\nto change the situation or the people who cause you to be unhappy.\"&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pratipaksha Bhavana is\nthe practice of cultivating a perspective that sees negative situations in the\nopposite way and in so doing will cultivate a positive and balanced mind.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Now the sadhaka is\nadvised to cultivate an outlook which can oppose the current of ferocity,\nfalsehood, stealing, non-chastity and venality, which is pratipaksa bhavana;\nand to go with the current of cleanliness, contentment, fervour, self-study and\nsurrender to the Universal Spirit, which is paksa bhavana.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The principles that\nprevent yama and niyama needs to be counteracted with right knowledge and\nawareness.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the mind is caught\nup in undecided ideas and actions, right perception is hindered. The sadhaka\nhas to analyse and investigate these ideas and actions and their opposites;\nthen only he learns to balance his thoughts by reiterated experimentation.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some people give an\nobjective interpretation to this sutra and maintain that if one is violent, one\nshould think of the opposite, or, if one is attached, then non-attachment\nshould be developed. This is the contradictory thought or pratipaksabhavana. &nbsp;Instead of trying to cultivate the opposite\ncondition, he should go deep into the cause of his anger or violence. This is\npaksabhava. One should also study the opposite forces with calmness and\npatience. Then only one develops equipoise.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Paksa means to choose a\nside (in an argument), to espouse one view; whereas pratipaksa communicates the\nidea of choosing the opposite position.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">A healthy state of mind\nimplies keeping one\u2019s mind free from sadness, dejection, worry, and tension and\nnegative sentiments such as anger, hate, greed, and pride. It also implies\neliminating these negative impulses and replacing them with constructive ones.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It has 3 stages:\ndilution\u2014you dilute the power of the negative thought back by denying it your\nattention; substitution\u2014while holding back attention from negative thoughts,\nstart asserting that which is positive; and sublimation\u2014as you continue doing\nthis, you will find that the negative becomes sublimated (i.e. vaporized) and\nfades away. In the first stage, you recognize the presence of a negative\nthought the moment it arises, and take control of it. In this stage the\nnegative thought is not allowed to root itself in the mind and held in check\nnot so much by force but rather by simply withdrawing the attention. One of the\ncommon mistakes people make is to resist and struggle with their thoughts,\nemotions, habits, and situations. Instead, as you notice the negative thought\nand gently restrain it by not attending to it, try to develop a positive\naffirmation within the mind. Substitute positive thoughts that are contrary to\nthe negative thought that is disturbing your mind. Try thinking exactly the\nopposite of what is going on in your mind. This is the second stage of\nPratipaksha Bhavana, referred to as the substitution stage If you become angry,\ntry presenting before your mind a state of forbearance in which your anger is\nconverted into compassion. As you practice the substitution process of\nPratipaksha Bhavana, the negative may come back again and again, but it will\ngradually dissipate and lose its force and momentum. The positive will begin to\nassert itself\u2014it is just a matter of time and patience. With sustained\npractice, as you go on developing the positive within yourself, the negative\nbecomes sublimated and, to your surprise, soon vanishes. This process of\nsublimation represents the third stage of Pratipaksha Bhavana.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Success or failure at higher levels of\nconsciousness depends upon yama and niyama. This fusing of paksa and pratipaksa\nin all aspects of yoga is true yoga.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Here, it needs to be\nemphasised that yama and niyama are not only the foundation of yoga, but also\nthe reflection of one's success or failure at its higher levels.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When disturbed by\nnegative thoughts, opposite (positive) ones should be thought of. This is\npratipaksha bhavana.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Upon being\nharassed by negative thoughts, one should cultivate counteracting thoughts..&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Negative thoughts arise\nin the mind as a result of the past impressions, samskaras, that are deep\nrooted in the chitta. These thoughts usually violate the values of yamas and\nniyamas. Thus these are thoughts directed toward violence, untruthfulness, stealing,\nsexual indulgence, accumulation, uncleanliness, discontentment, luxury,\ndisinterest in scriptures and lack of devotion to Ishvara. When negative\nthoughts, which are a natural outcome of the samskaras, arise, we do not berate\nourselves for having such thoughts. We simply learn to cultivate the opposite\nthoughts (pratipaksha bhavana). We should keep in mind that thoughts of\nviolence, dishonesty etc. arise because of impressions of past practices of\nsimilar nature that are imprinted in the chitta. The practice of yoga helps\ncreated a stronger presence of the sattva guna which helps in activating\npositive thoughts when confronted with negative ones. When pratipaksha bhavana\nis practiced regularly, it creates a stronger sattvic field in the chitta which\ncan prevent further activation of negative thoughts.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When improper thoughts\ndisturb the mind, there should be constant pondering over the opposites. Positive\novercomes negative. This is a grand effective Law of Nature. The method of\ndisplacing or dislocating the negative feeling by substituting the opposite,\npositive feeling, is very easy. Within a very short time, the undesirable\nfeeling vanishes. If there is pride, think of humility. If there is hypocrisy,\nthink of frankness and its invaluable advantages. If there is jealousy, think\nof nobility and magnanimity. If there is timidity, think of courage, and so on.\nYou will drive off the negative feelings and will be established in a positive\nstate. Switching from negative to positive self-talk allows one to have a more\npositive and joyful existence at the physical, mental and spiritual\nlevels.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The difficulty is making the\nshift out of old habits (Samskara) of negative thoughts and action to new more\npositive ones.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is difficult, but each\nday provides many opportunities to exercise Pratipaksha bhavana. The key to\nPratipaksha Bhavana is changing the environment by inviting the positive in, as\nwell as considering the after-effect of holding on to negative/violent thoughts\nand actions. Pratipaksha Bhavana is a powerful technique that relies on the power\nof the mind-body connection.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Consider\nthe harm caused by chronically thinking negative thoughts about self and\nothers.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thought becomes intention, and\nover time, intention often becomes action/deeds or physically manifest in the\nbody (i.e. as a disease).</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Disease occurs\nbecause chronic negative and violent thoughts stress and overwork the\nsympathetic nervous system (in a continuous fight or flight response) and flood\nthe body with stress hormones, causing illness.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The practice of Pratipaksha Bhavana can help one to activate the\nparasympathetic nervous system (relaxation response) promoting homeostasis and\nhealing.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Negative thoughts about\nself and others also shape one\u2019s self esteem and actions in the contexts of\ninter-personal relationships.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">If one approaches\nthe world and daily events with an attitude of (Ahimsa) kindness, friendliness\nand thoughtful consideration of others, then interactions with friends,\nco-workers and strangers are less stressful and have more positive outcomes.\nThe practice of Pratipaksha Bhavana is particularly helpful in dealing with\nnegative individuals and/or crisis situations..</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">One must thoughtfully\nexamine (negative) attitudes towards self and others and consider the\nconsequences of those (or alternative positive) attitudes at every moment of\ntime and place. Pratipaksha Bhavanamt helps us catch destructive and\ndistracting thoughts, and redirect our minds back toward the yogic path. These\nmethods remind us that other options exist! When we are feeling caught up in\ncycle of destructive thoughts, it is very unpleasant\u2026 Our judgment is obscured\nby the murkiness in the mind, and we may say or do something that we later wish\nwe had not done. Such feelings have a \u201ctrapping\u201d nature \u2013 both physically and\nmentally we feel tight, confined, and trapped in a corner. Pratipaksha Bhavana\nopens the doors for us. By creating the opposite thought and reflecting on the\npossible consequences of our thoughts, words, and deeds\u2026 we are instantly given\nmore options for thinking, feeling, and behaving. We move from reacting to\nchoosing. We are taken out of the cave and up to the mountain top, from where\nwe can see in every direction; we can see every way down the mountain and so we\nare able to <span style=\"color: red;\">THINK LATERALLY and pick the best option.</span> Reminding ourselves that\nnegative thoughts, utterances, and deeds will result is pain and suffering for\nus (as well as for the recipient!) can be a powerful tool for changing our\nbehavior.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">These disturbing\nthoughts that consume us at times arise from our past. They are based in fears\nand hurts from our past experiences. They are old. Pratipaksha Bhavana gives us\na concrete methodology that we can use to begin addressing and changing these\ndamaging patterns. Increasingly, we expose ourselves to new, uplifting options.\nThe ability to catch ourselves and consider the long-term consequences can help\nus stay in line with our yogic goal of not harming others. Over time, the\nprocess of slowing down thought and speech, of carefully considering our\nthoughts and words and deeds becomes more intuitive and arises naturally.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Often our ideas toward\nothers/ideas/situations may not be very clear. Thus reacting harshly could land\nus in situations we do not want to be in. In such circumstances, any\nopportunity to have second thought is worth considering. Sometimes harsh words\nare like nails driven into wood. You can take the nail out, but the hole\nremains. Yogis practice pratipaksha bhavana in order to actively change\nintrusive or destructive thoughts.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It can shift the\nenergies in our immediate life, by enabling us to choose to see the light that\nis absent in the darkness, and the goodness that resides in the essence of\nevery person, opportunity, and experience we are presented with. When we change\nour ways of seeing - we sow the seeds for changing our very being...</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pratipaksha\nBhavana is a simple and direct way of keeping our minds calm and our hearts\nopen.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">World leaders must\npractice Pratipaksha bhavana and cultivate grace and patience \u2013WW3 can be\navoided.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">With clarity they can realize\nthat changing the situation may not be possible; rather they can change their\nattitude allows peace to bloom.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Leaders ruling powerful\nnations cannot go berserk with rage. A feeling of revenge and retribution , \u201cto\nteach a lesson\u201d can result in loss of life. It will be too late to regret once\nthe situation has gone out of control. The best way to predict the future is to\ncreate it.</span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">2.34\u2014 vitarkaa\nhinsadayah kritakaritanumodita lobhakrodhamohapoorvaka<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">mridumadhyadhimatra\nduhkhajnananantafala iti pratipakshabhavanam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Uncertain knowledge\ngiving rise to violence, whether done directly or indirectly, or condoned, is\ncaused by greed, anger or delusion in mild, moderate or intense degree. It\nresults in endless pain and ignorance. Through introspection comes the end of\npain and ignorance.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vitharka himsadhayaha \u2013\nPerversities are incubators of injuries (to the mind) leading to<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Kritha karitha\nanumodhitha \u2013 Done, caused to be done, and approved deeds originating in<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Lobha krodha moha\npurvaka \u2013 Greed, anger and delusion of the dimensions of<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mridhu madhya adhimatra\n\u2013 Small medium and large, Soft average and intense degrees resulting in<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dukha agnana\nananthapala \u2013 Unending consequences of emotional pain and ignorance<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ithi\nprathipakshabhavanam \u2013 Therefore assumption of counterstrategic stance<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Indecent or perverse\nactions and thoughts result in endless pain. These thoughts, emotions and\nactions are of three types and differ in intensity - being mild, medium or\nacute. They are stimulated by direct indulgence, unconsciously induced, or\nexternally abetted. Violence, for instance, practiced directly, caused or\ncondoned, results in endless ignorance, physical pain and mental distress. Such\nbehaviour is motivated by avarice, wrath and delusion, and can be corrected by\nits opposites, i.e., introspection, proper thinking and action. This sutra\nelaborates the discords and misguided efforts that obstruct progress in yoga. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The individual person\npossessing different instruments of senses is called the adhy\u0101tmic person, and\nthe individual controlling deity of the senses is called adhidaivic. The\nembodiment seen on the eyeballs is called the adhibhautic person.&nbsp; (Srimad Bhagavatam----2:10:8)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Disease, pain and\ndistress are of three kinds. One comes through deliberate over-indulgence in\npleasures through desire, lust and pride. This is known as adhyatmika roga or\nself-inflicted disease. The second comes from non-deliberate habits and\nbehaviour, which arise from the discrepancy of the five elements in the body\nand their sensory counterparts. These are adhibhautika rogas. The last type,\nadhidaivika roga, is often a disease of genetic or hereditary origin that\nappears without noticeable cause. All three types may be experienced in mild,\nmoderate or intense form. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The living entity in\nthe bodily conception of life is absorbed in the body, which is a combination\nof the physical elements, the five senses for gathering knowledge, and the five\nsenses of action, along with the mind. Through the mind the living entity\nsuffers three kinds of tribulations\u2014adhibhautika, adhidaivika and adhy\u0101tmika.\nTherefore this body is a source of all miseries. (Srimad Bhagavatam----6:15:25)</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Patanjali emphasises\nthat it is by the exercise of the discriminative faculty that dubious,\nvacillating or uncertain knowledge, vitarka, is curtailed. When negative\nthoughts of acts such as violence, etc. are caused to be done or even approved\nof, whether incited by greed, anger or infatuation, whether indulged in with\nmild, medium or extreme intensity, they are based on ignorance and bring\ncertain pain. Reflecting thus is also pratipaksha bhavana.&nbsp; If we bring pain to someone or cause harm to\nbe done to another, reactions will result in ignorance and misery for us. Even\nif we don\u2019t cause the pain directly, we can merely approve of someone else\ncausing the pain due to our own anger or ignorance.Each of these categories has\nbeen further divided into three categories based on intensity \u2013 mild, moderate\nand intense. Additionally, they can be provoked in three ways: by lobha\n(greed); krodha (anger); or moha (illusion).Since greed, anger, and delusion\ncan form the basis for violent acts done by oneself, on one\u2019s behalf or\nauthorized by oneself, and can be mild, moderate or intense, there can be up to\n27 divisions of violence, as noted by Patanjali. To oppose these thoughts one\nneeds to think of the consequences of acts such as violence. The sutra states\nthat thinking that these acts lead us to unlimited ignorance and suffering, we\ncan develop pratipaksha bhavana (opposing thoughts). The resulting suffering\nmay come either in this life or in a future life. This follows the law of karma\nwhich Patanajali has talked about.Violence can be regarded as a result of the\nguna \u2018tamas\u2019. Perpetuating violence increased tamas which is ignorance of the\nchitta. Reflecting on these negative consequences, one should not contemplate\non committing negative acts like violence.Doubts, questioning, argument -for-\nargument-sake (devil\u2019s advocate) etc., have their place in the acquisition of\nknowledge prior to commitment. Once begun, they hinder the progress towards the\ngoal and in fact produce what our ancestors had considered as the sources of\nall suffering \u2013 emotional pain and poverty of mind. Both can completely inhabit\nthe mind to the point of inertia. Patanjali considers one of the possible\nperversities among many that can crop up in the mind in some detail and in the\nprocess gives us a researcher\u2019s view of the interior landscape of the mind. We\nstart with the thought of an act of violence and follow the thread of the act\nwhich could be performed by ourselves.A contemplated act of violence may EITHER\nbe committed OR be restrained by force of will. If committed against another\nbeing, deprivation of another\u2019s right to dignity enervates you ( your soul). It\nproduces guilt which even if nobody else notices makes your long life\nmiserable. If the wanton act is suppressed for reasons of social pressures and\nsuch, it eats you from the inside by erupting in unpredictable ways and\nshortens your life. Thus it\u2019s not just don\u2019t do it but don\u2019t even think about\nit. If the thought arises train your mind to reject (kill) it. The wondrous\nhuman mind is rich in layers of many hues and a thought once allowed can reach\ninto the recesses, play out an engaging drama, and drain your energy.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.35\u2014 ahimsapratishthayam\ntatsannidhau vairatyagah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">When one is confirmed\nin non-violence, hostility ceases in his presence</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the yogi has soundly\nrealised the nature of violence, he is established firmly in the practice of\nnon-violence. Peace in words, thoughts and deeds, whether awake or dreaming, is\na sign of benevolence and love towards all. In the vicinity of a yogi, men and\nanimals who are otherwise brutal and hostile towards each other, dispose off\ntheir hostility and demonstrate friendliness and mutual tolerance. When a\nperson is fully established in ahimsa in word, action and thought, he emits\nharmonious vibrations. Other people in the vicinity also give up their harmful\ntendencies. In the ancient times, sages, firmly following ahimsa, would live in\nthe forest harmoniously with wild animals. Ahimsa is a mind/body intentionality\nwhich triumphs over bad samskaras; not made once and forgotten thereafter but\nconstantly and vigilantly practiced. Ahimsa in practice makes fear disappear\nand that\u2019s the key. Ahimsa is about the intent, rather than the action itself.\nIt is an attitude of universal benevolence. Patanjali says that once ahimsa is\nmastered, even wild animals and ferocious criminals will become tame and\nharmless in our presence.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Traditionally ahimsa is taken to\nmean that a person should not kill. This is why vegetarianism is so widespread\nin India. Ahimsa, rightly understood, is the ultimate weapon; it turns one\u2019s\nenemy into a friend, thereby banishing the possibility of further conflict.</span><span style=\"color: red;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red;\">What\nPatanjali referred to, essentially, was the attitude of the mind, rather than\nthe literal acts of the body. </span>It is one\u2019s attitude that can either lead him\ntoward liberation, or hold him in greater bondage. An attitude of harmlessness\n(and its corollary, a feeling of universal benevolence) is what is meant by\nahimsa. It is not possible in any case kill anyone: The soul is immortal.</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nprinciple of ahimsa must be understood in subtle ways, not only in gross. To\nharm anyone in the slightest way, even by disrespect, will harm the person\ndoing the action as well as the one receiving it.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">Below: Jew Rothchild's agents Gandhi and Martin Luther King Jr. &nbsp;The white invader robbed Bharatmata blind and converted India from the richest nation to the poorest nation in 250 years flat. &nbsp;</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">A few thousand white men enslaved a nation of millions - and Gandhi , told us to give the invader LOVE. &nbsp;We should have stoned them to death , like mad jackals on a school street .</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-ua8siq1WxHE/V5kFFgc8MVI/AAAAAAABLIw/uRLixcwRjoE7m_rSNy9YFGpJpO1QHxynwCLcB/s1600/dowffnload.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\">Protecting ourselves and our watan does not violate ahimsa.&nbsp;</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b style=\"background-color: cyan;\">Practicing\nahimsa means we take responsibility to\nstop the harm caused by evil invaders . Remember both Ram and Krishna initiated wars of dharma. &nbsp;</b></span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-3mvsvfrgfAk/V5kGIR2sx3I/AAAAAAABLI4/xIOjXj5D-Qg3IVlgRjj2SwrR8qAR-bu8wCLcB/s1600/93c57c16-9662-44fffd2-ba38-ecd781669d38.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; text-decoration: none;\">July 27, 2016 at 7:21 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_7MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/life-style/relationships/ask-the-expert/Why-are-so-many-men-approaching-me-for-casual-sex/articleshow/53412316.cms<br />\n<br />\nTHUMB RULE: SUCH CHUTNEY MARYs MUST NOW ALLOW THEIR HITLER TO CATCH A COLD<br />\n<br />\nALWAYS --KEEP AND EXTRA PANTY IN THE PURSE.</div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_7BR\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; line-height: 22.4px; margin-left: 36px; margin-top: 1em;\">\n<div class=\"comment-thread inline-thread\" id=\"bc_0_4T\" kind=\"t\" style=\"background-color: #eeeeee; margin: 8px 0px; padding: 0.5em 1em;\" t=\"0\" u=\"0\">\n<div class=\"thread-dropContainer thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_4TD\">\n<span id=\"bc_0_7b+seedJW2UD\" kind=\"d\"><span class=\"thread-toggle thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_4TT\" kind=\"g\" style=\"cursor: pointer; display: inline-block; font-size: 16px;\"><span class=\"thread-count\" id=\"bc_0_4TN\"><span class=\"thread-drop\"></span></span></span></span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_7b+seedJW2UD\" kind=\"d\"><span class=\"thread-toggle thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_4TT\" kind=\"g\" style=\"cursor: pointer; display: inline-block; font-size: 16px;\"><span class=\"thread-count\" id=\"bc_0_4TN\">\n</span></span><br />\n</span><br />\n<ol class=\"thread-chrome thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_4TC\" style=\"list-style-type: none; padding: 0px;\"><span id=\"bc_0_7b+seedJW2UD\" kind=\"d\">\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_4B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"font-size: 16px; margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 16px 0px 8px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c8950632688838140128\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_4M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/03515649322352795115\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">abcindiagogo</a></cite><span class=\"icon user\" style=\"font-weight: bold;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/07/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_27.html?showComment=1469636315218#c8950632688838140128\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">July 27, 2016 at 9:48 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_4MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nCaptain,<br />\n<br />\nWhy have you stopped using the word \"Twat\" and substituted it with \"Hitler\" ?</div>\n<span class=\"comment-actions secondary-text\" id=\"bc_0_4MN\" kind=\"m\"><span class=\"item-control blog-admin pid-388877552\" style=\"display: inline;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/delete-comment.g?blogID=3564735312144269387&amp;postID=8950632688838140128\" o=\"d\" style=\"color: #888888; padding-right: 5px; padding-top: 5px; text-decoration: none;\" target=\"_self\">Delete</a></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_4BR\" style=\"margin-left: 36px; margin-top: 1em;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replybox-single\" id=\"bc_0_4B_box\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; margin-top: 5px;\">\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_5B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"font-size: 16px; margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 0.25em 0px 8px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c8746835319969369790\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_5M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/03515649322352795115\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">abcindiagogo</a></cite><span class=\"icon user\" style=\"font-weight: bold;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/07/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_27.html?showComment=1469672172465#c8746835319969369790\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">July 28, 2016 at 7:46 AM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_5MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nCaptain,<br />\n<br />\nYour usage of the word Hitler instead of twat may cause confusion among new readers who are not familiar with both your writing style and viewpoints regarding Chutney Marys and Pickle Johns.</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_5BR\" style=\"margin-left: 36px; margin-top: 1em;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replybox-single\" id=\"bc_0_5B_box\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; margin-top: 5px;\">\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_6B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"border-bottom-width: 0px; margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 0.25em 0px 0px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; font-size: 16px; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c8164940731195931712\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_6M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"font-size: 16px; margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/07/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_27.html?showComment=1469676497427#c8164940731195931712\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">July 28, 2016 at 8:58 AM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_6MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nNOWADAYS CHUTNEY MARYs WEAR THONGS --<br />\n<br />\nTHEIR PUBIC HAIR LOOKS LIKE HITLERS MOUSTACHE , JUST ABOVE THE TWAT.<br />\n<br />\nTEE HEEEEEEE<br />\n<br />\nTALKING ABOUT TWATS<br />\n<br />\nCP BROWN CREATED AND BACKDATED FAKE YOGI VEMANA ( BASAVA STUFF )<br />\n<br />\nREMEMBER APCO MODI WENT ALL THE WAY TO THAMES TO PRAY TO BASAVA STATUES .<br />\n<br />\nACCORDING TO CP BROWNs STORY-- YOGI VEMANA WAS A SCREW MASTER<br />\n<br />\nvemana used to patronise whores<br />\n<br />\nhe ran out of money --and then started stealing --<br />\n<br />\npretty soon he started stealing his sister in law's gold jewellery<br />\n<br />\nthe one day, while she was sleeping he stole her gold mangalasutra<br />\n<br />\nshe got up and told him \" my mangalasutra must be given to the whore from behind &nbsp;-- &nbsp;she must bend and receive it between her legs \"<br />\n<br />\nso yogi vemana went hoppetty hop-- he had sex and then , as instructed he made the whore bend and he went from behind on his knees to give the gold .<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><b>vemana took in the terrible FISH odor and the ugly sight of her huge repulsive dripping TWAT (bhosdaa) .</b></span><br />\n<br />\nwhen he went home, his sister in law asked him , if he gave the gold as per her instruction<br />\n<br />\nvemana said \"indeed !\"<br />\n<br />\nhe never went whoring again. he was reformed !<br />\n<br />\nTEE HEEE<br />\n<br />\nthis is how the white men made monkeys out of us.<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: 16px;\">http://astroloka.com/showarticle.aspx?articleid=866&amp;article=Dawn%20of%20Viveka%20and%20Vairagya.%20Yogi%20Vemana</span><br />\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-size: 16px;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2015/04/cp-brown-and-yogi-vemana-capt-ajit.html</span><br />\n<br />\ncapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</span></ol>\n<span id=\"bc_0_7b+seedJW2UD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_7b+seedJW2UD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; float: left; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 22.4px; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c1475444100286423818\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 22.4px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_32M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/15080597732504740590\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">Sushanta Kumar Das</a></cite><span class=\"icon user\" style=\"font-weight: bold;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/07/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_27.html?showComment=1469687022201#c1475444100286423818\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">July 28, 2016 at 11:53 AM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_32MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nHi Ajit,<br />\nWhat a Cock &amp; Bull Story on Vemana &gt;\"\"My beloved asked me to bring some ornaments. I came here to take them.\" Narasamma asked him to get out of the room at once. Then Vemana cried and fell at her feet. Narasamma prayed to God to give good Buddhi to Vemana and make him a pure, virtuous soul. Then she promised to give Vemana an ornament, provided he would strictly obey her words. Vemana fully assured her.<br />\n<br />\nNarasamma said: \"Vemana! Ask the girl to stand naked in front of you. Let her back be turned towards you. Then ask her to bend down and take the jewel from your hands by passing her hands through her thighs.\" Vemana promised to do so and took an oath also in the name of Goddess Kali. Then his sister-in-law gave him a valuable ornament.<br />\n<br />\nVemana proceeded directly to the prostitute\u2019s house and asked her to do in the manner his sister-in-law had instructed. While the prostitute was bending down, he saw very clearly the private parts of the woman. At once intense Vairagya dawned in his mind. He retraced his steps to his house with the ornament in his hands. He gave back the ornament to his sister-in-law and related to her all that had happened. He said, \"My dear sister-in-law! Thank you so much for all your kind acts. I am a changed man now.\"<br />\nSo the Whore become Goddess Kali !<br />\n<br />\n<br />\nWith Best Wishes,<br />\n<br />\nSushanta Das</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_32BR\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 22.4px; margin-left: 36px; margin-top: 1em;\">\n<span id=\"bc_0_32b+seedKb6CD\" kind=\"d\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"comment-thread inline-thread\" id=\"bc_0_31T\" kind=\"t\" style=\"background-color: #eeeeee; margin: 8px 0px; padding: 0.5em 1em;\" t=\"0\" u=\"0\">\n<span id=\"bc_0_32b+seedKb6CD\" kind=\"d\"><span class=\"thread-toggle thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_31TT\" kind=\"g\" style=\"cursor: pointer; display: inline-block;\"><span class=\"thread-count\" id=\"bc_0_31TN\"></span></span></span><br />\n<div class=\"thread-dropContainer thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_31TD\">\n<span id=\"bc_0_32b+seedKb6CD\" kind=\"d\"><span class=\"thread-toggle thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_31TT\" kind=\"g\" style=\"cursor: pointer; display: inline-block;\"><span class=\"thread-count\" id=\"bc_0_31TN\"><span class=\"thread-drop\"></span></span></span></span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_32b+seedKb6CD\" kind=\"d\"><span class=\"thread-toggle thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_31TT\" kind=\"g\" style=\"cursor: pointer; display: inline-block;\"><span class=\"thread-count\" id=\"bc_0_31TN\">\n</span></span><br />\n</span><br />\n<ol class=\"thread-chrome thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_31TC\" style=\"list-style-type: none; padding: 0px;\"><span id=\"bc_0_32b+seedKb6CD\" kind=\"d\">\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_31B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"border-bottom-width: 0px; margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 16px 0px 0px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c5529169129840204972\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_31M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/07/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_27.html?showComment=1469693424730#c5529169129840204972\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">July 28, 2016 at 1:40 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_31MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nALL THIS POISON INJECTION IS STILL GOING ON <b><span style=\"color: red;\">WITH ACTIVE HELP FROM THE HINDU ORGANISATIONS.</span></b><br />\n<br />\nWHY DID PM MODI GO TO KAMAKHYA TEMPLE ?<br />\n<br />\nIS HE ALICE IN WONDERLAND ?<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/09/aghoris-corpse-eaters-of-india-capt.html</span></div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</span></ol>\n<span id=\"bc_0_32b+seedKb6CD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_32b+seedKb6CD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">2.36\u2014</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;\"> </span></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">satyapratishthayam\nkriyafalashrayatvam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">When the sadhaka is\nfirmly established in the practice of truth, his words become so potent that\nwhatever he says comes to realisation. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sanatana Dharma is all\nabout using your conscience. There is no single holy book or single messiah to\nguide you. Never hush your inner voice, it is who you are-it is the voice of\nthe soul within you.&nbsp; Never let the voice\nof other people drown out this inner voice. Sanatana Dharma does not allow you\nto be trapped by dogma\u2014which is the fruit of other peoples thinking. Rather this\ngreat religion implores you to have the courage and the balls to follow your\nheart. Yoga enables you to develop this inner vision . The human ego constantly\ncompetes with the soul for control of this inner voice. In Hinduism we do NOT\ncremate humans who have burn their ego. When a yogi is totally established in\ntruth, whatever he says will come true \u2013 whether it be a curse or a blessing\nsays Pananjali. Through honesty, a state of fearlessness comes. Yogi\u2019s life\nbecomes an open book. The words of a truthful person always are infallible as\nthey always bring fruit. If the yogi says to someone, \"be virtuous\"\n(of course, the person should be deserving), then the person will become\nvirtuous. &nbsp;&nbsp;The power of truth can sway\nthe mind of the listener to act according to the yogi\u2019s words. The yogi\nestablished in truth does not exploit and is fit to become the guru of a\ndeserving disciple. Another interpretation of the sutra is that a truthful yogi\nhas control over actions and over the fruits they bear in future births. Truth,\nestablished in mind, is the substrate for all actions and consequences of the\npractitioner. Truth as a substrate, not just the basis, is recommended to be\nintegral to and guiding principle for all life\u2019s activities of mind, word, and\nbody. &nbsp;The Yogi\u2019s attainment of the state\nof truth is indicated by his ability to guide by example. Satyam is truth to\noneself. The yogic practice of satya (truth) focuses on carefully choosing our\nwords so they do the least harm\u2014and most good.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The spoken word\nhas the capacity to inspire, frighten, and delight.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because\nsatya is presented as a yama, Patanjali\u2019s teaching on the subject has mainly\nbeen associated with restraint rather than with action\u2014with what we should\nrefrain from doing rather than with what specifically we should do. The\nteaching of satya is not presented in this manner as an accident or oversight.\nIn most ways, the practice of satya is about restraint: about slowing down,\nfiltering, carefully considering our words so that when we choose them, they\nare in harmony with the first yama, ahimsa. Patanjali and his major\ncommentators state that no words can reflect truth unless they flow from the\nspirit of nonviolence . Truth hurts only for a little while, a lie hurts\nforever. Telling the truth and making someone cry is better than telling a lie\nand making someone smile. &nbsp;The naked\ntruth is better than the best dressed lie. &nbsp;Denying the truth does not change facts.\nMistakes must be used to derive lessons from. You cant change the truth, but\ntruth can change you. The worst thing about being lies to is realizing that you\nwere not worth the truth. Always be truthful to yourself. Wisdom exists only in\ntruth. Remember , within the family , honesty is the highest form of intimacy.\nHonesty is better than sugar coated bull. &nbsp;Honest hearts produce honest actions. In the\npath of &nbsp;Patanjali\u2019s yoga, honesty is\nvital. In Indian yoga, intuition is the single greatest tool to finding\nhappiness . Intuition is soul guidance or the inner voice.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Intuition\nhelps you stay in the present, as advocated in the Bhagavat Gita.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Intuition\nis a gift of crisis--- It tells you the right thing to do when you don't have\ntime to figure it all out. Intuits are able to see possibilities and\nalternatives that aren\u2019t immediately apparent. Your inner knowing comes from\nfirst your instincts, second your intellect, and third from your intuition.</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\ndivining power of intuition comes from our inner self. It arises from very\nrapid processing of bits of information that are stored in our subconscious.\nIntuition thinks in terms of metaphor, feelings, pictures, and the spatial\nwhole and doesn't fit neatly into the cause-and-effect model.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It\nis about trusting your own integrity - trusting your soul.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Your\nintuition will not force you to do things that are truly wrong for yourself or\nother people in contradiction with the laws of the universe. Intuition is\nlistening to the inner voice or heeding the promptings from within.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Intuition\nbuilt within by yoga , gives you the ability to cut through the thickness of\nsurface reality.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Your sub-conscious which operates a\ndozen times faster than your conscious mind has picked up on signals that your\nconscious mind has not yet processed. We function through partial information,\nand intuition gives us an overview, a whole sense of things. Intuition acts\nlike a bridge between your logical reasoning and the sum total of your\nexperience-based knowledge.Intuition is a knowing, a sensing that is beyond the\nconscious understanding \u2014 a gut feeling-- flashes of spontaneous thought that\nare done apparently without relating to facts or logic. The choices we make determine\nour destiny.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.37\u2014 asteyapratishthayam\nsarvaratnopasthanam</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">When abstention from\nstealing is firmly established, precious jewels come. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Upon the man who does\nnot take what does not belong to him, all riches are showered. Staying without\ndesire, he smoothly attracts what is precious - materially and figuratively,\nincluding the gem of all jewels - virtue. The practice of asteya demands that\none must not steal, nor have the intent to steal another's property through\naction, speech and thoughts. We steal because of greed. We don\u2019t allow other\npeople to use things that we own but are not able to make use of. It can also\nmean not hoarding materials you don't need, mindlessly consuming natural\nresources, coveting other people's possessions, or appropriating other people's\nideas.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Asteya\nis also the notion of not stealing the most precious and non-renewable resource\nof all: time. Time and tide awaits none. The yogi established in true honesty\nattracts not only the best of material things but also the best of noble\npeople. Not wanting to take something that belongs to somebody else because of\nfear of retribution or punishment by law is a trivial case of the non-stealing\nattitude. Established in spiritual pursuit, the yoga practitioner strives to\nroot out desire for ownership. The practitioner voluntarily gives up any claim\nfor anything. &nbsp;&nbsp;Such a yogi exudes an\naura.&nbsp; A contented mind is a continuous\nfeast. &nbsp;Do unto others as you would have\nthem do for you. When we make others wait for us we steal their time. When we\nignore somebody we steal their dignity. When we get paid and not do a day\u2019s\nwork we shortchange our employers. Stealing encompasses everything from the\nsimple swiping of a loaf of bread to distracting attention away from the one\nwho merited it. Asteya is ubiquitous. Be mindful of it. Stealing in any form\nemerges from a deep-seated fear.&nbsp; Jealousy\nand envy often lead us to take what isn\u2019t freely ours.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Jealousy\nis a raw human emotion created when a person feels insecure about his value to\nother people.&nbsp; It consists of negative\nfeelings, revolving around&nbsp;&nbsp; fear and\nanxiety over an anticipated loss .&nbsp; When\nyou compare yourself to others , it will lead to destructive thinking.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Have\nyou noticed how people go on Facebook and feel miserable.&nbsp; For all and sundry are waxing lyrical of ZE\ngood life.&nbsp; Jealousy is the religion of\nthe mediocre. It comforts them, it soothes their worries, and finally it rots\ntheir souls, allowing them to justify their meanness and their greed,&nbsp; until they believe these to be virtues.</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Self\nworth comes with self appreciation and love.&nbsp;\nPeople who are truly comfortable and secure with themselves, rarely let\njealousy get in the way .&nbsp; Hinduism\nmaintains that anything which causes the mind to lose balance with itself ,\nleads to misery.&nbsp; Envy cannot coexist\nwith truth and spiritual wisdom.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Greed, a form of\nstealing, is rampant in the world today and we are seeing the results as our\nforests dwindle, the poor starve, the skies pollute, and our waters clog with\nwaste and toxins.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As we explore Asteya deeper, we realise\nthat it\u2019s not enough to not-steal.&nbsp;\nGenerosity is the heart of Asteya.&nbsp;\nWe give because of the joy of giving, not just in order to receive what\nwe want.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fully embodied in Asteya, non-stealing, we become\ncontent and peaceful. A peaceful mind is our greatest wealth.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">No\nitem or accomplishment can bring us lasting peace and contentment like Asteya.\nThat\u2019s something worth striving for. Desire and want, is what causes us to go\nout of our way to obtain something. Often, the things we buy and don\u2019t need,\ncould be appreciated by someone else, but by needlessly taking them for\nourselves, we rob others of the chance to have what they do need.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Asteya\nand Aparigraha are two of several important virtues in Hinduism &nbsp;They both involve interaction between a person\nand material world, either as property, fame or ideas; yet Asteya and\nAparigraha are different concepts. Asteya is the virtue of non-stealing and not\nwanting to appropriate, or take by force or deceit or exploitation, by deeds or\nwords or thoughts, what is owned by and belongs to someone else. Aparigraha, in\ncontrast, is the virtue of non-possessiveness and non-clinging to one's own\nproperty, non-accepting any gifts or particularly improper gifts offered by\nothers, and of non-avarice, non-craving in the motivation of one's deeds, words\nand thought. Hoarding is another aspect to asteya. The idea is that you are\nkeeping more than what you need for yourself instead of sharing or giving\nthings away that you no longer need. Hoarding applies to many things such as\nfood (eating too much), money, and possessions. Of course one should always\nkeep what is reasonable and necessary to provide for one's self and family\nmembers, but a thoughtful analysis should be made as to what is actually\nnecessary to keep, and what one is keeping because of various attachments. We find\ncorrupt politicians stealing for hundred future generations. Remember, there is\nNO medicine for treating hoarding. This OCD is due to bad programming in your\ngenes. You need to wipe out the blue print and insert a healthy one.</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Since\nthe root cause of taking what doesn't belong to you is desire, when you give up\ndesire for things, all sorts of wealth will come to you by itself. To master\nthis yama we should try to curb our desires little by little through the\nregular practice of yoga, and eventually the mind and our actions will come\nmore under our control.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.38\u2014 brahmacharyapratishthayam\nviryalabhah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">When the sadhaka is\nsteadfastly established in continence, knowledge, vigour, fearlessness and energy\nrush to him.</span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Brahmacharya has\nnothing to do with withholding semen.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The celibate transforms\nthe energy of reproduction into spiritual energy (ojas), bringing in lustre.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">He who seeks merely to\nsuppress or subdue his sexual energy is in effect belittling his own origins. You\nare today reading what I write because all your forefathers had sex. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">If we all abandoned sex the human race would\nfizzle out in one generation.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The great yogi Vasista several\nchildren, yet he was called a brahmacari. It is when sensory pleasure is the\nsole motivating factor that brahmacarya is encroached upon.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The life force, which\nfinds sexual expression, also serves to find the warmth of one's emotions,. It\nis the creative relationship of purusa and prakriti which leads to freedom.\nRenunciation is a positive process of disengagement, not a sterile rejection. In\nthe ancient past, almost all our maharishis </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">were householders.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The religious or\neducational studentship of adolescence is also termed brahmacarya ashrama. That\nis because the enormous outburst of energy, which is released by puberty, needs\nto be controlled and channelled for the child's all-round growth. If a child\nwere to indulge in sexual activity, the moment he or she was biologically ripe,\na large part of his or her human potential would be thrown away.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is OK to have sex\nwith the appropriate life partner but </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">in\nmoderation. In the Hindu system four stages of life have been prescribed:\nbrahmacharya (celibacy), grihastha (family life), vanaprastha (literally,\nliving in a forest), sanyasa (total renunciation). In the first stage,\nbrahmacharya, a person leads the life of a student as a celibate. After\nfinishing the studies, he enters the married life of a grihastha. Having\nfulfilled the obligations to children and the society, both husband and wife\nfollow spiritual pursuits. In sanyasa, a person completely renounces all\nworldly belongings and becomes a mendicant.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In Sanatana Dharma a\nunmarried man or a widower cant perform a yajna or homam.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The word \u2018virya\u2019\nmentioned means </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">power of knowledge or\naction, vigor in body\u2019s organs and the mind, spiritual power or the attainment\nof siddhis.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Senses in control, the\nmind gains in strength of its faculties. (Brahmacharyam is the \u201con the path to\nBrahman\u201d and this has nothing to do with semen.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Attainment of Vivekam\nand its application to discernment is the goal of Yoga philosophy.Brahmacharyam\nis recommended for boys AND girls. Girls don\u2019t lose semen.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Attachment to sensual\npleasures, ( of which excessive sex and infidelity is just one part ) is seen\nas an obstacle to spiritual knowledge.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">External denial and\ninternal hankering after sensual pleasures is no form of discipline. Not\nstrenuously objecting to indulgences but gently and naturally developing an indifference\nis what is recommended. In the context of yoga practice, driving Prakriti back\nto its unmanifest state is the object. Prasadham ( tranquility) is the reward.\nThe sign of attainment of this reward is the natural ( not forced) settling\ndown of the senses away from chaotic pursuits. Brahmacharya asks an aspirant to\nthink about where he is putting his energy \u2013 sexual or otherwise. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Brahmacharya is about allocation: using your\nresources effectively to achieve your aspiration. To hone our practice of this\nprinciple, we must learn to conserve and not waste energy on things that do not\nserve our purpose. In other words, we always have a choice between frittering\naway our energy on not-so-purposeful actions (and thoughts and worries), and\ndirecting them towards those that will serve us better and lead to more\nhappiness, purpose, sense of union. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Brahmacharya,\nis as simple as that. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Brahmacharya\nmeans not misusing sex. Brahmacharya means \u2018to respect the creative power of\nsex and not abuse it by manipulating others sexually. The sex you have with\nyour wife is LOVE. The sex you have with a whore is LUST. Brahmacharya is a way\nto get to God\u2026 When sexual energy is directed wisely, it becomes a means to\ntranscend separation, or otherness. When sexual energy is used to exploit,\nmanipulate, or humiliate another, however, it propels us into deeper separation\nand ignorance (avidya). Like the other yamas, brahmacharya has to do with\nbalance, and how we choose to use or \u201cinvest\u201d our resources. Each and every act\nand thought is an outflow of energy. Some thoughts and actions offer beneficial\ndividends, while others simply drain our resources. In the name of continence,\nwe are asked to be wise investors. The yamas all center around intuitive ways\nof being, and of treating ourselves and others, so that we can be more\nconnected internally and externally. The yamas are about how to treat others \u2013\nto achieve the aim of dissolving otherness. When brahmacharya becomes stable\nthen the yogi gains great energy and power. In a very traditional sense\nBrahmacharya was a description for the early part of life, on average up to\nabout the age of 25, before marriage, time focused on studies. Here all energy\nwas devoted to learning of which much of that was gaining the tools to practice\nthe ways to self-realisation. It was typically a time of sexual abstinence.\nLater one entered family life and naturally sex was part of it. This was the\nsystem and culture around the time of Patanjali.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The yogic process is\none of channeling and managing energy within, where as in average daily life\nthis life energy, or prana, is wasted, drained out the senses. The thought of\nsex and the force of the sex drive is a huge component in this.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">One of the biggest\ndrainers of energy is the sex impulse. Very often it plays a large distraction\njust in the mind even though no physical engagement has occurred. It is very\ndifficult for that individual to find peace when the mind is continually\ndistracted and desirous of sexual activity. It draws the energy down and keeps\nit low. The flip side is some people totally suppress the sexual urge which\nleads to an unnatural repressed state and block. Sex is a need, both for\nsociety and for our personal well-being. Abstinence should never be forced. It\nshould come naturally. One might find at a point in life that time in sex is\ncomplete. This aspect of Brahmacharya has arisen from within.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Brahmacharya is about </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">harnessing the energy or power of our senses\nand directing that instead to greater personal understanding- not withholding\nsemen. Lot of TATTUS who can get it up and homosexuals who only get sexually excited\nwith a male asshole , have become gurus..&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">What is clear is that\nnowhere in Yoga does it suggest a liberal use of sex and random partners to\nsatisfy one\u2019s craving and appetite. It comes up in the Yamas after Ahimsa\n(don\u2019t hurt another), Satya (be truthful) and Asteya (no greed, don\u2019t take what\nis not your\u2019s). Typically loose sexual conduct ends up with one person being\nhurt and very often lied to. People feel let down and something taken from\nthem. So to follow these three Yamas is key in behaviour and relations with\nanother. Then the sexual activity becomes shared and understood.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Enjoy sex when engaged\nin it.
