The self\ncontrol as meant by Brahmacharya brings a healthy relationship into your life\nand, being so channeled, gives great strength and energy, as Patanjali has\nexplained. If complete celibacy arises then it is as a natural result of the\nfocus and practices engaged in over the years of rigorous </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">penance and yoga practice. Transmutation of\nsex-desire is a very potent, efficacious and satisfactory way to realise\neternal Bliss. The technical meaning of Brahmacharya is self-restraint,\nparticularly mastery of perfect control over the senses- not the prick alone. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">I repeat again , forget\nthe bull given by fake TATTUS who cant get it up / homosexual gurus \u2013 </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The word brahmacharya literally means a\nlifestyle adopted to seek and understand Brahman \u2013 the Ultimate Reality.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">means \"devoting oneself to Brahman\".Brahmacharya\nis the virtue of celibacy when unmarried and fidelity when married. It\nrepresents a virtuous lifestyle that also includes simple living, meditation\nand other behaviors. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Brahmacharyammeans\nan overall lifestyle conducive to the pursuit of sacred knowledge and spiritual\nliberation. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Brahmacharya is a means, not\nan end. It usually includes cleanliness, ahimsa, simple living, studies,\nmeditation, and voluntary restraints on certain foods, intoxicants, and behaviors-(including\nsexual behavior.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201c<i>Now what people call\nyaj\u00f1a (sacrifice) is really Brahmacharya, for only by means of Brahmacharya\ndoes the knower attain that world (of Brahman). And what people call Ishta\n(worship) is really Brahmacharya, for only worshipping by means of Brahmacarya\ndoes one attain the Atman (the liberated Self). Now, what people call the\nSattrayana (sacrificial session) is really Brahmacharya, for only by means of\nBrahmacharya does one obtain one's salvation from Sat (Being). And what people\ncall the Mauna (vow of silence) is really Brahmacharya for only through\nBrahmacharya does one understand the Atman and then meditate. Now, what people\ncall a Anasakayana (vow of fasting) is really Brahmacharya, for this Atman\nnever perishes which one attains by means of Brahmacharya. And what people call\nthe Aranyayana (life of a hermit) is really Brahmacharya, for the world of\nBrahman belongs to those who by means of Brahmacharya attain the seas Ara and\nNya in the world of Brahman. For them there is freedom in all the worlds</i>.\u201d \u2014\u2009Chandogya\nUpanishad, VIII.5.1 - VIII.5. 5000 BC.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Vedas and &nbsp;Upanishadic SRUTI texts of Hinduism in their\ndiscussion of Brahmacharya, make no mention of &nbsp;any restraint on sexual activity. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Now we have the FAKE Brahmakumari\ncult peddling celibacy for women.</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.39\u2014 aparigrahasthairye\njanmakathantasanbodhah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">When one is steady in\nliving without surplus possessions and without greed, one realises the true\nmeaning of one's life, and all life unfolds before one. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Aparigraha is one of\nthe five essential restraints (yamas, \"the don'ts\") in Hinduism, that\nwith five essential practices (niyamas, \"the dos\") are suggested for\nright, virtuous, enlightened living. Perseverance in this austerity leads to\nknowledge of one's past and future lives, which appear like reflections in a\nmirror. When the sadhaka is free of worldly aspirations, he is a krtarthan (a\nhappy and gratified person). Aparigraha means not only non-possession and\nnon-acceptance of gifts, but also freedom from rigidity of thought. &nbsp;&nbsp;Holding on to one's thoughts is also a form\nof possessiveness, and thoughts, as well as material possessions, which needs\nto be shunned. Otherwise they leave strong impressions on the consciousness and\nbecome seeds to manifest in future lives. These cycles of life continue until\nthe sadhaka is totally clean and clear in thoughts, words and deeds. Aparigraha\nis the subtlest aspect of yama, and arduous to master. Yet, recurring attempts\nmust be made to benefit pure knowledge of 'what I am' and 'what I am meant\nfor'. This judicial thinking helps one to plan one's future lives from this\npresent life. This is what Patanjali specifies when he says that the pattern of\nfuture lives unfolds to an aparigrahin. Aparigraha is abstention from greed or\nhoarding, or not receiving gifts. Accepting gifts may bind us and make us lose\nour neutrality.&nbsp; &nbsp;We may feel obligated to return the offer one\nday. The gift giver may also have expectations of something in return. We want\nto be free of any mental binding whether we are the gift giver or the gift\nreceiver. When the mind is calm and clear and free of desires and obligations,\nwe gain capacity to see how our desires caused our present birth.Aparigraha\nmeans to take only what is necessary, and not to take advantage of a situation\nor act greedy. We should only take what we have earned; if we take more, we are\nexploiting someone else. The yogi feels that the collection or hoarding of\nthings implies a lack of faith in God and in himself to provide for his future.&nbsp;&nbsp; Aparigraha also implies letting go of our\nattachments to things and an understanding that impermanence and change are the\nonly constants. When awareness is focused inward and not dissipated externally,\nit is channeled into one\u2019s chitta, the repository of past samskaras, thus\ngiving access to the past lives. Chitta can be imagined as a lake and samskaras\nas pebbles. Only when the lake (mind) is calm can we see the pebbles\n(samskaras) clearly. The chitta can be purified by maximizing the sattva\n(purity) potential of the mind. Aparigraha refers to a state of minimalism as a\nconsumer. Not just \u201cnot wanting\u201d but \u201crejecting\u201d. Again, we are confronted with\nthe questions of what belongs to us and what doesn\u2019t and what rights we have\nwhat doesn\u2019t belong to us. We are part of the Universe and we have a right to\nexist but when does need transform into greed ? &nbsp;Also, the consideration has to extend beyond\nmaterial things to intellectual property, fame, limelight, attention, dignity,\npersonal space, etc., When the practitioner refrains from appropriating\nanything more than the most minimal needs, the hypothesis in this sutra is, the\nmind is now free to engage in thoughts of why such a need for greed arises in\nthe first place. A certain vividness about our samskaras occurs in the mind. An\nunderstanding of the effect of past on the present and a freedom from having to\nreact in a certain way in the future arise. Free will begins to rule over\ninstinct.Well-known psychotherapists of the twentieth century had come to\nunderstand that the conscious part of the mind is only the tip of the iceberg\nand that we are driven by what is hidden in the unconscious part. They had\ndevised many techniques ( dream analyses, word/picture association, etc., ) to\ndelve into the hidden part of the psyche. The ancients did the same thing by\nnot wanting things. &nbsp;&nbsp;If you don\u2019t have your\nown horse in the race you are likely to see and enjoy the race for what it is. &nbsp;The slogan is \u201cWhat do I want? Why do I want\nit?\u201d and not \u201cwhen do I want it?\u201d.Aparigraha is the concept of\nnon-possessiveness, non-grasping or non-greediness. It is one of the virtues in\nHinduism.&nbsp;&nbsp; Aparigrah is the opposite of\nparigrah, and refers to keeping the desire for possessions to what is necessary\nor important, depending on one's life stage and context. The precept of\nAparigraha is a self-restraint (temperance) from the type of greed and avarice\nwhere one's own material gain or happiness comes by hurting, killing or\ndestroying other human beings, life forms or nature. Aparigraha is a concept\nthat is related to and in part a motivator of D\u0101na (proper charity), both from\ngiver's and receiver's perspective. Aparigraha is a combination word in\nSanskrit, fused from \"a\" and \"parigrah\". \"A\" as\nprefix means \"non-\" in Sanskrit, and aparigrah is thus the opposite\nof parigrah. The word Parigrah means \u2018to amass\u2019, \u2018to crave\u2019, \u2018to seek\u2019, \u2018to\nseize\u2019, and \u2018to receive or accept\u2019 material possessions or gifts from others.&nbsp; The word includes in its scope outer worldly\npossessions as well as inner attachment to material rewards, rather than doing\nthe right thing or good because it is the right thing or good. Parigraha thus\nincludes the results as well as the intent, in other words the possessions as\nwell as the craving, a sense of possessiveness and hoarding. Aparigraha is the\nopposite state of existence in thought, words and deeds than parigraha. &nbsp;&nbsp;The term contextually means accepting or\ntaking a gift, acquiring, possessing, claiming, controlling something such a\nproperty, or assistance, or constraining force on others.&nbsp;&nbsp; The virtue of aparigraha means taking what\nis truly necessary and no more. In Yoga school of Hinduism, this concept of\nvirtue has also been translated as \"abstaining from accepting gifts\",\n\"not expecting, asking or accepting inappropriate gifts from any\nperson\", and \"not applying for gifts which are not to be\naccepted\".&nbsp; The concept includes in\nits scope non-covetousness, and non-possessiveness.&nbsp;&nbsp; Aparigraha includes the psychological state\nof \"letting go and the releasing of control, transgressions, fears\"\nand living a content life unfettered by anxieties. Aparigraha is the virtue of\nabstaining from appropriating objects because one understands the disadvantages\nin \"acquiring them, keeping them, losing them, being attached to them, or\nin harming them\". &nbsp;Patanjali\nsuggests that greed and coveting material wealth increases greed and\npossessiveness, a cycle that distracts from good reasons for activity that\nshould motivate a person, and ultimately to a state where a person seeks\nmaterial wealth without effort and by harming, hurting or impoverishing someone\nelse, or some living creature.&nbsp; Restraint\nfrom possessiveness and greed, or aparigraha, leads one away from harmful and\ninjurious greed, refraining from harming others, and towards the spiritual\nstate of good activity and understanding one's motives and origins. The virtue\nof non-coveting, non-possessing is a means of Sadhana\u0101, path of spiritual\nexistence.&nbsp; In outer world, aparigraha\nmanifests as non-possessiveness with simple living; while in psychological\nterms, it is a state of non-attachment, non-craving and one that envelops the\nsense of contentment. The virtue of aparigraha is sometimes referred by other\nterms such as alobha or agradhnu &nbsp;\u2013 which\nall mean \"refrain from avarice\", \"avoid accepting and craving\nfor gifts\", and \"restrain from excessive greed\". The first hymn\nof Isha Upanishad says \"Do not covet the wealth of any man!\" The\n\"do not covet\" and \"do not accept\" virtue precept also\nappears in verse 8.1.10 of Srimad-Bhagavatam. In Shanti Parva and other books\nof the Epic Mahabharata, \"non-covetousness\" is described as virtue. In\nVaishnava Dharma\u015b\u0101stra, in the concluding chapters of a dialogue between Vishnu\nand Lakshmi, the concept of non-covetousness is extended to \"not coveting\nsomeone's spouse\".The dharmasastra includes aparigraha among virtues such\nas, \"being friendly towards all creatures\" (ahimsa), \"being free\nfrom wrath\" (akrodha), forbearance, being driven by excellence in one's\nown business, being skilled in related businesses and learning new abilities,\n\"being humble before everyone\", \"being positive\",\n\"being driven by one's duty\", among others.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Aparigraha implies the\nconcepts of charity (dana) and conservation. Taking and wasting more of nature,\nor from others, is inconsistent with the ethical precept of aparigraha. &nbsp;Aparigraha allies with ideas that inspire\nenvironmental and ecological sustainability. Aparigraha suggests the reduction\nof waste and adds a spiritual dimension to preventing destructive consumption\nof ecosystems and nature. Asteya is the virtue of non-stealing and not wanting\nto appropriate, or take by force or deceit or exploitation, by deeds or words\nor thoughts, what is owned by and belongs to someone else.Aparigraha, in\ncontrast, is the virtue of non-possessiveness and non-clinging to one's own\nproperty, non-accepting any gifts or particularly improper gifts offered by\nothers, and of non-avarice, non-craving in the motivation of one's deeds, words\nand thoughts. Krishna says in Bhagawad Gita &nbsp;\u2018Let your concern be with action alone, and\nnever with the fruits of action. Do not let the results of action be your\nmotive, and do not be attached to inaction\u2019. What Krishna is essentially saying\nhere, is that we should never concern ourselves with the outcome of a\nsituation, we should only concern ourselves with what we\u2019re actually doing\nright now as we work towards that outcome. The more we hoard material\npossessions, the more we weigh ourselves down with not only physical, but\nenergetic baggage, and the more we become attached to and worry about losing\nthese said possessions. Believing that the new object we buy will bring us\nhappiness is based on a feeling of lack that all too often enters our minds. Aparigraha\noffers us so much freedom - the freedom to work and do what we love without\nworrying about the outcome, the freedom to rely less on external and material\npossessions to bring us happiness, and the freedom to experience everything\nlife has to offer, whatever that may be. Aparigraha has many translations. In\nits purest form, it resembles vairagya, the sanskrit word for detachment and\nrenunciation. It is the path that our ancient sages too.&nbsp; They left all worldly things behind, and began\na life of austerity. &nbsp;We are a \u2018storage\u2019\nsociety of boxes, and closets, and cupboards, and homes\u2014stuffed full of things\nwe do not use, but still will not part with. It\u2019s not that we shouldn\u2019t enjoy\nmaterial objects, but somewhere along the way we became hoarders of them.\n\u201cThese things here\u2014they are mine,\u201d we say, and put them all in a box under the\nbed. To begin to practice aparigraha we have to let go of some of the physical,\nemotional, and mental baggage we\u2019ve amassed throughout our journey. Aparigraha heals\n. It is the art of decluttering . Give away all things you do not use or need\nanymore. In many ways our capitalist consumer culture demands that the line\nbetween what we 'want' and what we 'need' be blurred. Aparigraha is in this\nrespect the most necessary and difficult yoga practice we can commit to because\nit asks us not only to define the difference between 'want' and 'need' but also\nto relinquish the former. The difference between want and need is self control.\nAre you a hoarder? Think of all the cloth in your house--inside wardrobes.\nattics etc. How many of them will you use for the next 3 years. What is the\npercentage which you have hoarded? Hoarding is an effort to manage the anxiety\nraised by obsessive doubts.&nbsp; There will\nbe&nbsp; a disruption to feelings of\nself-worth, interpersonal relationships, occupation, or health as a result of\nhoarding items which are worthless. Hoarders experience intense anxiety when\nthey even think of discarding what most others view as useless objects. They\nare affected by anxiety-provoking thoughts such as: \"What if I run\nout?\" \"What if I need to know something and don't have the\ninformation available?\" \" \"What if I throw it away but the day\ncomes when I really need it?\" Hoarding usually starts in an attic, then in\na basement, a spare room, a closet, and then, eventually, takes over every room\nof the house. Strong emotional connections are formed to the extent that an\nindividual feels a sense of safety or comfort.&nbsp;\nHoarders are suspicious of other people touching possessions , as they\nfeel it may be thrown away , when they are not around. All hoarders firmly\nbelieve that every single object will be useful one day, whether it is a broken\ntoy, old magazine, torn ill fitting shoes, empty container, plastic bag , old\ntooth brushes, old school notebooks, old damaged&nbsp; music tapes .. They will have an imaginary\nemotional connection to all such garbage. Rings a familiar bell , right?&nbsp; Well be aware! Hoarders are afraid to throw\naway things, this is why it is a mental disease. Hoarders live with so much\nclutter it may endanger their physical health. Dirt, mites, ticks , insects,\nand bacteria that form over a period of time can cause sickness and\nunhappiness. Excessive paper and cloth in a home can cause a fire. Hoarders\nmake themselves miserable and and everyone else miserable. &nbsp;People with personality disorders , generally,\nblame others for their problems. They are awful to work with because they don\u2019t\naccept responsibility for themselves and therefore never change. Remember,\nthere is NO medicine for treating hoarding. This OCD is due to bad programming\nin your genes. You need to wipe out the blue print and insert a healthy one.\nYoga is the only way out. The yoga of non-attachment does not mean that we\nshould give up our goals (in practice or in life), it invites us to simplify\nour goals by getting rid of 'wants'. &nbsp;&nbsp;Yoga\npractice is about cultivating satisfaction and fulfillment from within through\nsimplifying. Aparigraha helps keep us moving forward at a steady pace, facing\nsuccess and failure evenhandedly, helping us find emotional balance.&nbsp;&nbsp; Gifts from others affect the mind of the\nreceiver. As people are extremely selfish, they make presents with various\nmotives. These motives affect the receiver. The mind of the receiver becomes\nimpure by receiving gifts. A student of Yoga should, therefore, avoid gifts.\nAttachment, and the anxiety which accompanies attachment, are obstacles to\nknowledge. Freedom from attachment will result in knowledge of the whole course\nof our journey. Who was I? How was I? What is this? What shall I be? How shall\nI be? In this shape comes to him the knowledge of his own experience in the\npast, present and future. He becomes independent and free. His mind becomes\npure. Everything becomes quite clear to him.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;\nAparigraha encourages us to consider our possessions with attention and\nawareness.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.40\u2014 shauchat\nsvanggajugupsa parairasansargah</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Cleanliness of body and\nmind develops disinterest in contact with others for self-gratification. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Purity and cleanliness\nprotects the body and makes it an appropriate home for the seer. Consequently\nit no longer inclines towards sensual pleasures and tends to refrain from\ncontact with other bodies. Although he recognises that the body is perishable,\nthe sadhaka does not regard it with disgust or distaste, but keeps it clean and\npure out of respect for the dweller, purusa, within. &nbsp;&nbsp;To that extent, he respects the body as a\ntemple. As a temple or a church is polished clean every day, the inner body,\nthe temple of the soul, should be bathed with a plenteous supply of blood\nthrough asanas and pranayama. They cleanse the body physically, physiologically\nand intellectually. The body, having its own intelligence, develops its\npotentiality to change its behavioural patterns. It helps the sadhaka to\ndisengage himself from sensual wants, and guides him towards the holder of the\nbody, the soul. Thus, shauca makes the body an appropriate instrument for the\npursuit of spiritual knowledge. Patanjali here is talking about a yogi who is\ndeep on a spiritual path and necessarily has to discard any identification with\nthe physical body. Any such attachment to the physical body can only become an\nobstruction toward spiritual pursuits. &nbsp;Ashtanga\nYoga is a progressive methodology for cultivating sustained discrimination of\nintellect for the purpose of eliminating all differentiations of the Being,\nperceiving the Being as the ( last) sole impression in the mind, and then\nlosing that impression as well to be in a state of nischalanam or absence of\ndisturbance. In the Sankhya system of evolutes, mind receives sensory\ninformation, recalls from memory, and processes the composite to facilitate the\nego to develop a subjective awareness of experience. A trained sathvic aspect\nof Buddhi can see through this mire and can display the Being as unmixed with\nlife\u2019s struggles. Recognition of this purity changes forever the outlook of the\nsadhaka. Mind is where everything happens and for the Being to be perceptible\nin it the mind has to be in a state of cleanliness. Cleansing the mind by a\nrigorous, sustained practice of yamas increases the fervor to keep the body and\nits desires at bay to avoid further contamination. &nbsp;Indifference &nbsp;for bodily needs and separation from crowds\nare external manifestations of an ascetic life. Shaucha refers to purity of\nmind, speech and body. Saucha is one of the Niyamas of Yoga. Shaucha, or\nholistic purity of the body, is considered essential for health, happiness and\ngeneral well-being. External purity is achieved through daily ablutions, while\ninternal purity is cultivated through physical exercises, including asana\n(postures) and pranayama (breathing techniques). Along with daily ablutions to\ncleanse one's body, the concept of Shaucha suggests clean surrounding, along\nwith fresh and clean food to purify the body. Lack of Saucha, such as letting\ntoxins build in body are a source of impurity. Saucha is all about is coming to\nterms with the fundamental uncleanness of the human body and moving on from\nthere. It\u2019s not so much about trying to cleanse it or see beauty in its\nimperfection, but it\u2019s really just about accepting the fact that the body is\nfundamentally dirty and there\u2019s not that much we can do about it. Shaucha goes\nbeyond purity of body, and includes purity of speech and mind. Anger, hate,\nprejudice, greed, pride, fear, negative thoughts are a source of impurity of\nmind. The impurities of the intellect are cleansed through the process of\nself-examination, or knowledge of self (Adhyatma-Vidya). The mind is purified\nthrough mindfulness and meditation on one's intent, feelings, actions and its\ncauses.The most literal understanding of saucha begins with awareness of how\nour physical state \u2013 both external and internal \u2013 impacts our outlook. Purity\nof body comes from cleanliness of body as well as from what one eats and\ndrinks. Purity of speech comes from being truthful and through use of words\nthat are not injurious, hurtful or distressing to others or self. Purity of\nthoughts comes from reflection, peace of mind, silence, calmness, gentleness\nand purity of being . Mahabharata mentions the virtue of purity (Saucha) in\nnumerous books. For example, in Book 14 Chapter 38, it lists Saucha as a high\nquality found in the liberated, happy and dharmic person,<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0928\u093f\u0930\u094d\u092e\u092e\u094a</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0928\u093f\u0930\u0939\u0902\u0915\u093e\u0930\u094a</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0928\u093f\u0930\u093e\u0936\u0940\u0903</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0938\u0930\u094d\u0935\u0924\u0903</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0938\u092e\u0903</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n| </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0905\u0915\u093e\u092e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0939\u0924</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0907\u0924\u094d\u092f</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u090f\u0937</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0938\u0924\u093e\u0902</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0927\u0930\u094d\u092e\u0903</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0938\u0928\u093e\u0924\u0928\u0903</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n||<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0935\u093f\u0936\u094d\u0930\u092e\u094d\u092d\u094a</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0939\u0930\u0940\u0938</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0924\u093f\u0924\u093f\u0915\u094d\u0937\u093e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u091a</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0924\u092f\u093e\u0917\u0903</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0936\u094c\u091a\u092e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0905\u0924\u0928\u094d\u0926\u094d\u0930\u093f\u0924\u093e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n| </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0906\u0928\u0943\u0936\u0902\u0938\u094d\u092f\u092e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0905\u0938\u0902\u092e\u094a\u0939\u094a</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0926\u092f\u093e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u092d\u0942\u0924\u0947\u0937\u094d\u0935</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0905\u092a\u0948\u0936\u0941\u0928\u092e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n||<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0939\u0930\u094d\u0937\u0938</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0924\u0941\u0937\u094d\u091f\u093f\u0930</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0935\u093f\u0938\u094d\u092e\u092f\u0936</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u091a</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0935\u093f\u0928\u092f\u0903</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0938\u093e\u0927\u0941\u0935\u0943\u0924\u094d\u0924\u0924\u093e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n| </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0936\u093e\u0928\u094d\u0924\u093f</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0915\u0930\u094d\u092e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0935\u093f\u0936\u0941\u0926\u094d\u0927\u093f\u0936</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u091a</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0936\u0941\u092d\u093e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u092c\u0941\u0926\u094d\u0927\u093f\u0930</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0935\u093f\u092e\u094a\u091a\u0928\u092e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n||<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0909\u092a\u0947\u0915\u094d\u0937\u093e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u092c\u0930\u0939\u094d\u092e\u091a\u0930\u094d\u092f\u0902</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u091a</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u092a\u0930\u093f\u0924\u094d\u092f\u093e\u0917\u0936</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u091a</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0938\u0930\u094d\u0935\u0936\u0903</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n| </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0928\u093f\u0930\u094d\u092e\u092e\u0924\u094d\u0935\u092e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0905\u0928\u093e\u0936\u0940\u0938\u094d\u0924\u094d\u0935\u092e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0905\u092a\u0930\u093f\u0915\u094d\u0930\u0940\u0924</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0927\u0930\u094d\u092e\u0924\u093e</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n||<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">(He is) free from\npossessiveness, free from egoism, free from pessimism, looks on all with an\nequal eye, free from craving. (In him) is seen confidence, endurance,\nrenunciation, purity, absence of laziness, absence of cruelty, absence of\ndelusion, compassion for all creatures, absence of the disposition to slander\nothers or to exult at gains; (he is) satisfied, humble, emancipated,\nindifferent, peaceful, unaffected by ups and downs, pursuer of Brahma, and\nexhibits purity in all acts aiming for tranquillity, understanding and the\nright.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2014\u2009Ashvamedhika Parva,\nThe Mahabharata, 14.38.5-8<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Where the yamas are\ndesigned as a framework for how we approach the external world, the niyamas are\nmore about how we view and relate to ourselves. In fact, the yamas are known as\nthe restraints, while the niyamas are thought of as the observances. The\nNiyamas are mainly concerned with the relationship between the Yoga\npractitioner and his or her own organism and energies. They can be considered\nas intimate rules of conduct towards ourselves, an internal system of rules\nthat can help us evolve and develop. Saucha, in particular, is usually\ntranslated as \u201cPurity\u201d or \u201cCleanliness\u201d; as with many other concepts of\ntraditional Yoga philosophy. Saucha &nbsp;refers to the purity of mind and of intention,\nand ultimately to the spiritual purity. Shaucha is the process of keeping\ndifferent energies separated in order to attain evolution. &nbsp;&nbsp;Things, feelings and thoughts are pure or\nimpure only relatively to our intention. Saucha from the standpoint of Yoga, is\nnot about the British cry of &nbsp;\u201csoap is\ncivilization\u201d or \u201cwiping your asshole well with toilet paper\u201d . It is more about\nmaking sure that we are aligned with the purpose of promoting connection,\nharmony and peace within ourselves and among all those who we interact with.\nOnce the intention is clear, then purity consists in the daily practice of\nconsciously selecting those objects, feelings, thoughts and energies that can\nhelp us in our path, while gracefully disposing of the others. Remember, the\nyam as and niyamas are not about \u201cgood &amp; bad,\u201d or \u201cright &amp; wrong,\u201d but\nrather about what helps us achieve peace while also supporting those around us\nin the same.&nbsp; In this sense, we use the\nword purity not in the moral form, but like in chemistry where it is used to\ndistinguish between a pure substance and one that contains a mixture and thus\nwill not provide the same results. Saucha is not about labeling things as bad \u2013\nwhether in appearance, nourishment, or thought \u2013 but rather making the\nhealthiest and best choices we can. &nbsp;&nbsp;Saucha\nis not about \u201cjudging\u201d or \u201cshunning\u201d certain &nbsp;activities but rather being aware how some\nthings can take us away from our natural state of wholeness and happiness.&nbsp; Once we realize this, rather than being\nrestrictive, the concept of saucha becomes in fact liberating, and also\nnaturally connects with our other principles such as non-coveting and\ncontentment. By making the best choices we can in terms of what we put in our\nbodies, our minds, and our lives, we can preserve our natural health and joy,\nand also support those around us in doing the same\u2026 Saucha for a yogi is less\nabout \u201ccleansing\u201d &nbsp;bodies and more about\nletting go of the clutter in our minds in terms of attachments, assumptions,\nand judgments. By entering our practice with fewer and fewer expectations, we\nare more able to be in the moment and to enjoy the presence that moment\nprovides.&nbsp; The essence of Bhagawad Gita\nis to be in the moment. Saucha helps us stay aware of the thoughts and\npractices that tend to distract us or \u201ccongest\u201d our lives and instead choose\nthose that allow us to maintain our natural state of ease and joy and love\u2026.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.41\u2014 sattvashuddhisaumanasyaikagryendriyajayatmadars\nhanayojnatvani cha</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">When the body is\ncleansed, the mind purified and the senses controlled, joyful awareness needed\nto realise the inner self, also comes through. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">With cleanliness the\nbody becomes the temple of the seer and feels the delight of self-awareness.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the consciousness\nis cheerful and compassionate, the seeker becomes ready to receive the\nknowledge and vision of the soul.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Practicing the purity\nof thought, word and deed will bring about all the benefits listed in the\nsutra. Even if you resolve to be pure, celibate and honest just for one day,\nyour benefits will make you repeat the experiment often.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Upon the purification\nof the mind, one attains cheerfulness, one-pointedness, sense control, and\nfitness to perceive the self.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In this sutra we learn\nthe benefits of the purification of the mind. &nbsp;&nbsp;Cheerfulness of the mind is attained when the\nmind gives up the obstacles of arrogance, pride and attachment, and becomes\naloof toward the body and material possessions.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">State of depression is\nthe farthest from the mental state of a yoga practitioner who, because of his\ndiscipline, is healthy of body and mind. A lot of western psychoanalysts have\ncommitted suicide.. A true yogi and a healer is never in depression.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Discriminating aspect\nof intelligence is refined; disposition is suffused with wellness; distractions\nare eliminated; and the yogi is in control of the senses instead of the other\nway around. These attributes grow and flourish in the mind which is prepared\nfor the grace of revelation of the Self. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Athmadarshanam refers\nto the revelation of the core shorn of subjective layers of perception. The\nword revelation signifies that this is not knowledge that can be gained by\nmethods of knowing. This is knowing itself, a presupposition to knowledge,\nwhich shines on methods and the resultant object-oriented learning. The mind\nhas to be in a state of clarity and readiness to accept the image. Immersion in\nday-to-day life keeps you away from recognizing the core.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Suddha Manas or Sattvic\nmind (pure mind) and Asuddha (impure) Manas or the instinctive mind or\ndesire-mind as it is called are the two kinds of mind according to Upanishadic\nteaching. There is the lower mind filled with passion. There is the higher mind\nfilled with Sattva (purity). There are two minds. You will have to make it into\none-Sattvic mind only-if you want to meditate. It is through the higher or\nSattvic mind that you will have to control the lower or instinctive mind of\npassions and emotions.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">A Sattvic mind like solitude, silence,\nsimple living, high thinking, study of spiritual books, philosophical\ndiscussions, concentration of mind and company of Sadhus, Mahatmas and\nSannyasins. A stainless mind can be judged through speech, face and eyes.\nThrough these expressions, the opinion can be formed whether a person has\nstainless mind. Higher desires, noble aspirations, lofty ideals, true religious\nfeeling, mercy, sympathy, pure unselfish love, devotion, Vichara (Atmic\nenquiry), inspiration, genius-all come from the higher, pure Sattvic mind.\nSuddha Manas (pure mind) is Brahman itself. It is an embodiment of purity\nitself.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">A\nsharp, subtle, one-pointed, Sattvic (pure) mind is needed for Atma-Vichara\n(enquiry into Atman or the Supreme Spirit) and study of Upanishads. A gross\nmind or practical (Vyavaharic) Buddhi with selfishness and lust is absolutely\nunfit for Vichara and philosophical ratiocination. Selfishness clouds\nunderstanding. Selfishness is the bane of life. The mind of a worldling is ever\nready to absorb sexual thoughts. It cannot imbibe subtle, philosophical ideas.\nIt is callous and cannot vibrate properly to take in philosophical ideas. You\ncan drive a nail in clay, but not in a stone. The mind has to be purified by\nNishkama Karma, Japa, Pranayama and other spiritual Sadhanas. Mind is compared\nto a mirror. If the mirror is dirty, you cannot see your face clearly.\nSimilarly, if the mind-mirror is dirty (full of Mala, impurities-Kama, Krodha,\nLobha, etc.), you cannot see God clearly; you cannot see the Self clearly. The\nlight of Brahman cannot shine efficiently. Clean it up with effort daily,\nthrough spiritual Sadhana, meditation, strenuous Nishkama Karma Yoga, devotion,\netc. You will realise God.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sattvic minds and Rajasic minds\nmove in diametrically opposite directions.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">A Rajasic mind likes\ncrowded cities, much talking, luxurious life, low thinking, the company of\nwomen, study of romantic novels, eating dainty dishes and selfish works.\nInstinctive mind is the lower, impure Kama Manas with desires, passions and\nappetities. The vast majority of persons have this instinctive mind only. Even\nthe so-called civilised and educated persons live on the plane of the\ninstinctive mind. Their senses are very sharp and acute and they run after more\nrefined things for their sense-gratification. They identify themselves with the\nphysical body and the senses. They have no idea of the subtle Atman which is\nentirely distinct from the body and the Indriyas. Their 'I' is the physical,\ngross body only though they know that there is a mind.</span><span style=\"line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sattvic\nmind unifies. Instinctive mind separates and divides. Voice from the\ninstinctive mind will mislead you. Purify the mind and hear the voice of\nconscience (Sattvic mind). You will have to develop the Sattvic part of the\nmind by annihilating the lower, impure, instinctive mind. If the lower mind is\ndone away with through the higher mind alone, then only will you have eternal\nhappiness and peace. Then alone will you attain Moksha, supreme knowledge and\nperennial bliss. Slay this mind through constant Vichara and meditation. Purification\nis the first part of Yoga. When purification is over, the natural tendency of\nthe mind is to go towards liberation, Moksha.</span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.42\u2014 santoshad\nanuttamah sukhalabhah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">From contentment and\nbenevolence of consciousness comes supreme happiness. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Santosha &nbsp;literally means \"contentment,\nsatisfaction\", it is included as one of the Niyamas by Patanjali. By contentment,\nsupreme joy is gained. We need to understand the difference between contentment\nand satisfaction. Contentment means neither to like nor dislike whatever we get\nin life, just be contented.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cessation of desires is\na requirement for transcendental happiness.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">An ascetic travels in\nthe opposite direction because his objective is not survival but a knowledge of\nthe Self. His objective is to clear the mind. He gradually reduces his needs\nand forces his body to acclimatize to less and less dependence on the\nenvironment until he is a minimalist. Freedom from needs leads to a sustained\nsense of relaxation.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Imagine you being\nsuffused with that feeling while you are free from needing anything. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Santosha as contentment,\nmeans accepting one's circumstances. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It\nis a as the lack of Trsna (craving) and desiring only that which is necessary\nfor one's life.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is an attitude of\ncontentment, one of understanding and accepting oneself and one's environment\nand circumstances as they are, a spiritual state necessary for optimism and\neffort to change the future. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Santosha is\na state of inner peace. Yoga Darshana, defines contentment as the inner state\nwhere, \"exists a joyful and satisfied mind regardless of one's\nenvironment, whether one meets with pleasure or pain, profit or loss, fame or\ncontempt, success or failure, sympathy or hatred\".</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">As intent, Santosha is doing one's best and\naccepting the results of one's efforts. As inner state, it is contentment that\ncombines with and works with other virtues such as Asteya (non-coveting,\nnon-stealing), Aparigraha (non-hoarding, non-possessiveness) and Daya\n(compassion for others). As outward expression, Santosha is the observed\n\"serenity\", of being \u201ctotally satisfied, not desiring anything other\nthan the fundamental\". Santosha is rooted in the desire to avoid anything\nnegative to self, to others, to all living beings and to nature. It is not the\nstate of abandonment or being without any needs, rather the state of neither\ntaking too much nor taking less than what one needs, one of contended optimism.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is the habit of being able to accept\ncircumstances one finds self in, without being upset, of accepting oneself, and\nof equanimity with others who are balancing their own needs as they share what\nthey have. Santosha is also abstaining from taking and consuming something to\nexcess, even if its appearance makes it tempting.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In cases the\nenvironment is one where one is forced to listen to a painful speech or\nsomeone's anger, Santosha is the serenity of accepting it completely as an\ninstructive and constructive message, understanding the other, then detaching\noneself and patiently seeking reform and change in one's environment.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Adi Shankarachaya, in\nverses 521-548 of the text Vivekachudamani (The Crest-Jewel of Wisdom), states\nthat Santosha is a necessary virtue because it frees a human being from the\ncompulsions of all bondage, manipulation and fears, whereafter he can\n\"dwell according to his will\", do what he thinks is right, pursue his\nown calling wherever, whenever and however he wants.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Santosha is the inner\nstate where, \"things neither distress him nor elate him much, nor is he\nattached to or repelled by them; in his own Self he ever joys, the Self is his\nrejoicing; altogether contented by the essence of uninterrupted bliss; with\nSantosha (contentment), he knows his Self \u2013 the Eternal, he is free from\nbondage, he is delighted no matter what, his life is victory; he moves where\nfancy leads him, unconstrained; he sleeps by the river-bank or the wood, his\ncouch is the world; he moves in paths where the beaten road has ended; he then\nis one delighting in the supreme Eternal\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Santosha (contentment)\nis the highest heaven, santosha is the highest bliss. There is no higher experience\nthan santosha. When one draws away all his craving desires like a tortoise\ndrawing in all it limbs, then the natural resplendence of his soul soon\nmanifests itself. When one does not fear any creature, nor any creature is\nfrightened by him, when one conquers one's cravings and aversion, then is one\nsaid to behold one's soul. When one, indeed, in word and thought, seeks to\ninjure nobody and cherishes no desire, one is said to attain Brahman\n(consciousness-bliss).&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2014\u2009Shanti Parva, Chapter\n21</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">To the man of\nknowledge, all that is perceived, there is both Sat and Asat. To him, this all\nis both the end and the middle. This truth is in all the Vedas. Then again the\nhighest contentment (Santosha) rests upon Emancipation, which is absolute,\nwhich exists as the Soul of all mortal and immortal things, which is well-known\nas Universal Soul, which is the highest object of knowledge, which is\neverywhere, which is in everyone and everything, which is full, which is\nperfect intense happiness, which is without duality, which is the foremost of\nall things, which is Brahma, which is Unmanifest and the Cause also, from which\nthe Unmanifest has sprung, and which never deteriorates. Ability to sense\nbeyond the senses, the ability to forgive, and the ability to abstain from craving\nsuperficial desires \u2013 these together are the causes of perfect, intense\nhappiness.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2014\u2009Shanti Parva, Chapter\n270</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Craving is an intense,\never-expansive compulsion to hoarding material possessions, an addiction for\nsomething or someone, and a state where the person accumulates the target of\nhis greed or lust while ignoring dharma. We crave for what we cant have .Some\npeople crave for faalthu sympathy or appreciation..</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Contentment is the opposite state, free from\ncravings that create bondage and dependence, an understanding of the minimum he\nneeds and alternate ways to meet those needs, thus liberated to do whatever he\nwants and what feels right, proper, meaningful to him. Contentment is the\nfountainhead of happiness. The richest people are not those who have the most,\nbut those who need the least. When you run after happiness, you run away from contentment.\nHappiness is FREE. It is about filling up the space deep inside, or\ngratification of the soul. It is about equilibrium or dynamic balance between\nyour </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">spirit, mind and matter. For life\nis a combination of spiritual, intellectual and physical aspects. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Santosha is sleeping well at night, because\nyou have a clean conscience \u2013 for you have never stitched up anybody. Because\nyou have a sense of accomplishment in managing the pieces of your day and feel\nlike a winner. Because you have run your own race . You have no need to over\nanalyze and then declutter your mind or tonsure the past with booze and drugs. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Santosha is the ability to say NO and pull the\nplug. Ability to cast a shoe aside that does not fit. Being graceful , mature\nand poised while doing this. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is responding\nto life proactively , not reacting. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It\nis the inherent ability to play a bad hand well. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is hope in defeat, faith in your abilities.\nKindness, generosity, patience, tolerance, humility, fairness , helping others\nto grow and reach their potential -- all create santosha. Material greed to\nfill up the hole in your life and psyche deprives you of santosha. Inability to\nsee your own assets with pride, inability to see the positive , taking things\npersonally, hypersensitivity, dwelling on nasty remarks. inability to move on\nafter grieving, seeing only problems\u2014no possibilities, being mired in self\npity, lack of grace under pressure,</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">negative revengeful thoughts, expecting too much, concentrating on what\nyou don\u2019t have, breaking your own word to yourself consistently, addicted to\nemotional drama, hysteria and cynicism, being happy at the expense of anothers\ndeep unhappiness, inability to adapt and CHANGE to the new order, remaining\nvulnerable and unhappy in the unfamiliar zone, sweating the faalthu small stuff,\nshort selling yourself, bowing to precedent, allowing criticism to shake your\nconfidence, inability to make peace with your past, living life on other\u2019s\nterms, ALL take you away from santosha.</span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\">2.43\u2014 kayendriyasiddhirashuddhikshayat\ntapasah</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i><span style=\"color: blue;\">Self-discipline (tapas)\nburns away impurities and kindles the sparks of divinity. </span></i><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Self-discipline\ndestroys all impurities, perfecting the body, mind and senses, so that\nconsciousness functions freely and accomplishes divinity. By austerity,\nimpurities of the body and senses are destroyed and occult powers are gained.The\nword Tapas is derived from the root Sanskrit verb \u2018tap\u2019 which means \u2018to burn\u2019,\nand evokes a sense of \u2018fiery discipline\u2019 or \u2018passion\u2019. In this sense, Tapas can\nmean cultivating a sense of self-discipline, passion and courage in order to\nburn away \u2018impurities\u2019 physically, mentally and emotionally, and paving the way\nto our true greatness. By mental tapas, we can burn away past impressions &nbsp;and phobias ( soul samskaras). By verbal\ntapas, we control speech. Tapas involves some pain. There is no elevation of consciousness\nwithout pain.&nbsp; However, when this pain\nburns away impurities then we feel joy. Sometimes we can bring happiness to\nothers by a little pain to ourselves. If censure upsets us and praise makes us\nhappy, we are not strong yet. As early as the Vedic texts, practice of tapas\nwas required for anyone undertaking a vedic sacrifice, jajna. The practice of\nausterity removes the covering of dirt , ashuddhi (in the form of tamas and\nrajas) from the body and the yogi can attain siddhis or mystical powers such as\nclairvoyance etc. Practicing tapas can take the form of putting the body\nthrough hunger, thirst and not falling for cravings. One can control sleep, do\nfasting or observe strict celibacy.&nbsp; &nbsp;Tapas may also include practice of pranayama\nand asana.&nbsp; Patanjali emphasizes the\npractice of tapas as a means to eliminate all the impurities \u2013 physical,\nmental, emotional etc. &nbsp;Tapas denotes , self\ndiscipline , penance, vrat , meditation and a spectrum of practices ranging\nfrom asceticism to inner cleansing . Tapas practice often involves solitude. The\nterm evolves to also mean \"to suffer, to mortify the body, undergo\npenance\" in order to \"burn away past karma\" and liberate oneself.&nbsp; In yoga tapas includes self-discipline,\nmeditation, simple and austere living or any means of inner self-purification. Tapas\nin yoga is a means for perfection of the body and the organs through the\nlessening of impurities\" and a foundation for a yogi's pursuit of\nperfection. The goal of tapas is to help focus the Brahmachari on meditation,\nobservation of reality, reflection and spiritual rebirth. In India before going\non a pilgrimage ,the pilgrims observe vrat.- a self resolution.&nbsp; It is about accepting some rigid self\ndiscipline and sticking to it. &nbsp;People\nwhen they want to even &nbsp;turn over a new\nleaf , do a vrat as a ritual. It is a thousand times more stronger than a\nbullshit new year resolution. This is always a goal in mind. It is about\nharnessing your meandering mind , which aids self focus to awaken your dormant\npowers within. &nbsp;Vrat has been given pride\nof place in Sanatana Dharma. You don't harm anybody by doing your Vrat. The\npractical aspect is linked a lot to regulation of diet or even abstaining from\nsex , rather some type of austerity. It has a spiritual tinge and hence it\nsends a message to an onlooker about how resolute you are in achieving your\ngoal,&nbsp; that you are firm as a rock and\nunwilling to surrender to destiny--that you plan to forge the hinges of your\ndestiny on your own terms. &nbsp;Non-violence,\nlove, truth , unselfishness, sacrifice, grace, honesty form the warp and weft\nof this vrat fabric.&nbsp; Optimism , courage\n, perseverance , contemplation and fortitude form the fibre. The pilgrims have\nto observe a 41 day VRAT or penance , before they go to the temple . There are\nno cheaters. Nobody monitors, as it is about your own mind cleansing. For 41\ndays the pilgrims abstain from sex, alcohol, cigarettes, non-vegetarian food,\nfoul language and&nbsp; lack of discipline. They\nhave to wear black cotton clothes, be barefooted ( in preparation for a steep forest\nmountain trail trek )&nbsp; and cannot shave\nor cut their hair, to remind them of their vrat and their determination&nbsp; keep away from worldly objects of pleasure,\nand NOT to hurt the feelings of others.&nbsp;\nThey have to bathe twice a day and visit the local temple to offer\nprayers. They sleep for 41 days on the floor without pillows. Sabarimala\npilgrimage is a great leveller. &nbsp;&nbsp;Vrat is\nall about steadfastness in purpose. Nothing can bar the way of such a\ndetermined soul--never mind that the whole world is against you..Think of Tapas\nas that little flame inside of you that motivates you and keeps you on track\nwith anything of importance in life. It makes you floss when you don\u2019t feel\nlike it. That inner fire motivates you to make changes when you know you need\nto. Without Tapas, we probably wouldn\u2019t bother to do the \u201chard\u201d things in life,\nand therefore to make any sort of progress, especially when embarking on the\nspiritual path<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">By Truth can this Self\nbe grasped,<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">by Tapas, by Right\nKnowledge,<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">and by a perpetually\nchaste life.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2014\u2009Mu\u1e47\u1e0daka Upani\u1e63ad,\n3.1.5-6&nbsp; - - 5000 BC<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In yoga practice, tapas\nis the heat that is generated as our internal purification, like the process of\npurifying gold.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br />\n<br />\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_0B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"background-color: #eeeeee;
